webTitle: The Consolations of Philosophy, by Alain de Botton

fields.headline: The Consolations of Philosophy, by Alain de Botton
fields.standfirst:
Hamilton, £13.99, digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Just call it The Little Book of Calm for the chattering classes.
fields.body:
I was wandering through the upper gallery of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as one does when one has a few hours to while away before catching a London flight, when my eye was taken by a painting of the death of Socrates. "Why," I thought to myself, "has no one written a self-help book for very clever people like me?"

It wouldn't, I realised, be warmly greeted by the hoi polloi who would see such an undertaking as smug and effete, but does not Plato teach us that it's OK to be unpopular?

My mind turned to objects of desire. A neoclassical Georgian house in the centre of London; a Dassault Falcon 900C jet, stationed at Biggin Hill; the Villa Orsetti in Marlia near Lucca; a bed built into a niche in the wall (like one by Jean-Francois Blondel in Paris); a penthouse apartment at the tip of the Ile de la Cit$eacute; ( for weekends). Sadly I could only afford three of them, but does not Epicurus teach us that it is OK not to have enough money?

Even so, I sometimes feel frustrated when things don't go my way. Why is my philosophy series only being shown on Channel 4 and not on BBC1? At times like this, I turn to Seneca. Who else?

A long time ago when L and I were travelling through the Minho, I had a bad case of detumescence when we were making love. We both consoled ourselves with Montaigne's wise words on inadequacy, but I would like to reassure my female readers it has never happened again. Ever.

For some strange reason, I think of a broken heart. Imagine, if you will, a man who meets a woman on a train who reminds him of a strangely moving picture in a Danish museum. They begin to talk and she agrees to have dinner. He invites her to stay the night but she says she has to get up early the next morning to go to Frankfurt. The next day, he mopes in Battersea Park over a copy of Goethe's The Sorrows of Young Werther. This man is NOT me. I would have been reading Schopenhauer.

Five philosophers does not a book or TV series make. I needed a sixth. But it was difficult to think of one. In a flash of inspiration, I thought of Nietzsche, the patron saint of difficulties. Hadn't I known acute difficulties in my life? Hadn't I struggled to the summit of Piz Corvatsch, high above the Engadine valleys, to read a quote from Nietzsche that I had written on an envelope from the Hotel Edelweiss in Sils-Maria to the wind and the rocks?

And if you really are pressed - the digested read, digested:
Just call it The Little Book of Calm for the chattering classes.

fields.headline: Postman Blues
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A chaotic Yakuza thriller from the Japanese director Sabu, which has a lot of energy and pace, but is let down by uncertain, and slightly callow, undertones of comic sentimentality
fields.body:
Postman Blues is a chaotic Yakuza thriller from the Japanese director Sabu, which has a lot of energy and pace, but is let down by uncertain, and slightly callow, undertones of comic sentimentality. It is the story of a suburban postman who delivers a package; as it is too big to go through the letterbox, he rings the bell and finds that the recipient is an old schoolfriend who has just that second hacked off his little finger as part of his initiation into the freemasonry of villainy. The police who have this matriculand villain under surveillance deduce the postman must be a criminal too, and this single misapprehension spirals out of control as the stupid cops assume the simple mailman is a very big Yakuza indeed.

The straight "crime" portions of the film work well, but not the silly and implausible police blundering, nor the icky and unrealised love story between the postman and a young girl dying of cancer, who, at one stage, have a kind of raindrops-keep-falling-on-my-head bicycle sequence together.

fields.headline: Erin Brockovich
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It is a laudable tale, but it often seems as though it's on autopilot... And, unlike Michael Mann's The Insider, there is never a sense of real risk or real dange
fields.body:
It is difficult to know quite how to take Julia Roberts's cleavage in Erin Brockovich, in a film based on this week's second true story, and starring Julia as the eponymous working woman who almost single-handedly leads a successful lawsuit against a corporation that is poisoning the water and giving local people cancer. Her cleavage, on show as never before, is undoubtedly there to connote a more blue-collar class of person - that title is as blunt as you like: this is Ordinary People we're talking about. But Roberts's cleavage is strangely non-sexual. It's thrust in our face, but so is Erin's periodic anger at being patronised as a woman. It alludes more to her status as a heroically hassled single mom with three kids, and also has a little of late-period Princess Diana - a non-man-pleasing cleavage of empowerment and feeling good about yourself.

Karen Silkwood she isn't. But Julia Roberts's screen presence is otherwise very familiar: her face always somewhere on a spectrum between the melon-eating grin and the deathly pale, triangular mask, where the mouth shrinks to the size of a penny and the two veins stand out on the forehead. Under Steven Soderbergh's workmanlike direction, Roberts gives a very competent performance opposite Albert Finney as the personal injury lawyer who gives Erin a filing job in his office, only to find she has uncovered a major corporate scandal. It is a laudable tale, but it often seems as though it's on autopilot. Erin gets sinister, threatening phone calls; Erin's 25-hour days mean she misses her kids growing up - we've been here before. And, unlike Michael Mann's The Insider, there is never a sense of real risk or real danger.

fields.headline: Dresdner chairman quits
fields.standfirst: Failed German banking merger claims first boardroom victim
fields.trailText: The fallout from the collapse of Germany's huge banking merger claimed its first boardroom victim last night when Dresdner Bank announced that its chairman, Bernhard Walter, is to quit his post at the end of this month.
fields.body:
The fallout from the collapse of Germany's huge banking merger claimed its first boardroom victim last night when Dresdner Bank announced that its chairman, Bernhard Walter, is to quit his post at the end of this month.

His departure is likely to increase the pressure on Rolf Breuer, the head of Deutsche Bank - the other partner in the failed deal - to step down ahead of his planned retirement date in 2002. Mr Breuer, however, said he saw no reason to leave early at the announcement of the bank's financial results yesterday.

To add to their woes the banks came under fire yester day from Germany's most senior banking executive.

Bundesbank president Ernst Welteke said the central bank regarded the failure of the merger as a matter of "regret", and that it was a setback for the country's standing as a financial centre as well as a possible cause of damage to the banks' images.

In London anxiety mounted about the long-term prospects of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the investment banking arm of Dresdner that was cited as the cause of the breakdown in the merger.

Senior managers were said to have told staff they planned to spend the weekend putting together "substantial" retention packages in an attempt to stem an exodus of staff.

In a statement last night Dresdner said Mr Walter had decided to leave because of his links with the failed merger.

"I have identified myself with this project because I considered it a sensible ... solution for our customers and shareholders," the statement quoted from Mr Walter. The merger was a "historic chance" that had been missed.

Mr Walter again blamed Deutsche, which wanted to sell rather than integrate the Dresdner Kleinwort Benson investment banking business, for the failure of negotiations.

Dresdner said Mr Walter would be succeeded by Bernd Fahrholz, the board member responsible for global finance and corporate business.

Following the decision to abandon the merger, Dresdner is at the centre of mounting takeover speculation. HypoVereinsbank and Commerzbank are seen as possible domestic partners but France's BNP, which works in tandem with Dresdner outside their home markets, and Citigroup are tipped as possible bidders. Dresdner has a strong investment banking presence in Europe but critics argue it is less well represented elsewhere.

"We think Dresdner will become a takeover target for foreign banks," said one German analyst last night.

Deutsche Bank yesterday sought to restore its credibility, insisting that it could go it alone and producing sharply higher profits to back its claim. Net income rose to a record €2.6bn in 1999, almost 50% up on the previous year.

The dramatic failure of the merger, seen in Germany as a missed opportunity to rationalise the domestic retail market as well as a huge embarrassment for the two banks, has unsettled shareholders, customers and employees.

But Mr Breuer yesterday insisted: "We are dealing from a position of strength and will continue on our path.

"We are not on the look-out for a new merger partner."

There were signs late yesterday, however, that Deutsche and the Munichbased insurer Allianz - which is a big shareholder in both Dresdner and Deutsche - may attempt to launch a salvage operation for parts of the deal.

fields.headline: A muted passion
fields.standfirst:
St John Passion
English National Opera, London Coliseum
Rating: * *
fields.trailText:
St John Passion
English National Opera, London Coliseum
Rating: * *
fields.body:
If one of Bach's Passions is going to be staged theatrically, it should uncover layers of the narrative which the familiar concert performances cannot reach. When he directed the St Matthew Passion in London in 1993, Jonathan Miller did just that, weaving the music, the text and the drama into a fascinating symbiosis. Deborah Warner's production of the St John Passion for ENO fails to find anything revealing to say about the work.

Just three elements make the new show worth catching: an intensely moving portrayal by Mark Padmore as the Evangelist, finely structured conducting from Stephen Layton, and, in the final moments of the performance, one of the most exquisite examples of kitsch to be seen in a British opera house for a long time.

Warner's starting point seems to be that of a community ritual. The singers wear modern clothes, and Tom Pye's set is minimal - a couple of benches, some stark wooden pillars used for Christ's scourging and crucifixion. Actors play out the essential elements of the story while the chorus and the Evangelist watch and comment; video projections of Christ's bloodied face appear intermittently.

Just occasionally the drama catches fire - when Pilate, intelligently sung by David Kempster, confronts the crowd baying for Christ's blood, for instance - but the rest is muted and sanctimonious. There is much aimless wandering around the stage by the chorus, many anguished expressions, much metaphorical wringing of hands.

After Christ's death, it loses even that balance. The chorus strew bunches of flowers and someone brings on a lamb, which is placed in the Evangelist's arms during the final chorale. It's a tacky idea to begin with, but on the first night the animal bleated, as lambs tend to do; the audience sniggered, and the performance ended with none of the rapt seriousness it should have generated.

Until that unfortunate point Padmore's contribution had been the centre around which the rest had revolved, delivering the recitative (in Neil Jenkins's antiquely biblical translation) with maximum meaning and effortless purity of tone; it would be a glorious performance in any context. Paul Whelan's Jesus is noble and forthright too, but none of the singers in the solo arias are crisp enough, and the ENO chorus regularly reveal their lack of specialist baroque expertise, even though Layton and an orchestra that nicely balances period instrument and modern approaches set them a fine example. Overall it's just not good enough.

 In repertory until April 22. Box office: 0171 632 8300

fields.headline: Barclays braced for backlash
fields.trailText: Barclays was urged yesterday by a leading shareholder not to risk further damage to its battered reputation as the bank braced itself for a further backlash over the closure this afternoon of 172 branches.
fields.body:
Barclays was urged yesterday by a leading shareholder not to risk further damage to its battered reputation as the bank braced itself for a further backlash over the closure this afternoon of 172 branches.

Standard Life Investments, which has a 2.7% stake in the bank, said it was the responsibility of the bank's board, chaired by Sir Peter Middleton, to ensure Barclays' share price was not hurt by a tarnished reputation.

The latest row was sparked by revelations that the bank's chief executive stood to gain a £30.5m bonus under a three-year executive pay package.

"The board must be very sensitive to reputational risks when implementing these pay proposals," said Guy Jubb, head of corporate governance at Standard Life Investments. "The impact of reputation on shareholder value must not be underestimated," he said, describing the proposed performance related deal for Barclays as containing "very demanding" targets.

The call came as the bank's attempts to fight off an unprecedented call for customer action by environment minister Chris Mullin over the shutting of rural branches.

A Barclays spokesman said: "No institution likes to go through something like this. Our reputation is important to us, to our shareholders, to our customers and to our staff. We're convinced that what we're doing is the right thing. Clearly if we continue to focus on what we're doing we will be able to move beyond this".

In an attempt to counter criticism that customers of the branches would now face long journeys to carry out their banking, Barclays said they would be able to use Post Offices for basic transactions in three weeks' time.

However, speaking on BBC TV's Watchdog programme, John Varley, the managing director of retail banking, was last night unrepentant about the closures.

"Any change is painful, but let's be clear - there is an enormous sea change going on in the banking industry at the moment," he said.

The programme of branch closures has also put Welsh actor Sir Anthony Hopkins, who is fronting an advertising campaign for the bank, in hot water in his home village of Ogmore Vale, near Bridgend, south Wales, where politicians have called for his support in fighting to keep branches open.

fields.headline: Vodafone attempts £3.6bn knock-out blow
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Vodafone AirTouch took the bidding in the government's auction of third generation mobile telephone licences to stratospheric heights yesterday with an offer of £3.63bn for licence B.
fields.body:
Vodafone AirTouch took the bidding in the government's auction of third generation mobile telephone licences to stratospheric heights yesterday with an offer of £3.63bn for licence B.

The company's attempt at a knock-out blow to its competitors, however, was criticised by an IT service consultancy group which acted as adviser to the government on the sale of the universal mobile telecommunications system, or UMTS, which is the spectrum on which signals for new mobiles will be transmitted.

The Smith Group said the bidders in the government's mobile phone auction were "significantly overpaying" for the licences based on the returns they would achieve from mobile internet commerce in the future.

The total of bids for the five licences yesterday hit £14.3bn.

Andrew Peck, Smith Groups' marketing director, said: "I'm pretty sure most of the business plans of the people bidding have been screwed up and are probably in the waste paper baskets by now. I think they are paying far more than they wanted to pay."

The Smith Group, with economic consultancy Nera, carried out the original work with the government's Radio Communications Agency on the technical and economic feasibility of spectrum pricing.

Smith Group also recently advised the French government on the merits of different approaches to the allocation of UMTS licences.

Mr Peck blamed the value placed on internet and telecommunications stocks for inflating the price of the third generation mobile licences in the auction.

He said if 10 million British consumers began using UMTS phones the cost to the mobile phone companies could be £1,500 per customer.

This is before the added cost of rolling out the networks for the five licences - estimated to be at least £2bn each.

"To recoup that cost in some way means that UMTS services are going to be hampered by relatively high access costs," Mr Peck said.

The auction, which began on March 6, does appear to be drawing to a close as five of the 13 original contenders have withdrawn from the bidding process this week.

The high prices that are being offered for the licences are being driven by the four incumbent operators, Vodafone, BT Cellnet, One2One and Orange. Both Vodafone and BT's networks are overstretched and they need to buy more capacity in order to increase their customer base.

But the bigger issue for each of the four is that not winning a licence could have a catastrophic effect on their stockmarket valuations and existing customer base.

It may also damage the investor confidence in any of those companies' international strategies.

Canadian group TIW bid £2.87bn for licence A yesterday, which has been reserved for a new entrant. One2One offered £2.5bn for licence C, NTL Mobile offered £2.7bn for licence D and Orange offered £2.6bn for licence E.

Third generation mobile phones will allow users to access the internet, rapidly download emails, music and high quality pictures. The government requires winners of its five UMTS licences to offer a combined cover of 80% of the population by 2007.

fields.headline: Working mothers warning
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Controversy over working mothers will be fuelled by research suggesting that young children looked after by other people may be more prone to bad behaviour.
fields.body:
Controversy over working mothers will be fuelled by research suggesting that young children looked after by other people may be more prone to bad behaviour.

Children who spend long days away from their mother, particularly in the first year of life, are more likely to develop problem behaviour, such as hitting and disobeying, according to the findings.

But the study also suggests that the higher the quality of day care, the fewer the problems. The research will be discussed at an international three-day conference in London next week, called Parent Child 2000, organised by groups including the National Family and Parenting Institute.

A psychology professor, Jay Belsky, of Birkbeck College, London, who will present the findings, said while it would be wrong to overstate the extent of problem behaviour among day care children, it would be equally wrong to deny the modest risk. "It would be a mistake to conclude that a lot of time in child care, especially started early in life, is creating psychopaths."

The research concerned 1,300 children in the US, and, in a separate study led by Professor Belsky, 125 first-born boys. Family environment was found to be the most important influence on a child's development. But the duration and quality of child care emerged as an indicator of problem behaviour, social skills and mother-child interaction.

Prof Belsky said that Britain was coming in line with the US, where almost one in two mothers of children under 12 months went out to work.

 Single mothers are 70% more likely to die early than married mothers and are more prone to death by suicide, violent abuse or alcohol, says a survey in The Lancet today. The analysis, from Sweden, of mothers' mortality rates between 1991 and 1995, used a sample of more than 750,000 women. It cited poor health and emotional stress as reasons for increased mortality rates.

webTitle: Ford workers told to cut absenteeism

fields.headline: Ford workers told to cut absenteeism
fields.standfirst: Workers take strain of strong pound
fields.trailText: The crisis facing Britain's beleaguered car industry deepened last night as Ford warned employees at its Dagenham plant to cut down on sickness and absenteeism or face a future of decline.
fields.body:
The crisis facing Britain's beleaguered car industry deepened last night as Ford warned employees at its Dagenham plant to cut down on sickness and absenteeism or face a future of decline.

On the other side of the country, 200 workers at Vauxhall's engine plant at Ellesmere Port walked off the job in a dispute about shift patterns.

Meanwhile, German car maker BMW - owner of the troubled Rover group - denied it had received any firm offer as yet from a new consortium which, as disclosed in yesterday's Guardian, is putting together a rescue plan aimed at safeguarding mass car production at Longbridge near Birmingham.

Despite this, the department of trade and industry is keen for the bid, originally known by its members as "Phoenix", to emerge as a viable alternative to the offer from venture capital group Alchemy, which plans to make thousands of Longbridge jobs redundant and concentrate on making MG sports cars for a niche luxury market.

Since BMW's shock announcement a month ago that it had given up its six-year battle to make Rover profitable and was looking for buyers, the DTI's preferred solution has been one that would maintain volume car production at Longbridge.

John Towers, the former Rover chief executive heading the rival project, was not available for comment yesterday.

Meanwhile, sales figures for March showed demand for Rover vehicles held up well, despite the turmoil surrounding BMW's announcement, suggesting Phoenix's hopes for a revival of the group's fortunes may be more solidly based than some had feared.

Rover sold 24,899 new vehicles last month, just 3.84% down on the March 1999 total of 25,892, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders reported.

But BMW's decision to sell Rover, announced in the middle of March, did little to stop a 14.7% rise in sales of BMW cars during the month as a whole compared to the same month in 1999.

The new bidder is thought to be supported by a number of venture capital funds and Rover dealerships, but may need government support to finalise its offer. BMW said in Frankfurt no solid deal from "Phoenix" was yet on the table.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the engineering union AEEU, said he was hopeful but cautious, adding: "[Mr] Towers is serious and ... we're serious about working with him".

Bill McIlquham, Dagenham's head of manufacturing, wrote to workers at the plant warning that failure to improve absence levels "immediately" as well as production quality would "ultimately result in our decline". Ford is conducting a Europe-wide review of all plants and Dagenham is thought to be vulnerable.

Vauxhall was reported to be "extremely disappointed" by the dispute at Ellesmere Port, triggered by new shifts to cope with production of the V6 engine.

fields.headline: Saudi prince swells AOL stake
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Saudi billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal said yesterday that he remained wary of dot.com stocks despite revealing he had taken a $400m stake in America Online, raising his investment in the internet firm to $1.4bn.
fields.body:
Saudi billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal said yesterday that he remained wary of dot.com stocks despite revealing he had taken a $400m stake in America Online, raising his investment in the internet firm to $1.4bn.

The prince, one of the world's most prolific private investors, said the slide in hi-tech stocks had presented him with "a historic moment to seize".

He has been mopping up AOL shares for the past six months and also announced a $400m investment in computer firm Compaq and $100m each in Eastman Kodak and office equipment firm Xerox.

Shares in AOL, which is in the process of acquiring the American multi-media business Time Warner, reached a peak of more than $95 at the end of last year but were trading yesterday at $65, having climbed 4%.

Prince Alwaleed's stake is still less than 1% of AOL, which is valued at almost $150bn.

The investor is well known for his ability to spot value in companies when they are weathering difficult conditions.

He has demonstrated a perceptive sense of timing in recent years, buying large stakes in property group Canary Wharf and EuroDisney when both were regarded as expensive follies. He has built up a reported fortune of $15bn and is ranked at number eight on the Forbes rich list.

"The right timing and the right entry price is very crucial," he said, citing the example of Apple Computer, which he bought into at $18 a share and now trades at around $132.

Prince Alwaleed said he had chosen his latest investments because they were strong international brands with potential for growth which had been "hammered" recently, as distinct from the sea of dot.com companies riding the bull market.

"Some of these companies will survive but they cannot survive with these high flying, crazy prices. I think eventually the market will distinguish between survivors who are making profits, and those who shouldn't be there."

Prince Alwaleed also has stakes in Planet Hollywood, the restaurant chain which he rescued from bankruptcy, and Daewoo, the troubled South Korean conglomerate.

fields.headline: The strange and silent minority
fields.standfirst: First she wouldn't speak. Finally she refused to accept a final written warning because it was typed
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: First she wouldn't speak, then she shut herself off. Finally the typist made dolls of her colleagues and refused to accept a final written warning because it was typed.
fields.body:
"I'd forgotten what her voice sounded like", remarks Jeff-the-accountant plying a fork dubiously in the hot-and-spicy special in the tribunal canteen at lunchtime.

Cherry was a typist who used to work for Jeff's firm. She stopped talking to Jeff (and everybody else in the firm) about 9 months before her dismissal.

Me: "Why?"

Jeff: "Uh, well, it was a protest about having to fill in timesheets."

Me: "And you didn't do anything about it?"

Jeff: "Well, she did fill in the timesheets. And it wasn't like she didn't communicate at all, I mean she wrote things down on post-it notes..."

It appears that things would have carried on like that indefinitely in shut-your-eyes-and-maybe-it-will-go-away world. But then Cherry brought in some six-foot screens and put them around her desk.

Me: "And the reason for that was?"

Jeff is getting slightly surly now. Rather late in the day, it seems to have occurred to him that perhaps he didn't handle things all that well. He points to a photocopy in the bundle of documents which reproduces a long snake of postits:

I AM PLACING THESE SCREENS HERE TO AVOID RADIATION FROM OTHER PEOPLE'S VDUS WHICH IS A SERIOUS THREAT TO MY HEALTH AND SAFETY AT WORK

Jeff: "Uh, she stuck that on the outside of the screens".

Me (gently): "And life carried on?"

Jeff just nods forlornly. We may win this case, but Jeff's managerial self-esteem is bleeding to death before my eyes.

So there was Cherry, barricaded behind her screens, increasingly covered in ageing post-it notes, a silent fortress in an office of less than twenty people. The eeriest thing about the case is the sense I get from Jeff and the other witnesses that this would have carried on into eternity had things not taken a further turn for the wierd.

Jeff shows me the little dolls. They look like something I made when I was a little girl from directions in an old Jackie annual involving pipe cleaners, some scraps of cloth and some retired American tan tights. Only Cherry is a much better seamstress than I ever was and the cunningly embroidered little faces are clearly recognisable as Jeff and various other people in the firm. Wearing expressions of torment.

Cherry hung the dollies on the outside of her screens by little chains of paperclips - and finally got a written warning. Or did she? Cherry turns out in cross-examination to be one of life's intransigent literalists:

Me: "And then they issued you with a written warning?"

Cherry: "No."

Me: "Well, what's this at page 42 of the bundle? Are you saying you didn't receive that?"

Cherry: "No, but it's not written, it's typed."

So in the end it was Cherry's refusal to accept a typed warning and take down the dolls that led to her dismissal. Which the tribunal finds was fair. Not that the news seems to cheer Jeff et al much. They still wear the blank expressions you see in photographs of people rescued from cults: What can we have been thinking of?

fields.headline: Oh dear, Mrs Robinson
fields.standfirst:
The Graduate
Gielgud Theatre, London
Rating: * *
fields.trailText:
The Graduate
Gielgud Theatre, London
Rating: * *
fields.body:
First there was the book by Charles Webb. Then came the famous Mike Nichols movie. Now Terry Johnson, as adapter and director, has attempted to turn this iconic 60s story into a stage show. But it seems an extravagantly pointless affair: stripped of the movie's slick, synthetic glamour, you suddenly glimpse the fragile, anti-intellectual nature of the fable beneath.

By now everyone knows the story of Ben Braddock, the alienated graduate who rebels against middle class mores first by sleeping with the terminally bored Mrs Robinson and then by abducting her daughter. And, even in this version, the opening scenes have a faint erotic frisson.

As Kathleen Turner's Junoesque Mrs R strips to her slip and then to the buff to entice Matthew Rhys's bewildered Ben, she announces, "I'd like you to know I'm available to you." Turner's mocking stillness gives the seduction scene a comic sexiness, as if Mae West were coming on to a panic-stricken Jerry Lewis.

But then everything rapidly goes downhill. Having first portrayed Ben as a virginal nerd, Johnson vainly tries to turn him into a mixture of New England Werther and romantic rebel. In the 60s, we may have bought the idea of Ben as a symbol of youthful defiance. Now - and it is no fault of Rhys's performance - he simply comes across as a graceless wimp who indulges his petty neuroses.

In this version, you do not give a toss about Ben; indeed I kept longing for young Elaine Robinson to reject this loutish Lochinvar and marry her middle class fiance. But that is partly because the best performance of the evening comes from Kelly Reilly as Elaine.

As Turner fades out of the story and Rhys is left trying to find something to act, Reilly establishes Elaine as odd, arresting and strange: a conventional girl who suddenly comes out with weird Holly Golightly remarks such as "I think cab drivers are fallen angels." Reilly even overcomes a dreadful drunk scene with her mother which thankfully was not in the movie.

What we are left with is a thin story about a morose kid who chucks his chances in life and gets away with it. In the movie we accepted it because of Hoffman, the Simon and Garfunkel score and Nichols's glitzy stylishness. Without those magic ingredients, The Graduate simply ends up looking sophomoric.

 Until 17 June. Box office 0171-494 5065.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Is it just a squabble?
fields.trailText: 13 April: The woman I work has also started sneakily changing work I have done on the PC to make it look wrong. Every one else in the office has noticed it except the MD - but he is not interested what he considers petty office squabbles.
fields.body:
The problem

I'm a secretary in a fairly small office where two of us carry out secretarial duties. The woman I work with is incredibly moody and lazy and does hardly any work. The trouble is when ever there is any work from our MD she jumps on it straight away, which makes it look like I do no work and she does everything.

I have tried speaking to her about it but I don't get anywhere. She has also started sneakily changing work I have done on the PC to make it look wrong. Every one else in the office has noticed it except the MD - but he is not interested what he considers petty office squabbles.

The solution

Oh dear, no, this is not a petty office squabble. Altering your work is serious and must be dealt with. Fortunately, you seem to have plenty of witnesses so you must fight this. You have tried speaking to your colleague and the MD, so now it is time to take more serious measures - which her outrageous behaviour demands. Whilst you cannot do much about her moodiness or laziness, the act of altering your work is a serious offence. I think you need to bring a grievance against her.

You will need to consult your company's grievance procedures to see how you should go about this (every company with at least 20 employees must have such a procedure and smaller companies much still give the name of the person to whom the employee should go with any grievance). If you are a member of a union, ask for their advice. If not, consult ACAS (their local public enquiry point number will be in your phone book).

But, however you do it, you will need evidence and witness support to prove that she is changing work that you have done with the express aim of making it appear as though you have produced incorrect work. This should be regarded as a disciplinary offence and your MD will be obliged to deal with it following your grievance. Hopefully, then he will realise that your complaints are not petty, but reasonable.

Keep records of everything she does, as well as any reaction to your complaints from the MD. You might need these if, for example, the MD does not address your grievance fairly and you end up being forced to leave the firm. You would, in this situation, have a good case to sue for constructive dismissal. However, you do need more advice on all this than I can give in this column so to get in touch with the people there to help.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: It was simply a glitch, says the exchange

fields.headline: It was simply a glitch, says the exchange
fields.standfirst: Lost eight hours all a matter of timing
fields.trailText: The London stock exchange yesterday quashed wild rumours that cyber-vandals had paralysed share trading on Wednesday, insisting that it had tracked down the computer "glitch" which left tens of thousands of investors unable to deal on the final day of the financial year.
fields.body:
The London stock exchange yesterday quashed wild rumours that cyber-vandals had paralysed share trading on Wednesday, insisting that it had tracked down the computer "glitch" which left tens of thousands of investors unable to deal on the final day of the financial year.

While stories circulated that internet hackers had somehow breached the exchange's security or a disgruntled employee had cut communications cables, the exchange said a mistiming between two computer programs meant its systems had begun transmitting share prices before up-to-date information had been downloaded.

Facing the prospect that investors would be making deals based on incorrect information, officials decided to switch off the system and start it up again, a measure which took several hours to complete and left traders' screens frozen for almost eight hours.

The exchange insisted it was confident that the fault had been resolved permanently.

Yesterday normality returned to the London market as trading resumed - although business was thin initially, although the FTSE 100 index closed 71.8 points higher at 6,451.1. "It is difficult to access but there is definitely a hangover today," one stockbroker said.

"Whether the authorities accept the argument or not, the fact is people have lost money."

While speculation mounted that the exchange might face claims for compensation from investors for their failure to complete deals before the end of the tax year, they were said to have little chance of success.

The faulty programs are managed for the stock exchange by Andersen Consulting, which was still refusing to comment on the glitch yesterday. The exchange tried to play down speculation that it would take legal action, saying it had a "good working relationship" with the firm.

The whole affair is now being investigated by the financial services authority whose head, Howard Davies, said the stock exchange still faced searching questions about Wednesday's events.

Mr Davies warned that in future investors would put more business through rival electronic systems. "It may well be that in five years' time we are looking at a much more varied picture, with a variety of what are called alternative trading systems, or electronic crossing networks, also transacting business in the same equities," he said.

Insisting that foul play was not to blame, Martin Wheatley, the stock exchange's director of business development, said: "It was simply a glitch, glitches occur. There was no sabotage, no internet hackers, nobody with a pickaxe through a wire. It was a simple software fault."

Investors looking for a fresh lifeline from the inland revenue after being unable to complete tax-related share trades ahead of Wednesday's midnight deadline were advised by officials to "go back to London stock exchange".

The inland revenue said this was the only course of action for investors who believe they have lost out by having failed to use up their full capital gains tax allowances.

"We would be sympathetic, but there would not be much we could do about it. The end of the year is the end of the year. You have a whole year to sort out your tax affairs and if you leave it to the last minute you do a take risk," a revenue spokeswoman said. An FSA spokeswoman added: "There is nothing we can do for them."

Facing the prospect that investors would be making deals based on incorrect information, officials decided to switch off the system and start it up again, a measure which took several hours to complete and left traders' screens frozen for almost eight hours. The exchange insisted it was confident that the fault had been resolved permanently. Yesterday normality returned to the London market as trading resumed - although business was thin initially, although the FTSE 100 index closed 71.8 points higher at 6,451.1. "It is difficult to access but there is definitely a hangover today," one stockbroker said. "Whether the authorities accept the argument or not, the fact is people have lost money." While speculation mounted that the exchange might face claims for compensation from investors for their failure to complete deals before the end of the tax year, they were said to have little chance of success. The faulty programs are managed for the stock exchange by Andersen Consulting, which was still refusing to comment on the glitch yesterday. The exchange tried to play down speculation that it would take legal action, saying it had a "good working relationship" with the firm. The whole affair is now being investigated by the financial services authority whose head, Howard Davies, said the stock exchange still faced searching questions about Wednesday's events. Mr Davies warned that in future investors would put more business through rival electronic systems. "It may well be that in five years' time we are looking at a much more varied picture, with a variety of what are called alternative trading systems, or electronic crossing networks, also transacting business in the same equities," he said. Insisting that foul play was not to blame, Martin Wheatley, the stock exchange's director of business development, said: "It was simply a glitch, glitches occur. There was no sabotage, no internet hackers, nobody with a pickaxe through a wire. It was a simple software fault." Investors looking for a fresh lifeline from the inland revenue after being unable to complete tax-related share trades ahead of Wednesday's midnight deadline were advised by officials to "go back to London stock exchange". The inland revenue said this was the only course of action for investors who believe they have lost out by having failed to use up their full capital gains tax allowances. "We would be sympathetic, but there would not be much we could do about it. The end of the year is the end of the year. You have a whole year to sort out your tax affairs and if you leave it to the last minute you do a take risk," a revenue spokeswoman said. An FSA spokeswoman added: "There is nothing we can do for them."

fields.headline: Reasons to be cheerful
fields.standfirst:
Ian Dury Celebration
The Forum, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
Ian Dury Celebration
The Forum, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.body:
This was not so much a concert, or even a tribute show, as an extended musical wake. Many of those on stage and in the audience had attended Ian Dury's funeral earlier in the day, and the mood was one of grief mixed with celebration of his remarkable life and unique contribution to British pop. It was a party in the old-fashioned, chaotic, pub-rock style, much as he would have wished it to be.

First up were his band the Blockheads. They have always acted as if they were deliberately trying to disguise the musical sophistication with which they dressed up Dury's gloriously witty lyrics. Tonight they had to manage without the great showman, whose picture was projected across the back of the stage, flanked by two burning flames.

They stuck, predictably, to the 70s hits that no one could ever perform like the man who wrote them. Baxter Dury, Ian's eldest son, bravely opened and closed the show, fronting the Blockheads with his treatment of his father's tribute to his own dad, My Old Man. Next to the microphone were the artist Humphrey Ocean, a friend of Dury's from art school days and from his early band, Kilburn and the High Roads, and Chas Smash from "that Kilburns tribute band", Madness. Lyric sheets were handed out, and we all sang Hit Me with Your Rhythm Stick and Sex'n'Drugs and Rock'n'Roll. It was like a finale, just as the show was starting.

The rest of the evening paid tribute to Dury's eclectic musical taste. Wilko Johnson, still in excellent form, blasted through some frantic R&B with trademark staccato guitar work. Then came 70s pub-rocker and Dury's one-time Stiff Records label-mate, Wreckless Eric, who looked rough but sounded terrific.

There was another contrast with a jazz set from pianist Ted Speight (yet another old Dury friend, from his school days), joining up with sundry Blockheads for a reminder that the old funk-punk-rocker was always a jazz fan at heart (at art school Dury booked Tubby Hayes rather than the Beatles). By now the Blockheads were getting into their stride, mixing jazz, funk and some fine keyboard and sax solo work as they headed from Summertime back to Dury's own compositions. Chaz Jankel, Dury's co-writer, switched from keyboards to guitar to join the singing on Reasons to Be Cheerful. It had been a sad and joyous wake. Thanks, Ian.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Net security broken at 60% of UK firms

fields.headline: Net security broken at 60% of UK firms
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: More than 60% of companies have seen serious security breaches through internet connections, according to a Department of Trade and Industry survey to be published next week.
fields.body:
More than 60% of companies have seen serious security breaches through internet connections, according to a Department of Trade and Industry survey to be published next week.

The findings based on 1,000 interviews show widespread negligence when it comes to net security. The breaches have cost up to £100,000 yet most companies changed nothing after detecting leaks.

Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, last night issued "a wake-up notice" to British business. She said the government's ambition was to make the UK the safest place to do business online.

Many small businesses were taking "too many risks" and needed to be more aware of the problems, which were not confined to hackers but included fire and theft.

Information security was about safeguarding a business's money, image, reputation and potential. "The consequences of security incidents can be disastrous, but they are avoidable."

According to the survey, 30% of organisations do not recognise that their business information is an asset worth protecting.

Almost three-quarters of companies suffering a breach they regarded as serious did not have a contingency plan to deal with it. More than half of those organisations did not believe they could have done anything to prevent the breach.

Some 82% of businesses with external electronic links do not use any form of "e-protection" and 59% with a website do not use effective security measures. Of those companies that have critical or sensitive information, 63% had suffered a breach that was considered serious.

One in three companies is already buying or selling over the net, or intends to start in the near future. But only 37% of organisations interviewed have undertaken a risk assessment whereby a systematic approach is taken to assess the security risks they face. Worse still, the survey showed that one in six companies did not think about security when buying or selling over the net.

Only one in seven organisations has a formal information management security policy in place. Ms Hewitt backed the report, saying that the presence of such a policy is one of the most important issues in resolving security breaches.

An important point, say authors of the report, is that companies did not consider the risks of not being paid, and therefore the credit-worthiness of their customers.

Bob Grace of Nokia internet communications, which helped to carry out the survey, said: "As an industry we need to raise awareness without causing panic. We need to remove the fear of doing business in a wired world."

 E-commerce is making faster inroads in Germany than in France, largely due to a lower rate of internet use among the French, whose Minitel system provides competition, a study released yesterday showed.

The study, conducted Ipsos for French online retailer Rouge & Blanc, showed 25% of German internet users had shopped online while the rate among the French was 20%. Only 23% of French respondents go online, against 42% in Germany.

webTitle: All hail the maestros of bat and ball

fields.headline: All hail the maestros of bat and ball
fields.standfirst: Hobbs the lone Englishman, Warne the only current star to make elite list
fields.trailText: Spare a thought if you will for Chris Cairns, Rahul Dravid, Lance Klusener, Tom Moody and Saqlain Mushtaq. In any other year they would be preening themselves this morning as Wisden Cricketers of the Year. It is, no two ways about it, an accolade to be chuffed about.
fields.body:
Spare a thought if you will for Chris Cairns, Rahul Dravid, Lance Klusener, Tom Moody and Saqlain Mushtaq. In any other year they would be preening themselves this morning as Wisden Cricketers of the Year. It is, no two ways about it, an accolade to be chuffed about.

But this year, well, they have been overshadowed by the announcement of the Five Cricketers of the Century. For Cairns and his companions it must seem like winning the county championship on the day that England regain the Ashes (we can all dream).

Today sees the publication of Wisden 2000, the millennium edition, the first of the new century or the last of the old depending on your standpoint. But despite the ongoing misfortunes of the England team, the editor Matthew Engel - who has suffered sufficient of them in his eight years in the chair to want to hand over responsibility for the next edition to his predecessor Graeme Wright - says it is an occasion worthy of celebration.

To this end, what Engel calls "the little yellow book" contains reams of stuff - 100 years of this or that, great matches, a century of photos (is Shakoor Rana really offended by Mike Gatting because the England captain has his willy hanging out? Seriously, have a look) - and top of the tree comes the century's famous five.

Now the selection of the cricketers of the year is a subjective exercise, the prerogative of the editor and no one else. He alone is responsible for the debate that will follow. This year's topic will be how Moody, worthy cricketer though he may be, gets the nod over Andy Caddick. But as for the cricketers of the century, that is another matter, requiring collective responsibility.

So Engel constructed an electorate - membership of 100, naturally, three of whom were women - comprising an international body of cricketers, commentators, writers, journalists and historians, with each of the Test-playing countries represented according, roughly, to the number of Tests it played during the past century.

Thus there were 28 from England, followed by Australia (20), down to Dave Houghton, the single Zimbabwean representative. Obvious candidates were not invited for equally obvious reasons.

Each then nominated his or her five candidates, occasionally giving reasons although not compelled to do so, and Engel gleefully counted them up. The result was like rollover week in the lottery, with no one nominating all of the top five. Yet as Engel says, no one surely will suggest that they have got it terribly wrong, with at least one of the five playing in each decade of the century and a neat geographical spread of two Australians, two West Indians and an Englishman.

Some of it was easy. No prizes for guessing Bradman, of course, for whom the voting was unanimous.

Nor really for Sobers, either, although 10% of the electorate clearly thought there were four others more worthy. This pair were streets ahead of the opposition.

Below that it started to get tighter, although Hobbs, Warne and Richards were still significantly ahead of the next qualifiers, Dennis Lillee, Sir Frank Worrell, Walter Hammond, Denis Compton, Sir Richard Hadlee (voted for by his father Walter, among others) and Imran Khan.

A further 38 cricketers received one or more votes, which, if nothing else, illustrates the difficulty with over sized selection committees.

On a personal note it is disappointing that I did not make the final five, although solace is gained in the fact that I received only one vote fewer than Michael Holding, Allan Donald and Curtly Ambrose, and precisely the same number as Brian Lara, Greg Chappell and Barry Richards.

(Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000, editor Matthew Engel, publisher John Wisden and Co Ltd, £29.99)

Wisden's famous five of the century

1 Sir Donald Bradman Australian batsman, 100 votes. "The greatest phenomenon in the history of cricket, indeed in the history of all ball games," writes Wisden, and who can argue with a Test average of 99.94 runs per innings. His appetite for runs was never sated.

5 Sir Vivian Richards West Indies batsman, 25 votes. Swaggeringly dominant, awesomely powerful and quite probably the most destructive batsman the game has seen. Scorer of the fastest Test century, from 56 balls.

2 Sir Garfield Sobers West Indies all-rounder, 90 votes. The best left-handed batsman of them all, he could bowl searingly fast left-arm, swing the ball wickedly, and then turn to left-arm spin, either orthodox or wrist. Who didn't vote for him and why?

4 Shane Warne Australian wrist spinner, 27 votes. One delivery, to Mike Gatting - the first of his opening spell in Ashes cricket - elevated him to legendary status. Resurrected the art of spin bowling in Tests when it seemed lost forever to the fast men.

3 Sir Jack Hobbs England batsman, 30 votes. The Master, scorer of more first-class runs - 61,237 - and more centuries - 197, 98 of them after his 40th birthday - than any other. "Lifted the status and dignity of the English professional cricketer," says Wisden

webTitle: If it's snowing it must be the cricket season

fields.headline: If it's snowing it must be the cricket season
fields.trailText: You might have seen my mate Paz's house on the news. It's the one on the banks of the Great Ouse by the bridge in Newport Pagnell, easily recognisable by the snorkel and flippers hanging beside the front door, the lifeboat in the garage and the video of Waterworld in an emergency cabinet.
fields.body:
You might have seen my mate Paz's house on the news. It's the one on the banks of the Great Ouse by the bridge in Newport Pagnell, easily recognisable by the snorkel and flippers hanging beside the front door, the lifeboat in the garage and the video of Waterworld in an emergency cabinet.

Disconcertingly, Paz's place is under threat from the river when the stair rods come down, and twice, in 1992 and again six years later, it has disappeared under several feet of mucky water. After the torrents of the past few days he and his family (they are the ones with the webbed feet) went sleepless on Tuesday night, jacking up furniture in anticipation of it happening again after the Anglian Water Authority issued a red alert.

Earlier that day I had pulled on my winter coat and woolly hat and caught the rattler to Wilmslow where, in a plush and steamily warm conference room at a fitness centre, Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher held a press conference. Outside, though, there were snow flurries blowing in the biffing, biting northerly wind and in the distance the hills of the Peak District gleamed toothpaste white.

So there we have it: floods, freezing temperatures and gale-force winds. It can only mean one thing, and sure enough tomorrow, at Fenner's in Cambridge and the Parks in Oxford, the first-class cricket season begins.

Now what, as Arthur Daley would say, is occurring? Years ago the cricket season would gain a sort of official status - a handing over of the nation's sporting baton, as it were - with the completion of the FA Cup final. Now the stumps are being knocked into the ground before the semi-finals have been concluded and possibly in conditions where batsmen will leave the pavilion like Captain Oates, with the words "I may be some time".

The coldest temperature ever recorded was in Vladivostok or some such, but Fenner's, on April 7, with a wind hustling in from the Urals straight over the cricket square, has the potential to knock it into a cocked hat.

In this year's Wisden, published today, Philip Eden, the weather expert for Radio 5 Live, writes about the summers of the past century. He says 1911 was a cracker and so was 1976, the best of the lot, and 1989 and 1995, but the rain during 1903, 1946, 1956 and 1958 would have kept Paz on his toes all summer long.

The hottest Test-match day in England, 34C (93F), came at Lord's in June 1975, not long after snow had fallen at Buxton during Lancashire's match with Derbyshire; the one in which, on the consequent terror track, Ashley Harvey-Walker removed his false teeth and handed them to the umpire for safe keeping lest they get smashed.

By contrast the second day of the first Test at Edgbaston in 1965 produced the lowest temperature - 8C (46F) with a wind-chill factor as well - ever recorded at a Test match anywhere. But none of Eden's charts mentions April. Even in the minds of the Met men the season does not start until May.

And how does the modern team prepare for the extreme weather? Years ago Middlesex took themselves off to a British Army base on the Rhine as a variation from the usual week's gym work at the Barclays Bank ground at Ealing, and went on to win the championship. That was proper preparation.

Nowadays sides jet off to more exotic locations in the Caribbean and Africa to limber up, "get some runs under their belts and a few overs at the back of them" as Micky Stewart used to say, and spend evenings in shirtsleeves, knocking back the rum punch and Red Stripe.

Well, much good it will do them when the time comes to dig out the long johns and thermal vests and a batsman takes the first ball of the season on an unprotected inner thigh. Provided of course the bowler can swing his arms above waist height with the volume of sweaters he will be wearing.

Of course, the Law of Sod applies to this. We all know the weather is a fickle business and that the year the authorities cry enough is enough and shift the season into May will be that when the April sun beats down, St George's Day brings a hosepipe ban and Paz is fetching his water from a communal standpipe. Personally I am prepared to take the risk. Paz and his house, by the way, have survived this time but it was close.

5 Lens are looking a little shell-shocked, and are losing possession in midfield to Vieira and Petit.
9 Silvinho breaks down the left wing and plays in a peach of a cross onto Kanu's head - he doesn't have to move - but from seven yards out the big Nigerian nods the ball straight at Warmuz, who makes the save whether he likes it or not.

16 Petit spots Overmars on the left, in space. The winger plays a first-time cross-shot hybrid that Warmuz smothers in front of his goal.
18 Kanu is displaying the full array of his abilities in missing good chances tonight. This time a cross from Silvinho is nodded into the welcoming arms of Warmuz from over the penalty spot. Arsenal are winning a lot of ball in the area and Lens cannot keep giving the Gunners these opportunities as even Kanu will score eventually.
22 Maybe because they think he can't score, but Kanu has been given the freedom to roam Highbury, the Lens defence finding it very difficult to pick him up, especially when he is in possession. nothing comes of this move, but the visitors need to be careful of the space they are giving to this talented player.
25 Petit, Overmars and Kanu combine well on both flanks to keep the pressure on Lens, who have been pushing up more after their early setback. You feel that Arsenal need to build on their superiority and translate that into goals in case this Lens side craft an away goal on the break.
29 For the second time tonight, Ray Parlour has turned down a gilt-edged shooting opportunity. He certainly didn't do that in Bremen - tonight he seems to want to play the vital through-ball when a shot is probably the better option.

62 Good build-up play on the right from Arsenal, but the final ball from Dixon is a poor one. The quality has left this game for a while, and the game needs a goal or an incident to get its spark back.
66 Overmars close to adding to Arsenal's total as he traps Dixon's cross with his back to goal, but Sikora is alert to the threat and the chance is snuffed out. A corner results, and Petit's delivery is deep, but Grimandi handles the ball and Lens regain possession.

70 A let-off for Arsenal as Brunel in space on the left for Lens, feeds Nouma in the area. His side foot beats Seaman but ricochets off the bar and into the crowd. If the visitors don't score that miss will haunt the Lens striker.
74 Arsenal substitution: Ljundberg for Overmars. The in-form Swede replaces the disappointing Dutchman. What price a Freddie goal?
78 Lens substitution: Sakho for Moreira. That brings the total Senegalese presence to two.
81 The game is reaching a climax of sorts - this largely disappointing second half has had incident and chances, but the overall feel of the game has been strangely dispassionate. Arsenal will look to super-sub Suker to inject some life into this wilting affair.
82 Arsenal substitution: Suker for Bergkamp.
84 A corner to Lens from the left is overhit and Arsenal dash upfield, only for Vieira to lose control on the right-hand touchline. Dross.
84 Some quality at last from the two subs - Ljundberg runs in from the right past three defenders to roll a perfect pass to Suker running in from the left. His first-time shot has goal written all over it but somehow Warmuz gets down to his near post and palms the shot away. Arsenal's best move this half by a country mile.

This game has a strange feel about it. No-one in the Arsenal defence is even screaming at each other after another near miss.
93 Kanu penalised for a foul on Coly and both players are mystified. It is the last surreal decision of a dull half. Full time: Arsenal 1 - 0 Lens.

webTitle: Two Leeds fans die in soccer fight

fields.headline: Two Leeds fans die in soccer fight
fields.standfirst: Leeds face stern test of character
fields.trailText: Two Leeds United fans were killed and at least five others were injured in violent clashes in Istanbul last night ahead of this evening's Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds and the Turkish side Galatasaray.
fields.body:
Two Leeds United fans were killed and at least five others were injured in violent clashes in Istanbul last night ahead of this evening's Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds and the Turkish side Galatasaray.

The fighting began in Istanbul's central Taksim Square about 10pm, as a group of Leeds fans was leaving a bar.

Police said several people had been taken into custody after the clash but they gave no other details.

A Turkish witness said the trouble had began when some of the Leeds fans insulted a driver. A knife was pulled by a Turkish man, and before the police could intervene a British fan lay in a pool of blood by the side of the road.

The police acted immediately, but it was too late. One of the dead men was identified by police as Christopher Lofthouse, the other, who also died of stab wounds, was not named. Mr Lofthouse's brother, Darren, is thought to be among the injured fans who had to receive medical treatment.

The chairman of Leeds United, Peter Ridsdale, visited a hospital with Mr Lofthouse's brother to identify the body. "It's a terrible thing," he said, "it's a real tragedy." He said it was too soon to say whether the match would go ahead on schedule.

Police in Istanbul had already beefed up security in the centre of the city, which was also the scene of trouble when Manchester United visited in 1993.

Chief Superintendent Steve Matthews of West Yorkshire police, who travelled with the team, said: "We did anticipate there could be trouble and there were 4,000 police on duty, but we never thought there would be anything like this. It's a horrible shock and surprise."

webTitle: Star lecturers to vie for £50,000 teaching award

fields.headline: Star lecturers to vie for £50,000 teaching award
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The glitz, the tension, the tears, the inflated egos - Oscar fever is about to grip university common rooms up and down the land.
fields.body:
The glitz, the tension, the tears, the inflated egos - Oscar fever is about to grip university common rooms up and down the land.

Lecturers, whose ability to keep their students awake has up to now earned them nothing more than a pat on the back from the professor, stand to win £50,000, national recognition and a "small and tasteful" award presented by a government minister.

Universities and funding councils in England and Northern Ireland yesterday launched a £1m scheme to raise the status of teaching - long regarded by academics as a distraction from their beloved research. There will be 20 Dons' Oscars - National Teaching Fellowships - and each university or college can nominate one star lecturer for consideration by a national panel, including two students.

An ability to "inspire and enthuse" students will be one of the key qualities sought and students' views of their lecturers' performance will be taken into account, although this would not be the only test, said Sally Brown, of the Institute of Learning and Teaching which is organising the prizes.

Following the success of last year's teaching awards instigated by Lord Puttnam, which was welcomed by schools, the institute is hoping that the idea will catch on in higher education as it has in Australia where the awards ceremony is broadcast on television.

Winners will have considerable freedom in how to spend their £50,000 - travel is allowed provided it can be shown to improve the standard of future teaching.

The money can also be used to pay someone else to do some of the fellowship holder's work. Several universities already have their own award schemes to encourage teaching. Napier University in Edinburgh is now in the fourth year of its scheme with 25 active fellowship holders who have each received about £500 for their record in teaching and promoting students' learning.

fields.headline: Netscape unveils new browser
fields.standfirst:
The program's first big upgrade for two years could reignite the 'browser wars' with Microsoft, writes Neil McIntosh, deputy editor of Guardian Online

Download a preview version of Netscape 6

Reviews
fields.trailText: Web pioneer Netscape today unveiled the latest version of its famous internet browser, claiming its new software represents a "major advance in browsing".
fields.body:
Web pioneer Netscape today unveiled the latest version of its famous internet browser, claiming its new software represents a "major advance in browsing".

Netscape 6 is the first big upgrade in almost two years for the program which was once the first choice web browser for 90% of internet users. That was before the "browser wars" between Netscape and Microsoft in the late 1990s in which Netscape was beaten into a distant second place. Microsoft's Internet Explorer now has 70% of the browser market.

The new product takes on added significance after this week's ruling in the US that Microsoft was guilty of abusing its monopoly power to crush Netscape, which it once regarded as a major threat to its business. Netscape is now owned by America Online (AOL).

Despite the Microsoft ruling, there is some scepticism about the impact Netscape 6 will have. As the software is free the company will not make any direct financial gain by signing up users. One analyst observed that users "don't care" which browser they use, while another added: "It¹s not really a contest any more. The browser wars are over."

Netscape has seen this scepticism brewing and knew that it would have to offer good reasons to entice new users to go through the rigmarole of downloading, installing and learning a new browser.

The initial reaction to the new program, introduced to Britain in London today, suggests they may have managed that. Netscape 6 is a complete rewrite of the browser which helped spark the internet revolution. It has a number of new features and runs noticeably faster, but still manages to be around half the size of its bulky predecessor.

It also boasts impeccable geek credentials: the new software is the result of the protracted Mozilla open-source project, a voluntary network of independent programmers who came together to keep Netscape browser development alive while the company struggled against Microsoft's onslaught.

Given Netscape's scrapes with Microsoft, it should be no surprise that the new software is designed to be more independent of the software giant's Windows operating system. The new software is available immediately to run on Windows, Macintosh and Linux computers.

AOL has also put Netscape 6 at the centre of its AOL Anywhere plans, which aim to let users use AOL and the web not just on home computers but on televisions, mobile phones and handheld computers.

Once again, that brings Netscape into direct competition with Microsoft, which is developing its own mobile browser in conjunction with mobile phone company Ericsson.

By 2005 there will be more mobile internet browsers than people surfing via their desktop PC, which suggests that, even if the desktop browser war is over, there's plenty left to fight for in the mobile market.

"The Netscape magic is back," claimed AOL chief executive Steve Case. And it could be about to ignite the browser wars all over again.

New features in Netscape 6
 My Sidebar: a second window, to the left of the screen, which can be customised to carry constantly updated information such as news, share prices, sports results and auction news. eBay.co.uk and Lastminute.com are already offering a Sidebar service.

 Faster surfing: certain types of page, especially complex pages made up using tables, now appear much more quickly.

 Integrated AOL Instant Messenger and an "intelligent" email module which collects and files the names and email addresses of everyone who emails you.

 New version of Sun's Java programming language, plus Net2Phone software for internet telephony, and Gist-in-Time, offering automatic translation of foreign language web pages.

 Smaller download files - from 5MB for the browser only to 7MB for the full program.

Useful links
Special report: the future of Microsoft
Netscape
Microsoft
eBay
Lastminute.com

Reviews

"Netscape 6 ain't soup yet, but it's off to a good start."

C-Net

"Netscape 6 is not the home run the company needs in its increasingly uphill battle against Microsoft Internet Explorer."

Zdnet

webTitle: The king is dead, long live the Kings Road

fields.headline: The king is dead, long live the Kings Road
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle congratulates Chelsea on their Champions League win but wonders whether result is really as surprising as everyone seems to think
fields.trailText: Chelsea's victory over Barcelona had Fleet Street's finest straining to come up with the sort of superlative which would actually do justice to the stunning upset they'd just witnessed.
fields.body:
Chelsea's victory over Barcelona had Fleet Street's finest straining to come up with the sort of superlative which would actually do justice to the stunning upset they'd just witnessed.

Predictably it was The Sun wot won it, describing the match as 'the night football turned blueThe night Chelsea came up with the most staggering result of their 95 year history.' But the others weren't far behind. The Star hailed Chelsea's "performance of their lives," while the Daily Mail called the display of 'Chelsea's cavaliers' the "stuff of dreams."

The verdict was unamanious. The mighty Barca had been slain by the lowly Chelsea. The king was dead! Long live the king!

Meanwhile the rest of us sat back and wondered whether this reaction was just a bit too much.

This wasn't the kind of upset that has viewers staring blankly at their screen, jaw dropped open in disbelief. David hadn't slain Goliath. Buster Douglas hadn't whupped Mike Tyson. All that happened was that one very rich team - who are currently fifth in the Premiership had beaten another very rich team, who are second in Spain's Primera Liga.

Where's the great shock in that?

Anyone that doubts this should have a closer look at the two teams. First of all, Chelsea aren't the plucky - but painfully limited - side they were a couple of years ago. That team, lest we forget, had a backbone of Eddie Newton, Frank Sinclair and Paul Furlong - and Frode Grodas in goal.

These days every player from one to eleven is a full international. Marcel Desailly and Didier Deschamps have won the World Cup and Champions League - and Albert Ferrer has also picked a European Cup. After what they've gone through, do you really think a home match in the Champions League - even against the mighty Barcelona - is going to worry them?

Futhermore, the results of the mighty Barcelona - who were heralded as the best team on the planet when then arrived in London earlier this week - haven't been that convincing in the Primera Liga.

They've twice lost a league game in the Nou Camp this season - to mid-table Malaga and the mighty Alaves (who have also incidentially done the double over them). And their away form has been patchy too. They've been beaten by sides deep in the relegation quagmire, like Real Betis and Seville, and just last month were thrashed 3-0 by Real Madrid - who most people had written off before their game against Manchester United on Tuesday.

In short, we need a sense of perspective here. Barcelona are a fine team, and boast an attacking three of Patrick Kluivert, Luis Figo and Rivaldo which is the equal of any side in the world. But they're not the sporting supermen that everyone built them up to be, particularly in defence. Similarly, Chelsea aren't quite the no-hopers that everyone seemed to think either.

What last night's game really showed us was that when two teams with world class players meet, the result is never a foregone concusion, whatever the tabloids say. Any team - no matter how good they supposedly are - is fallible. And as Chelsea proved, when they are hit hard enough - and often enough - even the giants of the world game can come crashing down.

webTitle: Two dead but game will go ahead

fields.headline: Two dead but game will go ahead
fields.standfirst: Hear Daniel Taylor's report from Istanbul
fields.trailText: Security has been increased in Istanbul today following the decision to go ahead with tonight's Uefa Cup tie between Galatasaray and Leeds United despite a night of violence in which two Leeds fans were stabbed to death. Around 13, 000 police have already been deployed around Galatasaray's Ali Semi Yen stadium.
fields.body:
Security has been increased in Istanbul today following the decision to go ahead with tonight's Uefa Cup tie between Galatasaray and Leeds United despite a night of violence in which two Leeds fans were stabbed to death. Around 13, 000 police have already been deployed around Galatasaray's Ali Semi Yen stadium.

Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight were killed and another Leeds fan was left seriously ill in hospital with knife wounds after fighting in Istanbul's Taksim square last night. At least three other Leeds fans were injured in clashes. Earlier today Galatasaray secretary general Sinan Kalpakcioglu said that 16 Turks had been placed in detention after the incident, and two had been formally identified as being involved in the stabbings. He also claimed that police also had camera evidence to back up the identification.

The fixture itself had remained in doubt until this morning, when Leeds United chairman Peter Ridsdale confirmed that an agreement had been reached between both clubs and Uefa. "The Uefa view was that it should go ahead as planned and we accept that," Ridsdale said.

Galatasaray have welcomed the decision to play on, claiming that their fans were not responsible for the stabbings and that they should not be punished as a result. "This has nothing to do with Galatasaray," said board member Aziz Ustel. "The incident is very, very sad. We have had previous matches with all the European clubs in Turkey and nothing has ever happened. This is the first time such an incident has taken place in Istanbul."

Leeds have cancelled all official flights that were to have brought around 200 supporters to Istanbul today. Ridsdale has urged these fans, and those planning to travel to Turkey independently, to remain in Britain.

"In the light of last night's tragic events when two Leeds United supporters were killed in Istanbul, we have decided to cancel all official flights scheduled to travel today," he said in a statement.

"We are also appealing to any supporters who were intending to travel independently not to do so. This advice has been given for everybody's well-being and personal safety.

Prime Minister Tony Blair offered his sympathies to the bereaved families this afternoon and asked that supporters remain calm. "While the facts are being established his thoughts and the thoughts of everybody in Government are with the families of the two men who died," a Downing Street spokesman said. "We would add our voice to those who appealing for calm ahead of today's game."

Leeds supporters claimed that hordes of Turks attacked them after emerging from shops, restaurants and cafes brandishing bottles and glasses.

One Leeds fan in Britain, who spoke to fellow supporters on their mobile phones in Istanbul after the violence, said "absolute mayhem" had broken out.

"There were about 30 Leeds fans in a bar and then it all kicked off somehow. Then they said Turks came out of shops, restaurants and cafes and attacked them," said the supporter, who did not want to be named.

"They said the Turks were carrying bottles, knives, glasses, anything they could get their hands on and just rushed at them."

Fans on both sides were said to have used an array of weapons. The Foreign Office said today that one Briton had been arrested as a result of a separate incident.

The British Consul General in Istanbul, Peter Hunt, said today there had been no warning of the violence to come.

"There was nothing in the days running up to this match to suggest there would be this level of violence," he told BBC Radio Four.

FA spokesman Steve Double said that it was far too early to determine whether last night's violence would damage England's bid to host the World Cup in 2006.

"We are also very conscious of the fact that in recent years the English fan abroad has in many instances, particularly in European club football, been certainly more sinned against than sinning."

fields.headline: Petrol bomb thrown at church
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A gospel church was petrol-bombed as worshippers inside conducted a bible study class, in what appears to be a racist attack, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A gospel church was petrol-bombed as worshippers inside conducted a bible study class, in what appears to be a racist attack, police said yesterday.

None of the congregation of 15 was injured when the bomb was thrown at the front door of the mainly white Full Gospel Mission Church in Nelson, Lancashire.

Detective Sergeant Steve Chard said: "It was a fairly minor attack and there was a small amount of fire damage to the door. But it appears that it might be racially motivated.

"Nothing like this has ever happened before in this area and we are determined to find whoever is responsible."

Police believe the attack is linked to three anti-white racist leaflets stuck to the windscreens of cars parked outside the church.

Minister David Bullock said the bible class was coming to an end when the attack happened on Tuesday night.

"I heard a loud smash of glass and looked up from the pulpit and saw the flames bursting up from the doors, which have a glass panel at the top," he said. "I jumped down and ran to tell people to get out."

Mr Bullock said there had been several attacks on the church over the past 18 months, including vandalism to cars, graffiti and arson attempts.

He said: "These people are so cowardly because they won't face me and discuss the issues. They do this kind of thing instead."
