webTitle: Mandela vows aid to race killing case

fields.headline: Mandela vows aid to race killing case
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Former South African president Nelson Mandela last night pledged to help the family of two black men who died in suspicious circumstances in Telford in their fight for justice.
fields.body:
Former South African president Nelson Mandela last night pledged to help the family of two black men who died in suspicious circumstances in Telford in their fight for justice.

Mr Mandela met Clifton McGowan, whose brother Errol and nephew, Jason, were both found hanged in separate incidents. They are believed to be the victims of racist attacks.

Mr McGowan and his wife Dawan met Mr Mandela at a £200-a-head dinner organised by the Board of Deputies of British Jews in London, when he offered his support.

The McGowan family hope that an endorsement for their campaign to bring their relatives' killers to justice will echo the impact of Mr Mandela's meeting seven years ago with the Lawrence family.

Mr Mandela met with Doreen and Neville Lawrence, the parents of murdered black teenager Stephen, in May 1993 two weeks after his murder, and the first arrests were made by police the following day.

Although Errol McGowan, 34, was found dead in July 1999 and Jason, 20, was found dead on New Year's Day, police have so far failed to arrest any suspects.

A fresh investigation into both deaths was agreed earlier this year by West Mercia police chief constable, Peter Hampson. They had previously been dismissed as suicides, despite evidence of a campaign of racial harassment and death threats against Errol McGowan. Jason had been investigating his uncle's death when he was found dead.

Last night Clifton McGowan said: "I spoke to him [Mandela] just briefly and he has all the details of our case. He's promised us he would comment on it and he was sympathetic. I'm sure it will make a difference to our case. I'm sure whatever he says will spur the police on to be a lot more active than they have been."

Mr Mandela is on a private visit to Britain and Ireland to see friends and to raise funds for his charity the Mandela Foundation.

He promised the McGowan family that he would offer words of support to their campaign before he leaves for Ireland on Friday.

The McGowans were the guests of Lee Jasper, the director of anti-racist campaign group the 1990 Trust, at the dinner at the Park Lane Hotel in London last night.

Mr Jasper said: "I have been assured Mr Mandela will look at the briefings before he leaves."

fields.headline: An about-turn at the turnstiles
fields.standfirst: Ticket prices are being frozen or dropped. What's going on?
fields.trailText: Ticket prices are being frozen or dropped. What's going on?
fields.body:
Something strange is happening at the bloated end of English football. For the past few seasons at this time of year the papers have reported in shocked tones as the envelopes containing next year's prices start fluttering through letter-boxes of Premiership season ticket holders. Gargantuan rises have been the order of the day at many clubs, though, in defence of Manchester United and Arsenal, not even the biggest have necessarily followed the trend.

This year, however, things have been startlingly different. Chelsea and Tottenham, two of the grossest over-chargers in the Premiership, have both announced that season ticket prices are to be frozen for two years (in Chelsea's case from the beginning of the 2001-2 season). Watford, whose disastrous pricing policy in their Premiership season has resulted in a failure to fill even Vicarage Road's 22,000 capacity for most games, have reduced their prices for next season to a level below that of their 1998-99 promotion campaign. Aston Villa, who have also suffered from low attendances this season, have followed suit and will drop their prices next season.

There is more than one possible interpretation of this miraculous development. The most obvious is that clubs have realised that enough is enough. The market simply will not bear any further increases. On the face of it that seems unlikely, since both Chelsea and Tottenham have enjoyed near capacity crowds for almost every Premiership game this season.

Those figures, however, do mask the flow of supply and demand to some extent, since a very high proportion of the crowd is made up of season ticket holders. For matches where season tickets were not valid, attendances have not been quite so impressive.

Four thousand seats remained unsold for Chelsea's fourth and fifth round FA Cup ties against Nottingham Forest and Leicester, while even their FA Cup semi-final allocation does not seem likely to sell out, at the time of writing. So there may be a sense that some limits have been reached.

On the other hand, the story that has made the news this April is that all Premiership clubs can expect vastly inflated revenues from the next television deal and the big clubs most of all, since they now have restricted rights to show their games on their own TV channels and on the internet.

Perhaps the move to freeze prices is more of a nod to Silvio Berlusconi's prediction that top European clubs would eventually let punters in for free, to create the atmosphere for which TV consumers would pay handsomely. Perhaps.

But even if it were true that the money through the turnstiles was insignificant for mega-clubs (which it isn't, yet), what kind of football club owner would deny himself any income he thought he could get his hands on? Not one like Ken Bates or Alan Sugar, that's for sure.

webTitle: War on want hampered by 'crazy' conflict

fields.headline: War on want hampered by 'crazy' conflict
fields.standfirst: As the prospect of famine looms over Ethiopia, Mark Tran explains why the relief efforts of the west are being undermined by the war with neighbouring Eritrea
fields.trailText: As America and Europe step up relief efforts to avert a new famine in Ethiopia, the country's foreign minister, Seyoum Mesfin, said he had warned international donors back in December that a food crisis was imminent.
fields.body:
As America and Europe step up relief efforts to avert a new famine in Ethiopia, the country's foreign minister, Seyoum Mesfin, said he had warned international donors back in December that a food crisis was imminent.

"I'm afraid to say this is Africa, and the situation in Africa always gets a response from Europe or the international community when people come to see the skeletons on the screen," he said, during the recent Africa-Europe summit in Cairo.

There is undoubtedly some truth in what he says. The UN and aid agencies are invariably slow in responding to disaster and crises, whether in Mozambique or Turkey. But the Ethiopian authorities are not entirely blameless.

As Britain's international development secretary, Clare Short, pointed out today: "The failure of the last three years' rains is the root cause of Ethiopia's current crisis, but there is little doubt that the continuing conflict with Eritrea is hampering the response to the relief effort and valuable resources are being diverted to perpetuating the conflict."

So while there is the predictable hand-wringing in the west, Ethiopia and Eritrea also need to focus on putting an end to what they themselves admit is a "crazy" war. The conflict between these two neighbours and former allies is not only an obscene waste of resources in two of the world's poorest countries, it is also hampering relief efforts.

The conflict between Eritrea and the land-locked Ethiopia has forced the closure of the Eritrean port of Massawa, leaving Djibouti - the only other big port in the region - to handle food distribution, which is not large enough to cope with the amounts needed.

"If we had peace and normal relations between Ethiopia and Eritrea, then the harbour of Massawa would also be available and the problem more manageable," said Poul Nielson, the EU commissioner for development. As it is, a large proportion of food will probably have to be air dropped, considerably increasing costs.

The famine does not seem to have engendered any spirit of co-operation between Ethiopia - which lost 1m people to famine 15 years ago - and Eritrea. Last week, Ethiopia's government rejected a reported offer from Eritrea to let aid agencies use Eritrean ports for emergency aid to its neighbour. A government statement called the offer "absurd," saying Eritrea had confiscated a previous donor shipment to feed its army.

In the past, the two countries were allies. Eritreans had helped Ethiopia overthrow Haile Mariam Mengistu's dictatorial Dergue regime and, in turn, won their long fight for independence in 1993. The long and mostly desolate 620-mile border between the two countries had never been properly delineated but that did not seem to matter until May 1998, when fighting broke out in the Badme area.

Ethiopia, which administered the area, said the Eritreans had invaded and demanded their withdrawal. Eritrea admitted it had entered the area but said it was only claiming back its own territory. This pattern was repeated in several other border areas. Days later, the countries rained bombs on each other. The two former allies are now bogged down in a conflict that has already cost thousands of lives and threatens to cost many more through the delay of supplies.

fields.headline: Cybershopping:  lingerie
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: E-commerce could almost have been invented just so that men would never have to browse nervously around lingerie departments. www.poshknickers.com (nothing to do with Victoria Beckham or her husband) is a site for independent retailers. Designed for "guys" buying gifts for girlfriends, the site oozes style and offers plenty of advice for the novice, such as borrowing items of underwear to check for sizes. Bras and briefs are matched together in sets that often work out cheaper than the combined price of the individual items.
fields.body:
E-commerce could almost have been invented just so that men would never have to browse nervously around lingerie departments. www.poshknickers.com (nothing to do with Victoria Beckham or her husband) is a site for independent retailers. Designed for "guys" buying gifts for girlfriends, the site oozes style and offers plenty of advice for the novice, such as borrowing items of underwear to check for sizes. Bras and briefs are matched together in sets that often work out cheaper than the combined price of the individual items.

www.easyshop.co.uk is undergoing a revamp to make it a sexier shopping experience. Nasty orange backgrounds are out, while clearer imaging and Dolce & Gabbana are in. There are more than 60 brands represented on the site, from Wonderbra to Beau Bra and Kenzo. If you know precisely the bra you want, but don't fancy spending the weekend trying to find it, it's ideal.

Rigby & Peller, anxious not to compromise its reputation for quality of fit - staff claim they can judge a customer's bra size simply by looking at her - has so far restricted sales at www.rigbyandpeller.com to repeat orders, nightwear and gift vouchers. But now that the label is being sold elsewhere on the net, it has changed its tune and plans to start selling online in the next few months.

fields.headline: The DIY send-off
fields.standfirst: As the price of the average burial tops £2,000, more people are arranging their own cut-price funerals.  Anna Tims explores the options, from woodland ceremonies to home-made coffins
fields.trailText: As the price of the average burial tops £2,000, more people are arranging their own cut-price funerals. Anna Tims explores the options, from woodland ceremonies to home-made coffins
fields.body:
The cost of burials in Britain has risen by 25% in the past two years, according to a survey published this week by the Oddfellows friendly society. That means the average cost is now £2,048. In London's Kentish Town (the most expensive place to die in Britain, the survey found) a decent send-off will set you back £3,928. Cremations, which are favoured by 80% of Britons, cost an average of £1,215.

These daunting figures partly reflect increased charges levied by local authorities for burial plots and partly European anti-pollution regulations, which cost crematoria around £500,000 each. A sizeable, chunk, however, goes into the pockets of unregulated funeral directors - around £585 for the most basic, no-frills service.

The conglomerates, which control a large swathe of the country's funeral parlours, are likely to charge a good deal more. An independent survey conducted for the Society of Allied and Independent Funeral Directors (SAIF) 18 months ago, found that while the average fee for an independent director is £791, the US company SCI, which, in the past three years has bought up 18% of funeral parlours in Britain and 21% of crematoria, charges around £1,031.

For many, unable to cope with red-tape after a bereavement, it is money well spent. However, more people are choosing to make the arrangements themselves, and finding that the experience not only saves them money but helps them come to terms with their loss.

"In the west we have sanitised funerals too much," says John Weir of SAIF, which encourages its 15,000 members to offer free advice on DIY funerals. "You go into the funeral parlour, issue your instructions and the next time you see them is at the crematorium."

According to R Aubrey Miles & Sons, a family-run funeral parlour in Wokingham, DIY funerals are easier to organise than the average family holiday and the number of people choosing to go it alone has more than trebled in the past five years. "Funerals have become big business - very slick, smooth and impersonal," says owner Adam Miles, who offers free advice and mail-order coffins to non-clients. "But people don't want to be spectators any more."

When her father died two years ago, Jill Harcourt-Ray of Carmarthenshire decided to see to the funeral herself after being put off by the atmosphere of the funeral parlour. "The Natural Death Centre sent me literature on coffins and we used my daughter's people carrier to transport the body to the crematorium," she says.

Paul Harris, funeral director and author of the new Which? Guide to What to Do When Someone Dies, estimates that burials and cremations take 30 to 40 hours to organise and the process is usually straightforward. Next week the Natural Death Centre, a charity set up to help the bereaved, publishes The New Natural Death Handbook, which explains how to arrange an alternative funeral, down to how to construct a coffin.

Most funeral directors will now allow families to hire a hearse (usually around £100), mortuary space or other vitals without paying for the entire service. Many will also provide the necessary paperwork for a small fee - SCI charges £25 - and most small independent firms are happy to sell coffins, although prices are likely to be higher than those bought direct from a supplier.

The first concern for those who want to go their own way is how to store the body. If the deceased died in hospital, the hospital will probably consent to keep them in the on-site mortuary free of charge for a few days. Otherwise, it is a good idea to pay for a place in a funeral parlour mortuary or to get the corpse embalmed.

If the person died at home, a doctor must have visited them within two weeks, otherwise the death is referred to a coroner. The doctor will then issue a death certificate free of charge if a burial is planned. If the body is to be cremated, two certificates from two different doctors must be obtained for a total charge of £82. The certificates must then be taken to the local register office within five days of the death. The registrar will then issue a burial certificate (this will come from the coroner if an inquest has taken place), which must be given to the cemetery or crematorium 24 hours in advance. If the burial is on private land, the certificate should be handed to the landowner or manager. The tear-off slip at the bottom must be filled out and returned to the registrar within 96 hours of the burial.

Local authorities run most of the country's crematoria and cemeteries and will provide an application form, to be returned with the appropriate fee and, if a church service is required, a minister must be contacted and a date and time agreed. Planning permission is not strictly necessary if the body is to be buried on private land, although it's wise to check with the Environment Agency in case the water table is likely to be affected. An alternative is using one of the many woodland burial sites and nature reserves detailed in the Natural Death Handbook. Usually a tree is planted over the grave and the site left as a natural wilderness, although some allow plaques and monuments.

Many woodland sites will accept bodies wrapped only in a shroud or borne on a burial stretcher, something cemeteries and crematoria are still squeamish about; those who prefer a coffin should be able to buy one for as little as £45 by mail order (suppliers are listed in the Natural Death Handbook) and there are now seven different types of eco-friendly cardboard coffins available direct from wholesalers from £53 upwards, including delivery.

Unfortunately, most newly bereaved relatives are too traumatised to think of shopping around for a funeral. According to a survey by the Office of Fair Trading, 97% of people sign-up to the first funeral director they come too. But attitudes are changing and the advent of internet funeral products is likely to encourage more to take the plunge. "Don't take death lying down," urges Funerals to Die For, a website offering moral support to DIY organisers. "Always stand up for your rites."

The New Natural Death Handbook is available at £12.99 inc. p&P from The Natural Death Centre, 0181-208 2853, www. naturaldeath. org.uk

fields.headline: How much can you pay for . . .
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: . . . A mobile phone holder
fields.body:
. . . A mobile phone holder

Hands up, this is a robbery. Yes, Chanel is killing deux oiseaux with one bullet: its mobile phone holder looks like an upmarket gun holster, and sets customers back by the princely sum of £385.

It's odd to think that the Chanel label was once regarded as absolute, understated elegance. Only older women could really carry off the Chanel suit, with its plain lines and huge price: Coco Chanel herself was the chicest of them all, and had to teach her models how to walk, a special kind of slinking along that involved leading with your pelvis for that "too cool to stand up straight" look. It's impossible to imagine what she would make of her fashion house's output now. Karl Lagerfeld, her successor, clearly feels that the gangsta chic look is so in that they should give up that boring old tasteful business, and go for LA gun-mob chic. Mmm, red leather with a patent finish: welcome to the 21st century. Or is it the 80s all over again? You can reach Chanel on 0171-235 6631.

webTitle: Is it art: shock tactics of the Sensation generation

fields.headline: Is it art: shock tactics of the Sensation generation
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive online essay taken from the current edition of the London Review of Books, Marina Warner considers the tradition of the grotesque in Britart and its forebears
fields.trailText: Marina Warner on Britart and the grotesque
fields.body:
High Art Lite: British Art in the 1990s
by Julian Stallabrass
Verso, 342 pp., £22, 8 December 1999, 1 85984 721 8

This Is Modern Art
by Matthew Collings
Weidenfeld, 270 pp., £20, 24 June 1999, 0 297 84292 7
Buy it at BOL

The heavy in shirtsleeves on the door of the disused Strand tube station was working the phone to a reluctant client who had rented the premises for a rave that didn't happen and now didn't want to pay. The man's job title was something like Manager of Decommissioned Underground Material and I had gone to see him with Michael Morris, one of the directors of Artangel, a company that puts on art events in different media in unusual places. He was trying to get permission to use the tunnels and platforms for The Vertical Line, a performance piece devised by John Berger.

In Ways of Seeing, Berger presented on television for the first time an ideological analysis of art and aesthetics. One of the programmes juxtaposed pin-ups and centrefolds with Titians, in a powerful early assault on advertising. Thirty years later, Berger was still in compelling voice, a burly, gravelly oracle prowling in the dromos of the underground tunnels, as he took us down with him on an archaeological excavation of art, past the encaustic portraits on the mummies of Fayum, deeper down to the cave paintings of Chauvet. Art figured as a magical enactment: "Smell the bear!" he commanded as he evoked in the darkness a prehistoric drawing. Then, describing the vitality of art made thousands of years ago, he marvelled: "In the beginning there was no fumbling."

Julian Stallabrass, in his Verrine blast against Britart, combines the early Berger's fierce critique of consumerist contamination with the later Berger's sense of art's high purpose: "It is often said of high art lite that it has a dark view of things," he writes, "and it does; the true depth of its cynicism, though, is not be found in its representation of suicides, or torture victims, or abused children, or in its multitude of corpses, but instead in all that it turns its back on, all that it leaves out when it comes to what art can be." As it pans the miasmic waters where the Chapman Brothers, Gavin Turk, Tracey Emin and of course Damien Hirst loom, High Art Lite finds the ark of art occupied, betrayed and shipwrecked. The principles that gave the avant-garde of the earlier part of the 20th century its energy and optimism have rebounded on themselves and collapsed: the use of popular material as an anti-élitist, anti-bourgeois strategy; the flouting of proprieties; the wilfully bad execution and recourse to deskilled methods; the spurning of the West End for Shoreditch and Hoxton - all the 'alternative' themes and media and sites and forms of attention have been emulsified into a phenomenon on which Tony Blair smiles.

Stallabrass follows the tracks of this social monster, which can be identified by what seems to be an infinitely elastic, numbing permissiveness, from mannikins of children with penises for noses and vulvae for mouths to used sanitary towels cast from an unmade bed. Stallabrass excoriates the artists' nihilism, cynicism and tourist populism: he describes the ubiquity of urban decay, social ruination and personal degradation in their imagery as 'urban pastoralism', a late millennial equivalent of the rococo's pleasure in swains and Bo-peeps frolicking in hayricks. "A pervasive and disabling irony becalms the work," he writes, "in a manner that is supposed, in conventional wisdom, to challenge the viewer but which in fact conveniently opens up demotic material to safe aesthetic delectation." How indeed should one enjoy, in Aristotle's phrase, "the figures of the most despicable animals, or of human corpses"?

Catharsis is no longer the aim, but can it still be an effect of Mat Collishaw's magnified bullet wound, or Hirst's cloven-hoofed beasts? Stallabrass emphatically refuses this ancient validation, believing that the way Britart is presented - the Royal Academy the venue, Saatchi the patron - fatally puffs it into empty bubbles (the unbearable liteness of the book's title). Britart is part of "a wider failure of a culture of opposition": the artists' deliberate assault on good taste, political correctness, and Enlightenment models of aesthetic value and social progress is just a matter of style, a form of quickfix entertainment which, as Gavin Turk warns, isn't even "particularly entertaining". Stallabrass concedes defeat, too: there is no place for the critic to triangulate the deadly shot that will burst this ballooning monster. "For theory," he writes despairingly, "the combination of a false but ineluctable authenticity from which the art is supposed to issue and the neutral, non-judgmental position that it adopts, is lethal." Interestingly, Stallabrass has found points of sensitivity and even resistance in the bodies of his victims: the space where a plate of Steve McQueen's Bear should have appeared remains blank, with the supertitle, 'Permission to reproduce denied'. This happens in Richard Billingham's case as well, although his pictures of his family escape Stallabrass's everlasting fire.

Concurrently with last year's Turner Prize show at the Tate, Ana Maria Pacheco, a Brazilian artist long resident in this country, showed the works resulting from her year's residency at the National Gallery. Dark Night of the Soul is a monumental piece, consisting of 19 massive figures carved out of wood and arranged like a Latin American Stations of the Cross around the glaringly spotlit figure of a naked man bound and hooded for execution. The statues are larger than life-size, with eerie, enlarged, polished onyx eyes and small teeth (real ones). You could walk among the statues, become part of the scene, one of the witnesses, one of the voyeurs, and share in the figures' perplexity and awe. Pacheco also showed richly coloured, buffed and waxed oil paintings on mythical themes: the temptation of St Anthony as a modern apocalypse, the tryst of Solomon and Sheba as a battle of wits from a spirited fairy tale. The show was popular, and the crowds were hushed. Brian Sewell praised it, against his first instincts, he admitted.

Stallabrass doesn't mention Pacheco, or indeed many other artists who aren't in the Tate inner circle, even by way of contrast to his lite targets, and although Dark Night of the Soul engages directly with contemporary issues, delivers a powerful sense of tragic humanity, and, above all, avoids irony, my sense is that Stallabrass still wouldn't find it in himself to praise it. He's very tough on Mark Wallinger, for example. Discussing Capital, Wallinger's 1990 corporate portrait sequence of homeless people, Stallabrass decides that "despite his laudable intentions, there is something knowing and cold, almost mocking about these works." Permission to reproduce was denied in this case as well. He doesn't mention Wallinger's tiny, frail, pallid figure of Ecce Homo, which was put up on the empty fourth plinth in Trafalgar Square.

Can any art made today fulfil what used to be accepted as its chief aims: to illuminate the human predicament, to reveal truths, to illustrate in a heightened manner contemporary existence, to question the status quo, to shed lacrimae rerum? If any art can do this, will it still be able to take its place in the ever-growing octopoid world of venues, private views and PRs? Stallabrass isn't asking that Britart do anything unprecedented. He wants to keep all the right enemies (and not find himself finessed so that he's lined up with Sewell - or the late Peter Fuller) and stay out on the left flank; his fury is rather Victorian - Ruskin's rage against the immoralism of the Baroque.

Oddly enough, Matthew Collings - in the book of his Channel Four series - says many of the same things as Stallabrass; he even borrows the term 'art lite'. But most of the time he seems to like the art and the artists, for the same reasons that Stallabrass detests them. He feels easy with numbness and dumbness and "shock, horror"; he doesn't vituperate against vacuousness and lack of affect; he likes being made to feel "glidey" and "nice"; he's funny about the artists' self-mythologising and bad behaviour, and irony for him is natural. The presiding angel would appear to be Gertrude Stein, in Alice B. Toklas mode, faux-naive and paratactic, artless and kooky, the godmother of Adrian Mole. But his favourite art critic, as he admits in It Hurts, his book about the New York art scene, is Clement Greenberg, and he can suddenly throw out a shrewd, decisive insight in the master's best manner. His claims on art's behalf are modest and canny; "windiness" is a favourite term of condemnation. The Chapman Brothers's gruesome 3-D reworking of Goya's Disasters of War prompts the comment: "Everything odd and inexplicable about Goya rushes to the foreground. And everything that was a timeless humane truth about the horror of atrocity seeps away."

The book bears the marks of its origin as a TV series: potted biographies of the founding heroes (Jackson Pollock and Picasso) interpolated here and there, scenic shoots in studios far and wide, and a haphazard structure. It does well, though, to place the Sensation lot in a family tree, with Goya, Munch, Picasso, America, Modernism and Matisse. Collings has a vigorous curiosity about aesthetic value and in an interesting chapter called 'Lovely, Lovely' tries to get to grips with the question of beauty: "We know no artists will ever be nominated for the Turner Prize for their contribution to loveliness," he writes. "But the loveliness we find in a lot of art . . . seems to be a property or quality that can never be wholly got rid of. However much we may stop mentioning it and try and shame it into leaving, it just keeps on hanging around."

Chris Ofili, who won the Turner Prize in 1998, is included in this chapter with his sequinned, beaded, dotted, varnished, lustrous, rainbow-coloured paeans in paint to numinous beings - Captain Shit and the Virgin Mary and various other Ebony or Hello! heroes and heroines. The difference between Stallabrass's approach and Collings's couldn't be plainer: in High Art Lite Ofili gets three colour pics and a thorough discussion of the arguments used to defend/praise him, concluding with a resonant dismissal of his work ("Indeed, it is utterly of a piece with high art lite in its refusal to do anything other than present a dilemma"). In This Is Modern Art, Ofili is treated to three colour pics and a four-page discussion marked by the ropey syntax and meandering musings that Stallabrass finds so infuriating about the Britart running dogs: "Is it identity politics that drives him?" Collings asks: "It would be exhausting now to remember what they are and write it all down." For Stallabrass, Ofili has failed the cause of Stephen Lawrence because he feeds the "largely white and certainly largely privileged gallery-going audience with standard prejudices about blacks, delivered in a manner that is so over-the-top as to be absurd". These ironies were exultantly lost on the schoolkids I saw in the Ofili room at the Turner Prize show at the Tate, who identified for me every one of the tiny black faces in the stars spangling the background of one of the Captain Shit and the All Stars pictures. For Collings, acting the idiot aesthete again, "the look of Ofili's paintings is always beautiful."

What can art do now? and What should art do now? are distinct questions, but they both go to the heart of the problem facing the visual arts in the age of global iconomania, in the multimedia blizzard of signs and non-signs. In New York, Mayor Giuliani snatched at an opportunity for crowd-pleasing when he denounced Ofili's The Holy Mother Mary, but the episode showed that scandal can still erupt around the images lambasted by Stallabrass as meaninglessly, lethally equivocal.

Collings ends with a promise that art still holds out "hope, marvels, beauty, a route to transcendent meanings, a few laughs". Stallabrass, too, if scathingly, proposes laughter as a possible response to contemporary art, and the productions of Emin and Hirst, like horror film gore and monster comics, often elicit a grim, gallows humour - shrinking, wincing, giggling and smirking. It's a new twist in the long tradition of the grotesque and Collings is right to draw attention to the pleasure-in-pain, in which relish and disgust are coiled together, stirred by Goya's fantastic nightmares: "We feel there ought to be a dividing line somewhere - between art and sadism. Someone should tell us what it is. Did Goya have a dividing line in his head? Were there any boundary lines in there at all?"

The tendency to monstrous imagery wavers; it doesn't keep up a constant pressure - unlike, perhaps, the desire for beauty. It would appear to be at high tide today, however, sucking into its undertow an interest in detritus, effluvia, leavings - industrial, military and carnal - as well as a delight in childishness (polymorphous perversity): these characteristics can be swept up into the larger family of deformations, malformations and formlessness. In his original and fascinating overview of aesthetic change in The World of Sculpture (Pimlico, 435 pp., £15, 6 April, 0 7126 6442 4) James Hall attributes the shift to messy, ramshackle mixed media constructions and the taste for haptic variety to the influence of Maria Montessori and her belief that touch is the primary cognitive sense. The sandpit, mud, lollipop sticks, goo, plasticine, oozing clay and, later, petri dishes and test tubes: playing with such stuff, Hall argues, has clearly influenced the materialisations of contemporary art, so much of it three-dimensional, inherently transient and labile, and playful. Homo ludens has supplanted homo faber.

Giving basic epistemological processes visibility and status corresponds to the old, paradoxical role of jesting - both these critics represent their subjects as jesters or fools - which was to speak the unspeakable, but with an accompanying impulse towards self-protection. These images may be apotropaic, like grinning death's heads at the entrances to cities, Medusa heads on temple porticos, snarling griffons on tombs, shelah-na-gigs on castle walls - they are ferocious, grisly, barbarously comic effigies erected to ward off worse terrors. The quips of Shakespeare's fools aren't very funny: they're often rude and nasty, at once riddling and in your face - rough charms uttered to banish care, to lift dullness, whistling in the dark. The fooling function of art doesn't help us to evaluate its aesthetic quality, but Stallabrass's jeremiad reveals that art's politics have to do not with the work, but with the way it is received. (He might like some of these artists more if Saatchi liked them less.) Meanwhile, Collings, with almost spacey, dopey voluptuousness, takes pleasure in not offering a verdict grounded in an aesthetic system of values.

fields.headline: BNFL admits safety breach
fields.standfirst: Acid leak at Sellafield left three men injured, court told
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels today admitted breaching safety regulations after three of its workers were injured in an acid leak at its Sellafield reprocessing plant.

The men suffered burns when seven cubic metres of highly-corrosive concentrated nitric acid escaped from a valve in March last year. Engineer Ray Hodge, fitter Andy Karnall and a site fireman received treatment after the leak.

British Nuclear Fuels plc and BNFL Engineering Limited pleaded guilty at Whitehaven Magistrates' Court, Cumbria, to failing to ensure the safety of workers during commissioning and maintenance work.

Magistrates were told that nitric acid sprayed on to Mr Karnall was at a pressure five times that of a car tyre. The leak happened because of a systems failure, John Batty, prosecuting for the health and safety executive, said.

"Both BNFL plc and BNFL Engineering Limited had allowed a culture to grow whereby systems proving unworkable were not being adhered to and alternative systems were put in place by on-the-ground workers," Mr Batty told the court.

The HSE had highlighted problems in systems management and audit management as early as 1991 but they had not been rectified, the court heard. In the solvent treatment plant, where the accident occurred, workers had been forced to set up their own system of isolating damaged valves because existing procedures were too complicated. The management was not aware of these practices.

Regular staff knew of one valve in the plant which looked as though it was closed when it was not. However, when work was required to carry out repairs on another valve, a stand-in permit engineer, Ray Hodge, oversaw the replacement, because the regular worker was on holiday. The first valve was closed to isolate the faulty valve and Mr Karnall carried on with the repair. However, nitric acid was still being pumped through the pipe and, when the valve was opened, it sprayed over the fitter, Mr Batty said.

"Thankfully, although it was not a requirement of him, Mr Karnall was wearing an acid suit and eye protection, and the permit engineer was standing behind a Perspex screen," he said.

The two men escaped from the area but had to "forcibly break down a locked door to gain entry to an adjoining building because they were, in effect, trapped."

A total of £750,000 worth of damage was caused to the building, which had to be evacuated. The fumes from the acid leak, which amounted to the equivalent of 120 car fuel tanks, triggered the fire alarm system and the on-site crew went to the area without protective clothing, believing a fire had broken out. One crew member suffered the effects of fume inhalation.

Bench chairwoman Marina Walker said that because of the serious nature of the incident she had no option but to commit the case to crown court where a higher fine could be given.

She said: "The prosecution has highlighted serious failures in management systems, auditing control and safety monitoring and these failings have continued over a number of years. Although thankfully the consequences of this incident were not particularly serious, potentially the consequences could have been very serious indeed."

Speaking outside the court, a spokesman for the company said: "Safety is our first priority and we regret that such an event occurred. However no one was seriously injured, and the emergency response and the safety systems we had in place prevented any acid escaping to the environment. We have already acted to ensure that similar events cannot happen in the future.

"The company has already complied with all the requirements of three improvement/enforcement notices issued by the regulators shortly after the spill. In addition the company has also acted on the other recommendations identified by a formal enquiry into the event," he added.

The case was one of a number investigated by the HSE and formed part of a report by the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate published in February. This report also showed workers had falsified quality control documents and led to Switzerland, Germany and Japan halting shipments of fuel from Sellafield.

The case is another blow to the beleaguered nuclear giant following a series of safety scares over the past three months.

fields.headline: Strings attached to Ashcroft peerage
fields.trailText: April 6 2000: The controversial Conservative party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, has at last been awarded a peerage - but only if he returns from tax exile to live permanently in Britain by the end of this year.
fields.body:
The controversial Conservative party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, has at last been awarded a peerage - but only if he returns from tax exile to live permanently in Britain by the end of this year.

The Florida-based billionaire, who has donated £1m a year to the Tories since 1997, is the most eyecatching name on the list of 33 working peers announced last week. The public honours scrutiny committee (PHSC) vetoed his nomination by the Tory leader, William Hague, last year. This time, in imposing unprecedented conditions on his peerage, the committee insisted that a foreign-domiciled tycoon could hardly be a working peer.

The committee - Lord Hurd (Tory), Lady Dean (Labour), and its chairman, Lord Thomson (Lib Dem) - demanded Mr Ashcroft's "clear and unequivocal assurance" that he will come home to live and pay his taxes. "That really is quite unprecedented," said one insider.

Labour and the Liberal Democrats denounced Mr Ashcroft as a "conditional peer" for whom the rules had been bent because of his political donations. Senior Tories such as Sir Edward Heath condemned the peerage as "a disgrace". Lord Cranborne, the former Tory leader in the Lords, described it as "an affront to the dignity and standing" of Parliament.

Mr Ashcroft's influence on a previous government in Belize, including his role in drafting its offshore banking rules and as its United Nations ambassador, triggered last year's uproar about his suitability to be the Tory party's treasurer. It led to a libel suit against the Times for hinting at his involvement in laundering drug money. The suggestion was withdrawn when both sides backed down.

It was only when the PHSC threatened to block his nomination again last month that he promised to return to live in the UK by Christmas and to resign his UN post, which he has now done.

Mr Ashcroft said he was "thrilled and honoured" to be able to make a contribution to the Lords "as a businessman, a campaigner against drugs and as a political party fundraiser".

He said he would become "a voice for Belize" and would take the title Baron Ashcroft of Belize, which critics took as a snub to the PHSC for the strings attached to his peerage. He later backed down on the proposal, which Mr Hague described as "a little joke".

An Ashcroft spokesman said: "It was slightly-tongue-in-cheek kite-flying." But Mr Ashcroft, who made a one-day visit to the Tory spring conference in Harrogate, said he still held dual nationality. "Belize runs through my bones," he said. His spokesman added: "He wants to be an authentic voice on the debate on agricultural production and third world debt . . . an informal voice."

Twenty of the new peers are Labour, including the economist Richard Layard, the publisher Matthew Evans of Faber & Faber, the academic and race relations expert Professor Bhikhu Parekh, and five former hereditary peers.

With the Conservatives confined to four newcomers, including the Olympic gold medal-winning runner Sebastian Coe, and the Liberal Democrats to nine, Labour now has more life peers than the Tories in the half-reformed Lords, 198 to 184. The new influx leaves the upper house with 202 Labour peers, 236 Tories, 63 Lib- Dems and 161 cross-benchers, plus 26 archbishops and bishops.

fields.headline: When the generals reign supreme
fields.standfirst: A Pakistani special court has sentenced former prime minister Nawaz Sharif to life imprisonment for hijacking and terrorism. The shock sentence has reinforced fears that the army general who ousted Sharif in October last year intends to cling on to power indefinitely, says former south Asia correspondent Derek Brown
fields.trailText: A Pakistani special court has sentenced former prime minister Nawaz Sharif to life imprisonment for hijacking and terrorism. The shock sentence has reinforced fears that the army general who ousted Sharif in October last year intends to cling on to power indefinitely, says former south Asia correspondent Derek Brown
fields.body:
Nawaz Sharif has paid a heavy price for committing the cardinal sin of Pakistani politics: he tried to challenge the awesome power of the military.

Whether in power or lurking on the margins of it, successive army bosses have demanded the right to guide the nation's destiny. Some, like Ayub Khan in the 60s, have been outright dictators. Others, like Zia ul-Haq in the 80s, cloaked their authoritarianism under a veneer of constitutional propriety. In between, and since, there have been army chiefs who preferred to pull the strings of political puppets, without appearing on stage.

Nawaz Sharif was a Zia protege, who rose to provincial power in Punjab as a competent, albeit corrupt, administrator. When the dictator was assassinated in 1988 - the plane crash in which he died has never been fully explained - Sharif was swept aside in the wave of popular support for Benazir Bhutto, daughter of the prime minister martyred by Zia in the late 70s.

Bhutto, a striking young woman saying all the correct democratic things, dazzled the world, but duped her own country. After a couple of years of corruption, she was ditched by the shadowy coalition of interests represented by Sharif's Muslim League and the military establishment.

In 1993, it was Sharif's turn to feel the hot breath of the army on his neck, as he was manoeuvred from the seat of power. The Bhutto dynasty was back, and once again they blew it. Asif Ali Zardari, Benazir's husband, amassed a vast financial empire, but could not defend it against the rising wrath of jealous rivals. In 1997, Bhutto was again dismissed, to be paraded with her husband through the mockery of a deeply flawed judicial system.

Back in the prime minister's chair, Sharif set about tinkering with the constitution and legal code. He wanted to tighten the law on terrorism and subversion in his unruly land, setting up an system of arbitrary special courts - the very system which has now brought him low.

The rumbles of serious military discontent began last summer when the prime minister, alarmed by the escalating conflict with India in the high mountains of divided Kashmir, ordered his army chiefs to pull back. To compound the insult, he tried to divide and rule the cantonments, by appointing his own placeman to head the immensely powerful and semi-autonomous ISI military intelligence organisation.

By last September, the chiefs of staff were visibly seething with discontent, holding highly publicised meetings to discuss "national defence issues". Washington took the rare step of publicly warning the generals against a coup. Perhaps emboldened by US support, Sharif launched what he fondly hoped would be a pre-emptive strike In October, when army chief Pervez Musharraf visited Sri Lanka, the prime minister dismissed his top soldier and forbade his return to Pakistan.

But the general was already in the air over Karachi, and his aircraft was running out of fuel. Dismayed military chiefs overruled the prime minister, and ordered air traffic control to led Musharrif's plane land. From the moment his feet touched the ground, Sharif was doomed. That night, he was under house arrest.

Now, he is facing an indeterminate jail sentence, which prosecutors suggest will be 25 years. He was found guilty, absurdly, of hijacking and terrorism, but acquitted on the slightly more plausible charge of attempted murder.

There can be few Pakistanis today who believe that Sharif, who is 51, will really stay in prison for the rest of his days. He is not the most impressive of politicians, being furtive in demeanour and dull of speech. But he is the most wily and astute of Pakistan's occasional civilian rulers, and he still has a formidable power base in Punjab.

That the court acquitted all his six co-defendants, and declined to pass the death sentence demanded by the prosecution, is a signal that not even the judicial system is wholly in the pocket of the generals. But for the moment it is they, and not the judges or the politicians or the voters, who rule supreme.

webTitle: Law review shifts rape burden of proof to accused

fields.headline: Law review shifts rape burden of proof to accused
fields.trailText: Men contesting rape charges will have to convince a jury that their accusers gave free and unqualified consent, under radical proposals from a review of the law on sex offences set up by the Home Office.
fields.body:
Men contesting rape charges will have to convince a jury that their accusers gave free and unqualified consent, under radical proposals from a review of the law on sex offences set up by the Home Office.

The reform would strengthen the hands of rape complainants by forcing a defendant to show not only that his accuser consented to sex, but did so freely. It would shift the balance in rape trials in the accuser's favour and could substantially improve the low success rate in rape prosecutions.

The proposal is part of a blueprint for the most wide-ranging overhaul yet of the law on sex offences in England and Wales. It would also widen the definition of rape to include forced oral sex, and give greater protection for children and vulnerable adults by increasing the penalties for offenders who prey on them.

The steering group has rejected calls for a lesser offence of date rape, arguing that rape should retain its status as second only to murder in the criminal calendar.

The report, expected to be published in late May or early June, was handed to Home Office ministers on Tuesday by the sex offences review steering group, which includes officials from the Department of Health, the Department for Education and Employment, the Lord Chancellor's Department, the attorney general's office, the Cabinet Office women's unit and the crown prosecution service. The Bar Council, Law Society, Victim Support, and the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children are also represented.

The Home Office set up the group in 1998 to review all the existing legislation on sex offences and come up with proposals to plug gaps and bring the law up to date. The main statute, the Sexual Offences Act, was passed in 1956 and received only three minutes' debate in the House of Commons.

The government will consult on the proposals until the end of the year.

webTitle: City mourns as beautiful game turns ugly

fields.headline: City mourns as beautiful game turns ugly
fields.standfirst: Pride in Leeds' young team has given way to grief, says Guardian northern editor Martin Wainwright
fields.trailText: Pride in Leeds' young team has given way to grief, says Guardian northern editor Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
A statue and a pub are the focus of grief in Leeds today, appropriate symbols of the bond between the city and its team. This has two sides, one powerfully invigorating and the other a throwback to old, bad times. The murders in Istanbul wretchedly put the second side centre stage.

Drink, violence and Leeds were already in the public mind because of the huge publicity given to an alleged racist attack in the city which has seen United players charged. The case has yet to be heard, just as exactly what happened round Taksim Square has still to be unravelled. But the miserable associations have been made.

That sense explains the frustration detectable alongside Leeds' natural anger and grief; frustration that the bonhomie and civic pride represented by a pub like The Bay Horse in Farsley are shoved aside by hatred and the perversion of sporting ideals. The Bay Horse was where one of the Istanbul victims, Ken Speight, was landlord and he made it a shrine to his team; a shrine hugely supplemented now by flowers and scarves.

He was just a great guy, all the neighbours and regulars said, stopping by in the sunshine in an uninterrupted flow to support Ken's widow Susan and her fatherless three-year-old daughter and eight-year-old son. But like all pub landlords, he would have been aware of the destructive power of alcohol and the way that pictures of Leeds teams and all the yellow-and-blue paraphernalia could become a weapon and a taunt.

Just along the ring road at Leeds' Elland Road stadium, the grinning statue of United's former captain Billy Bremner is also awash with flowers, plus a black mourning band looped over one of his chunky arms. Here the pathos is even stronger than at Farsley, for the statue (heir to all those bronze sculptures of aldermen and worthies from Victorian days) represents all that football could do for the city.

O'Leary's 'babes' showed enough promise to emulate the haul of gleaming trophies and the extraordinary mixture of fame and self-confidence of Manchester United, the old rival across the Pennines. These prizes seemed so reachable this season for everyone in Leeds - including those like myself who never got beyond a lonely life as an Under-16 'B' league full-back.

It is not too late. There is still the hope of glory and, just as important, of showing the discipline and decency which Sir Alex Ferguson commands from his team's fans. Tonight's game against Galatasary and next week's second leg at Elland Road could be the best memorial for Ken Speight and his fellow-victim Chris Loftus. There's a powerful feeling in Leeds of everyone willing that to be so.

fields.headline: Carl Dreyer: Day of Wrath
fields.trailText:
It is quite common to hear film people, even critics, acknowledge Carl Dreyer's
greatness with the merest hint of a yawn, as if this Danish director of The Passion of
Joan of Arc (1928), Vampyr (1932), Ordet (1955) and Gertrud (1964) was a
film-maker relevant to film history but not to us today. Yet Godard paid tribute to him
in Vivre Sa Vie (1962); and Antonioni, Resnais and other directors who came to
prominence in the 60s freely acknowledge their stylistic and moral debt to him.
fields.body:
It is quite common to hear film people, even critics, acknowledge Carl Dreyer's greatness with the merest hint of a yawn, as if this Danish director of The Passion of Joan of Arc (1928), Vampyr (1932), Ordet (1955) and Gertrud (1964) was a film-maker relevant to film history but not to us today. Yet Godard paid tribute to him in Vivre Sa Vie (1962); and Antonioni, Resnais and other directors who came to prominence in the 60s freely acknowledge their stylistic and moral debt to him.

Nothing could be further from the truth than to characterise him as a close relative to Shakespeare's gloomy Dane and his films as too slow and lingering, too concerned with martyrdom and suffering, and too intent on marketing a gaunt spirituality to reach out to modern audiences. Vampyr, for instance, was one of the most poetic horror films ever made, and Day of Wrath (1943) one of the most terrifying.

The fact is that almost all Dreyer's films, stretching through the silent era into sound, etch themselves in the memory. And if they deal with the kind of subject matter today's film-makers, and some audiences, find largely beyond them, that is surely not to his discredit. He stands among the greatest, most profound, artists of the 20th century.

Day of Wrath is about the persecution of witches in the 17th century and is sometimes seen as an allegory of the German occupation of Denmark. Anne, the second wife of an old pastor, who has given refuge to an alleged witch, discovers that her own mother, also accused of witchcraft, was saved from the stake by the pastor in exchange for her hand. Falling in love with her stepson, she is wracked with guilt and confesses to her husband. When he dies from the shock, Anne is denounced as a witch and burnt at the stake.

The film – in some ways reminiscent of the paintings of Dutch masters – examines the cruelty of the time, which is supposed to be the workings of divine law. One of the two central characters admits under torture that she is a witch; the other volunteers to die, convinced of her own evil. Dreyer's measured pace and stark visuals – long, horizontal pans and close-ups of riven faces – accompanied as they are by acting of intense realism, make this a morality play of enormous power.

The scenes of torture and burning, though discreetly handled, are almost unbearable, at least partly because the torturers and burners are not mere hysterics but convinced they have divine justice on their side.

What Dreyer achieves is the sense that for these sternly Protestant people, whose inscrutable faces conceal great passion, witchcraft was a frightening reality. He does not argue for or against them, but simply, as one critic has said, evokes the dark night of the soul through an intensely physical world. Most directors refine their style towards the end of their lives, and Dreyer did so with Gertrud, which some regard as one of the dozen or so greatest films ever made and others as an impenetrable bore; just as The Passion of Joan of Arc is regarded either as a masterpiece of the silent cinema or redeemed only by the luminous face of Renee Falconetti.

Dreyer was not everybody's director. He was, however, over some 45 years of work, a unique and innovating talent.

fields.headline: BlackStar
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It is what advisers might call a "brave decision," which roughly translated means it appears a damn fool idea or, at the very least, a risky one.
fields.body:
It is what advisers might call a "brave decision," which roughly translated means it appears a damn fool idea or, at the very least, a risky one.

Undeterred by the tumble in internet shares, British online video retailer BlackStar.co.uk unveiled plans yesterday to float on the London stock market.

The company, which sells videos and DVD discs by mail- order on the internet said it planned to raise about £50m in new shares in the flotation and to go to the market in the final quarter of the year.

Co-founder Jeremy Glover said yesterday that he was undaunted by the sharp sell-off in hi-tech shares this week which saw the tech-heavy Nasdaq dipping 13% at one point on Tuesday.

"A lot of readjustment has taken place [in the market] in the last month and it's our view that that's actually good for the market," Mr Glover said. "We have always taken a long-term view of our market."

The theory that the market is undergoing a giant winnowing process, which is sorting the internet wheat from the chaff is only comforting, of course, for firms who are convinced they will be one of the winners.

Yesterday Mr Glover was talking up BlackStar's prospects of becoming a global leader in the $33bn global market for video and DVD sales.

But with BlackStar's market share last year just .0075% of that, there is a long way to go. Mr Glover is forecasting sales this year of £15 to £20m.

In the cut-throat world of e-tail that may be easier to predict than to achieve.

BlackStar is likely to choose an adviser and broker in the next few weeks. Mr Glover's two other co-founders, Tony Bowden and Darryl Collins, also own 16.5% each of the two-year-old firm.

Venture capitalists Atlas and Tarrant own about a third of BlackStar.

Staff options account for 15% of the diluted equity and minority shareholders own the rest.

webTitle: Oasis in search of fertile ground

fields.headline: Oasis in search of fertile ground
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: If the stock market was a desert yesterday, Oasis hoped it would provide some respite. The women's clothing chain announced that after a 15% drop in pre-tax sales for the year to January the first seven weeks of the new year's trading showed like-for-like sales up 5%.
fields.body:
If the stock market was a desert yesterday, Oasis hoped it would provide some respite. The women's clothing chain announced that after a 15% drop in pre-tax sales for the year to January the first seven weeks of the new year's trading showed like-for-like sales up 5%.

"We are pleased to be back on track," finance director Dominic Lavelle said yesterday. The company had a disappointing Christmas, blaming tough competition.

"We had a very encouraging first three quarters of the year and a very challenging fourth quarter where the trends that we saw in the first three quarters did not continue," Mr Lavelle said.

The company reported pre-tax profits of £11.1m for the year to January 29, down from £13m last time.

In the deflationary bloodbath on Britain's high streets, clothing retailers have been particularly hard hit, as the travails of corporations like Marks and Spencer shows. Aiming for fussy female shoppers in the 18-25 range - high on fashion sense but low on cash - is the particularly challenging task facing managing director Derek Lovelock, who joined the company in October.

In January the operation, which operates 146 Oasis stores and 22 upmarket fashion brand Coast stores, issued a warning that profits would be below the lower end of market forecasts, which were then around £12.5m.

The announcement dented the company's already falling share price. Since December, Oasis shares have underperformed the market by 45%.

Mr Lavelle argues that the upturn since the start of the year is sustainable because of the brand's strength, its positioning on the high street and its design content - 80% of the chain's fashions are designed in-house.

But it has still to shake-up its new acquisition, the Coast chain, which recorded a pre-tax loss of £1.4m in its first full year of trading.

"It won't break even this year, but we will see progress from the loss we made last year and we would anticipate it breaking even next year," Mr Lavelle said.

Oasis shares were down 4p at 95p at the close last night after trading resumed late yesterday afternoon..

webTitle: Eleven wickets and one silver box

fields.headline: Eleven wickets and one silver box
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Can you tell me anything about a silver box I bought a while back in Scotland? On the box there are details of a match at Lord's on July 11-12, 1919. Can you tell me what the match was, and who scored 43 runs and took 11 wickets in it? And any ideas on who might have been sitting in Box 10 with the initials EWF? asks Markus Steger
fields.body:
Can you tell me anything about a silver box I bought a while back in Scotland? On the box there are details of a match at Lord's on July 11-12, 1919. Can you tell me what the match was, and who scored 43 runs and took 11 wickets in it? And any ideas on who might have been sitting in Box 10 with the initials EWF? asks Markus Steger

The box refers to the Eton v Harrow schools' match of 1919. The player was Wilfred William (later Sir Wilfred) Hill-Wood, who scored 43 (and 0) and took 4-40 and 7-29 with his legbreaks as Eton won by 202 runs. The match had a controversial start when GO "Gubby" Allen, who later captained England, was run out while backing up in the first over, before he had even faced a ball. The identity of the man in Box 10 is a bit more difficult - books don't often list the spectators as well as the players! - but my money would be on EW Foljambe, who played in the match for Eton in 1908 and 1909. The match was (and still is) a great meeting place for old Etonians and Harrovians, so a lot of former players would have been at Lord's for the game.

Where was Mohinder "Jimmy" Amarnath given out "obstructing the field" in a one-day international? asks R Shantaram

It happened in India's match against Sri Lanka at Ahmedabad, during the Nehru Cup competition in 1989-90. The batsman kicked the ball away from the bowler to avoid being run out. Amarnath also managed another odd dismissal: in the second final of the World Series Cup against Australia at Melbourne in 1985-86 he was given out "handled the ball". Daryll Cullinan of South Africa is the only other batsman to be out this way in one-day internationals.

Can you give the list of overseas players who will be playing county cricket this year? asks Jishnu Biswas

Australians dominate this list: 12 of the 18 counties have plumped for an Aussie this season. They are Michael Di Venuto (Derbyshire), Simon Katich (Durham), Stuart Law (Essex), Matthew Elliott (Glamorgan), Ian Harvey (Gloucestershire), Shane Warne (Hampshire), Justin Langer (Middlesex), Matthew Hayden (Northamptonshire), Jamie Cox (Somerset), Michael Bevan (Sussex), Glenn McGrath (Worcestershire) and Darren Lehmann (Yorkshire). There are three Indians, Rahul Dravid (Kent), Sourav Ganguly (Lancashire) and Anil Kumble (Leicestershire), two Pakistanis, Shoaib Akhtar (Nottinghamshire) and Saqlain Mushtaq (Surrey), and one South African - Allan Donald (Warwickshire). For the first time in many years there won't be any West Indians.

Which West Indian Test cricketer was the first black governor of the BBC? asks Russell Armstrong

It was Lord Constantine who, as Learie Constantine, played 18 Tests for West Indies between 1928 and 1939. After retiring from cricket he became a barrister, and was appointed Trinidad's High Commissioner to London in 1962. He was knighted in 1962, and made a life peer in 1969. He died in 1971.

Was there an English Test cricketer called Basil D'Oliveira? asks Donald Barry Voegt

Indeed there was. Basil Lewis D'Oliveira was born in Cape Town in 1931. He captained South Africa's non-white team in the 1950s but, because he was coloured, he was affected by the odious apartheid policy and was not allowed to play official Test cricket at home. He moved to England to try his luck, and qualified to play for Worcestershire in 1965: in a turn of events that reads more like a fairytale he proved so successful that the following year he played for England, even though he was 35 by then. "Dolly" finished with 2484 runs and 47 wickets in 44 Tests. He made a famous century against Australia at The Oval in 1968. That winter, after initially being omitted from the squad, D'Oliveira was called up to play for England in South Africa, but their government refused to accept him as a tourist and the tour was cancelled. England didn't play South Africa again until 1994. D'Oliveira played on until 1980 for Worcestershire, where he was (and remains) a crowd favourite. And he was my first cricketing hero too, dating roughly from the time at The Oval in 1968 when he ran into the crowd and accidentally spiked one of my tomato sandwiches. He said "Sorry, son," and became the first Test cricketer who ever spoke to me.

For which county did Ted Dexter play? asks Keith Henbrey

"Lord Ted" played for Sussex, from 1957 to 1968. He was the first captain to lift the Gillette Cup, in 1963. He also played 62 Tests for England, 30 of them as captain, and later served as chairman of selectors (1989-93), as well as being the brains behind the PricewaterhouseCoopers Ratings. Dexter was born in Milan, in Italy, and one story has it that Sussex successfully argued that he was qualified to play for them because they are the nearest first-class county to Italy as the crow flies.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

webTitle: Britain expresses concern over Sharif trial

fields.headline: Britain expresses concern over Sharif trial
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has expressed misgivings at the trial of former Pakistani prime minister Nawaz Sharif, who was found guilty of terrorism and hijacking and sentenced to life in prison.
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has expressed misgivings at the trial of former Pakistani prime minister Nawaz Sharif, who was found guilty of terrorism and hijacking and sentenced to life in prison.

Although Mr Sharif was spared death by hanging, Mr Cook said he was disturbed by a number of aspects of the trial.

"These include changing the terms of the trial to include hijacking in the anti-terrorist laws after the alleged event, and the questionable judicial climate, given the forced oaths of allegiances for the senior judiciary," he said.

Mr Sharif was spared the death sentence which the prosecution had demanded for hijacking, a capital offence. The court also cleared him of kidnapping and attempted murder and acquitted his brother Shabaz and five others of all charges against them. Mr Sharif and his co-defendants had denied all charges. Mr Sharif's son Hasan said in London that his father would appeal against the verdict. Mr Cook said the British government would watch the appeal process closely and would reserve its view until the full judicial process had been completed.

"There is no longer any justice in Pakistan. Now my case rests with God," Mr Sharif said after the verdict.

The charges arose after Mr Sharif refused to let a passenger plane carrying General Pervez Musharraf, the army chief, land in Pakistan on October 12. The army seized power that night and installed Gen Musharraf as the country's military leader.

Kulsoom Nawaz, Mr Sharif's wife, and dozens of Sharif supporters yelled angrily inside the court when the verdict was announced, but officials of Mr Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League party have said they will not ask their supporters to take to the streets.

Mr Sharif has the right of appeal against the sentence, which means a jail term of 25 years.

"Obviously we are going to file an appeal within seven days," Haleem Siddiqi, a leading member of Mr Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League, told reporters.

President Bill Clinton appealed for clemency for Mr Sharif during a six-hour visit to Islamabad last month and Gen Musharraf, chief executive of the military-led government, has consistently said he is not a vindictive man.

But Gen Musharraf also said it was up to the court to decide, stressing that the court was independent.

Gen Musharraf claims he is a reluctant army leader and only seized power to prevent the country sliding further into chaos.

At pains to rescue Pakistan from further political isolation after the army coup, he says he has only suspended the constitution and not imposed full martial law.

fields.headline: Freedom of information
fields.standfirst: Home secretary Jack Straw has been trying to get his much criticised bill on freedom of information through parliament in the last few months. Libby Brooks explains why he has been having such a hard time of it
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw has been trying to get his much criticised bill on freedom of information through parliament in the last few months. Libby Brooks explains why he has been having such a hard time of it
fields.body:
Why is freedom of information in the news today?
Last night at least 25 Labour MPs joined forces with the Tories and Lib Dems in an attempt to change a key element of the government's freedom of information bill, as parliament debated on the detailed report stage of Jack Straw's beleaguered piece of legislation. The cross-party rebels wanted to force ministers to allow disclosure of the factual data behind their decisions, even if policy advice from officials was withheld. They were defeated by government loyalists.

So why is the government against the disclosure of that sort of information?
They are worried that officials will be reluctant to offer candid advice if they know that it could be published for all to see. Jack Straw claims that there is a genuine difficulty in disentangling facts from advice. But critics disagree. Tony Benn, for example, has argued that cabinet ministers need the legislation as much as backbenchers because they are similarly kept in the dark by civil servants.

This bill has a history of controversy, doesn't it?
Yes. From the moment the draft bill was published last May, it's been lambasted as a significant retreat from Labour's manifesto commitment to end secrecy. The Guardian's campaign for a less restrictive bill has garnered massive support.

Apart from the issue under debate last night, what are the other main points of weakness in the bill?
The bill sets out plans to create an information commissioner who has the power to order disclosure, within categories of information otherwise covered by a blanket exemption, if they consider it in the public interest. But a crucial veto exists which means that this ruling can be overriden by any minister or local authority which doesn't like it. So the information commissioner is essentially left toothless.

What else?
Critics say there are too many loopholes, which give public bodies excuses for keeping information secret. It all boils down to the traditional British expectation that all official information should be kept secret unless it's deemed - only in exceptional circumstances - to be suitable for disclosure. There has never, for example, been a right of access to government documents. Despite some recent concessions from a panicky Jack Straw, the general thrust of the bill remains the same: ministers want to have final say on what journalists and the public have the right to know.

The United States has a much more open policy on freedom of information. What can we learn from them?
Passed in 1966, the US Freedom of Information Act promotes the disclosure of official information. Because power in Washington is far more dispersed, secrecy is far less sustainable than it is in Westminster. From nuclear power to property ownership, it's possible to find out a wide range of information online - ironically this also means that it's much easier to find out about aspects of contemporary British government in Washington than it is in London.

From the moment the draft bill was published last May, it's been lambasted as a significant retreat from Labour's manifesto commitment to end secrecy. The Guardian's campaign for a less restrictive bill has garnered massive support. Apart from the issue under debate last night, what are the other main points of weakness in the bill? The bill sets out plans to create an information commissioner who has the power to order disclosure, within categories of information otherwise covered by a blanket exemption, if they consider it in the public interest. But a crucial veto exists which means that this ruling can be overriden by any minister or local authority which doesn't like it. So the information commissioner is essentially left toothless. What else? Critics say there are too many loopholes, which give public bodies excuses for keeping information secret. It all boils down to the traditional British expectation that all official information should be kept secret unless it's deemed - only in exceptional circumstances - to be suitable for disclosure. There has never, for example, been a right of access to government documents. Despite some recent concessions from a panicky Jack Straw, the general thrust of the bill remains the same: ministers want to have final say on what journalists and the public have the right to know. The United States has a much more open policy on freedom of information. What can we learn from them? Passed in 1966, the US Freedom of Information Act promotes the disclosure of official information. Because power in Washington is far more dispersed, secrecy is far less sustainable than it is in Westminster. From nuclear power to property ownership, it's possible to find out a wide range of information online - ironically this also means that it's much easier to find out about aspects of contemporary British government in Washington than it is in London. webTitle: Blair pleads for calm as Leeds tie goes ahead

fields.headline: Blair pleads for calm as Leeds tie goes ahead
fields.standfirst: Listen to Daniel Taylor's report from Istanbul
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair has called for calm this evening after football authorities decided to go  ahead with tonight's Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds United and Galatasaray, despite a night of violence in which two Leeds fans were stabbed to death.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair has called for calm this evening after football authorities decided to go ahead with tonight's Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds United and Galatasaray, despite a night of violence in which two Leeds fans were stabbed to death.

"While the facts are being established his thoughts and the thoughts of everybody in government are with the families of the two men who died," said a Downing Street spokesman this afternoon. "We would add our voice to those who appealing for calm ahead of today's game."

Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight were killed and another Leeds fan was left seriously ill in hospital with knife wounds after fighting in Istanbul's Taksim square last night. At least three other Leeds fans were injured in clashes.

The fixture had remained in doubt until this morning, when Leeds United chairman Peter Ridsdale confirmed that an agreement had been reached between both clubs and Uefa. "The Uefa view was that it should go ahead as planned and we accept that," Ridsdale said.

The decision to go ahead with the game has been followed by an escalation of security in Istanbul. Around 13,000 police have already been deployed around Galatasaray's Ali Semi Yen stadium.

Leeds have cancelled all official flights that were to have brought around 200 supporters to Istanbul today. Ridsdale has urged these fans, and those planning to travel to Turkey independently, to remain in Britain.

"In the light of last night's tragic events when two Leeds United supporters were killed in Istanbul, we have decided to cancel all official flights scheduled to travel today," he said in a statement.

"We are also appealing to any supporters who were intending to travel independently not to do so. This advice has been given for everybody's well-being and personal safety.

Leeds supporters claimed that hordes of Turks attacked them after emerging from shops, restaurants and cafes brandishing bottles and glasses.

One Leeds fan in Britain, who spoke to fellow supporters on their mobile phones in Istanbul after the violence, said "absolute mayhem" had broken out.

"There were about 30 Leeds fans in a bar and then it all kicked off somehow. Then they said Turks came out of shops, restaurants and cafes and attacked them," said the supporter, who did not want to be named.

"They said the Turks were carrying bottles, knives, glasses, anything they could get their hands on and just rushed at them."

Fans on both sides were said to have used an array of weapons. The Foreign Office said today that one Briton had been arrested as a result of a separate incident.

The British consul-general in Istanbul, Peter Hunt, said today there had been no warning of the violence to come.

"There was nothing in the days running up to this match to suggest there would be this level of violence," he told BBC Radio Four.

FA spokesman Steve Double said that it was far too early to determine whether last night's violence would damage England's bid to host the World Cup in 2006.

"We are also very conscious of the fact that in recent years the English fan abroad has in many instances, particularly in European club football, been certainly more sinned against than sinning."
