fields.headline: Straw sees off disclosure rebels
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Thirty six Labour MPs last night joined forces with Conservatives and Liberal Democrats in an attempt to force ministers to allow disclosure of the factual basis behind their policy decisions under the government's freedom of information bill.
fields.body:
Thirty six Labour MPs last night joined forces with Conservatives and Liberal Democrats in an attempt to force ministers to allow disclosure of the factual basis behind their policy decisions under the government's freedom of information bill.

Voting was 202 to 311, a government majority of 109, leaving Labour rebels to claim 36 supporters. Earlier predictions that up to 60 Labour members would revolt were eroded by Jack Straw's concessions on Tuesday night.

As the Commons entered a marathon late night session to give detailed report-stage examination to Mr Straw's controversial measure, the home secretary insisted that the government had acted in good faith over the bill - and wider disclosure of information - since 1997.

At stake in the first of last night's tests of strength between loyalists and the cross-party coalition was the rebel ambition to ensure that the factual data behind government decisions is published even if the sensitive policy advice from officials is withheld.

Mr Straw's bill, watered down from the white paper drafted by David Clark - the sacked cabinet office minister - exempts 23 categories of information, ranging from security matters to commercially sensitive ones, from FoI requests.

Last night, Tony Wright, chairman of the Commons public administration committee, who led the revolt, hinted that Downing Street "forces in the land even mightier than the home secretary" were behind the tougher line. Tony Blair is known to share fears, based on US experience of FoI, that officials will not offer candid advice if they know it could shortly be published. Instead they would rely on Post-It stickers which could be attached to policy papers and later removed. But critics in last night's debate derided Mr Straw's claim that there was "genuine difficulty" in disentangling "facts" from advice.

Before pressing his amendments to a vote that would have protected "facts" from ministerial restriction, Dr Wright argued that the bill contradicted the whole thrust of the government's commitment to openness in other areas. These included the publication of the minutes of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee on interest rate decisions - "the sky did not fall in," he said. Ahead of the 1997 election Whitehall mandarins had been prepared to separate their "subjective advice" from factual data, if Labour had asked them to, he said. Openness benefited ministers as well as the public in an "era of scepticism", he said.

The Tory MP John Greenway asked why Labour was tightening John Major's code of conduct for disclosure. The former Labour cabinet minister Tony Benn warned Mr Straw that if he knew what the security services were up to he would be the first home secretary ever. "So I am making the case - I hope it doesn't shock anybody - that open government and freedom of information is good for ministers, not just for parliament and the public."

Mr Benn added: "I hope public opinion makes it clear to the home secretary and others that we are not prepared to accept that we shall be treated as children outside the inner knowledge of what happens, because if so it denies ministers the advice they need and the public the opportunity to participate in their future and not just be spectators of their fate."

The 36 Labour MPs voting against the government on the principle of policy advice being exempt from the bill were:

Tony Benn, Dr David Clark, Ann Clwyd, Harry Cohen, Frank Cook, Jeremy Corbyn, Robin Corbett, Jim Cousins, Tam Dalyell, Gwyneth Dunwoody, Mark Fisher, Derek Foster, Neil Gerrard, Thomas Graham, David Hinchliffe, Kelvin Hopkins, Jon Owen Jones, Dr Lynne Jones, Andy Love, John McDonnell, Andrew Mackinlay, Alice Mahon, Jim Marshall, Robert Marshall-Andrews, Bill Michie, Julie Morgan, Gordon Prentice, Alan Simpson, Dennis Skinner, Llewellyn Smith, Betty Williams, David Winnick, Mike Wood, Dr Tony Wright, Derek Wyatt. Ronnie Campbell acted as a teller for supporters of the amendment.

fields.headline: Post-it Notes
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about those sticky yellow reminders on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about those sticky yellow reminders on the net
fields.body:
1. Now you've finally peeled all those sticky yellow messages off your computer screen, you can join in the celebrations. It is the 20th birthday of the Post-it Note today.

2. Consider how these little yellow scraps with the stubborn yet gently adhesive strip have transformed the office landscape.

3. Back in the Jurassic age of office equipment, when big black ring-binders ruled and computers belonged on Buck Rogers, workers had to write on their hands to keep dates in mind, or weigh down notes for colleagues with cumbersome paperweights. God saw all was not well and intervened.

4. Art Fry, a devout Iowa church-goer who worked in product development at US stationery giant 3M, was suddenly struck with inspiration while finding the paper markers in his hymn book kept falling out.

5. "I thought, what I really need is a bookmark that would attach and detach lightly, wouldn't fall off, but wouldn't hurt the hymnal either," he recalled, and, with the help of a colleague's special non-sticky adhesive, the Post-it Note was born.

6. "The Post-it story is a classic example of how one person's spark of inspiration has thrived on an unperceived need," says a 3M spokeswoman. Gurus of good management should note that Fry took advantage of 3M's innovative 15% rule, allowing scientists to spend up to 15% of their time pursuing personal projects.

7. The Post-it Note stuck around and is now available in 56 shapes, 27 sizes and in 29 different colours, including fluorescent, neon, "retro bright", midnight shade, not forgetting the original pale yellow - produced because it was the same shade as legal note pads.

8. You can also buy many different imitations, from custom-printed notes to Mouse Post-it Notes.

9. "The circle of addiction quickly spread," recalls Art, now retired, although enjoying a life of cult celebritydom that has seen him star in an advert for Gap khakis.

10. A passion for Post-it Notes was formed across the world. At the Royal College of Art in London, a student is currently showing a work of art celebrating the humble notes and the mundanities of daily life they mark, while in Italy, another student is writing a thesis about the little yellow slips.

webTitle: Leeds fans dogged by bad name

fields.headline: Leeds fans dogged by bad name
fields.standfirst:
The violence in Turkey will damage English football, whoever is to blame, says Football Unlimited editor Paul MacInnes

Listen to sports correspondent Daniel Taylor on the streets of Istanbul
Two dead but game will go ahead
fields.trailText: It is still too early to be certain of what happened in Istanbul's Taksim Square last night, but one can be sure that the consequences of the fighting between Leeds fans and locals in which two English supporters died will be far-reaching.
fields.body:
It is still too early to be certain of what happened in Istanbul's Taksim Square last night, but one can be sure that the consequences of the fighting between Leeds fans and locals in which two English supporters died will be far-reaching.

Any thoughts about the implications for English football are obviously insignificant when two families are in mourning. But the Football Association have already been on the defensive today, denying that the violence will affect England's bid for the 2006 World Cup and rebutting the instant assumptions that English fans were to blame.

"We are very conscious of the fact that in recent years the English fan abroad has in many instances, particularly in European club football, been certainly more sinned against than sinning," said FA spokesman Steve Double this morning. But at the same time as Mr Double was speaking, the Turkish press was proclaiming 'the return of the hooligan' on their front pages.

And this is where the problem lies for the FA and English clubs in general. No matter how hard they try to dispel the hooligan image created by the horrors of the 80s, any violence - no matter who causes it - only serves to reinforce commonly-held assumptions abroad. The fact that last night's tragedy might have been the fault of Galatasaray fans or even supporters of local rivals Fenerbahce is really neither here nor there.

It has been announced that tonight's game will definitely go ahead, giving Leeds fans a chance to demonstrate that they are far from the animals that some people will paint them as. However, the club has reacted by cancelling all official flights to Istanbul today and appealing to fans not to travel. The decision was ostensibly made for the supporters' own protection, but it only goes to further underline that when travelling abroad, the English reputation precedes them still.

fields.headline: Bosnich passes Spanish inquisition
fields.trailText: Goalless habits may be unbecoming to Manchester United but last night their second 0,0 draw in Spain in the space of a fortnight should set up Sir Alex Ferguson's European Cup holders for a place in the last four once again.
fields.body:
Goalless habits may be unbecoming to Manchester United but last night their second 0,0 draw in Spain in the space of a fortnight should set up Sir Alex Ferguson's European Cup holders for a place in the last four once again.

The alertness of Mark Bosnich, plus sound sensible defending, successfully defied Real Madrid who in the end were looking to Steve McManaman for inspiration.

Yet even the former Liverpool forward was unable to beat Bosnich, although he had an outstanding chance to do so eight minutes from the end. A backheeled return pass from Fernando Morientes left McManaman to beat the United goalkeeper from a range of six yards and an angle of 45 degrees but Bosnich had little problem blocking his shot.

The moment summed up the evening. Real Madrid spent much of the match driving forward and for a time it seemed that the swift, subtle passes and intuitive running of Raul, Morientes, Savio and McManaman would eventually find a way through.

That happened several times in the first half, though less in the second. But Bosnich was equal to every crisis and as Real tired, both physically and mentally, the authority of Jaap Stam and Henning Berg in the middle of the United defence became more pronounced while Roy Keane put in another performance of tireless industry in midfield.

Not that Ferguson was enamoured of his team's performance. 'I am relieved because it was one of our poorest performances in a big game for some time,' Manchester United 's manager said afterwards. 'Our use of the ball was careless and 0,0 is not the best of results for us. We still have a long way to go.'

Clearly Manchester United would have preferred a scor ing draw if they could not win the game. Even one away goal would have been mighty precious. But, while the result has put them in a strong position, it is worth remembering that after sharing a 0,0 draw in Monaco at a similar stage in 1998, United then went out to an away goal.

Last night three opportunities fell to Andy Cole before half-time but he was unable to take any of them. The best came in the 26th minute after Stam had nodded on Beckham's corner from the near post. Cole met the ball inside the six-yard box but his header flew over the crossbar.

The Madrid youngsters' adulation of Beckham was not shared by the Real fans, who showered him with minor missiles every time he took a corner. Bosnich, too, was the target of a load of rubbish from behind the goal once he moved to the end occupied by the Ultra Sur sec tion of Real's support, but he seemed unmoved.

Gento, a voice from Real's golden age in the 50s, had declared himself confident that in European games the present side could succeed in performing 'like 11 Di Stefanos'. United were grateful that their opponents could no longer come up with one Alfredo - or, indeed, Nicolas Anelka, whose pace has troubled Stam before now.

Morientes, doubtful beforehand because of a leg injury, did not look match-fit and with the hard-working Raul starting to flag, Real lost much of their momentum during the last quarter of an hour.

McManaman was the exception. Stamina was always his strength, and his willingness to run at defenders, take the ball square and make himself available for return passes enabled Real to maintain some attacking force until the end.

Yet it would have been hard on Bosnich had McManaman beaten him at the last. After nine minutes the Australian had denied him a goal for the first time by tipping a diving header over the bar but his best moment was the one-handed save which thwarted Morientes after McManaman and Savio had left the striker with only Bosnich to beat.

Ferguson's point about United's sluggish use of the ball was well made. Although Beckham often switched to the middle in the first half, with Ryan Giggs doing the same in the second, and Paul Scholes strove to get forward to support Dwight Yorke and Cole, United's attack seldom achieved its normal rhythm.

Yet briefly, on the stroke of half-time, they thought they had gone in front. Iker Casillas, Real's 18-year-old goalkeeper, failed to hold Scholes' low shot from 25 yards and, though Yorke pounced to put in the rebound, he was adjudged to have been offside earlier.

That moment apart, the game was always going to end as it did if Real failed to score.

Real Madrid (4,4,2): Casillas Salgado, Ivan Campo, Karanka, Roberto Carlos McManaman, Helguera, Redondo, Savio (Balic, 75min) Morientes (Ognjenovic, 86), Raul.

Manchester United (4,4-2): Bosnich G Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin (Silvestre, 87) Beckham, Keane, Scholes (Butt, 81), Giggs Cole,Yorke (Sheringham, 76).

Referee: G Veissiere (France).

fields.standfirst: Lawrence Booth looks at the reaction of the following day's press to Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Year. Click here to read the initial response
fields.trailText: "What, no Beefy?" screamed the headline in the Mirror. Yes, the selection that "sparked a million barstool arguments", as the paper's own Mike Walters put it, has continued in today's press, with the nation's cricket correspondents reacting to yesterday's announcement of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century.
fields.body:
"What, no Beefy?" screamed the headline in the Mirror. Yes, the selection that "sparked a million barstool arguments", as the paper's own Mike Walters put it, has continued in today's press, with the nation's cricket correspondents reacting to yesterday's announcement of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century.

The redtops were predictably outraged by the omission of Ian Botham from the famous five. The Mirror quoted one of his old adversaries, former Australian captain Allan Border: "I am surprised he didn't make the top five because he was a phenomenon whose impact on cricket went far beyond his statistics." But former England seamer and selector, Sir Alec Bedser, was less enthusiastic: "To be honest, I'm surprised he even came that high [16th]."

The Sun was less histrionic, but still noted that "possibly the biggest surprise is the omission of Botham." Unlike the Mirror, however, it led with the inclusion of Shane Warne. Cricket correspondent John Etheridge wrote: "It is unlikely that any bowler has ever turned the ball so savagely and retained such accuracy."

Jim Holden, writing in the Express, poured scorn on the Botham-apologists (who also included Teletext and Ceefax). "What nonsense," he wrote of those who took Beefy's absence as a slight on the good name of cricket. "Would anyone quibble with the credentials of the five players involved? [...] Botham wouldn't..."

Like many other papers, the Express led instead with Warne, the only contemporary cricketer among the chosen five. "Australia's leg-spinner deserves to be in such distinguished company," wrote Holden.

Ian Wooldridge of the Mail, a member of the 100-strong panel that cast the votes, approached the Warne question from a different angle: "I did not vote for him," he admitted, "and nor would I in a second ballot." Wooldridge would have gone for Wally Hammond instead. But then he seemed reluctant to vote at all: "With respect to Wisden...the idea of naming the five greatest cricketers over 100 years is so subjective as to be quite ridiculous." It was, he said, no more than "tremendous entertainment and clever marketing." Wooldridge's iconoclasm was also evident when he said that Garry Sobers, "the most complete cricketer of our time", and not Don Bradman, should have headed the list.

Two of the country's most respected writers also queried the fact that Sobers didn't get more than 90 votes. The Telegraph's Michael Henderson was amazed that 10 panellists didn't pick him, and called the choices of South Africans Colin Bland and Bruce Mitchell "naughty." And Christopher Martin-Jenkins of the Times, who delivered the speech on the five cricketers at last night's Wisden dinner at the Honourable Artillery Club in central London, said it was "a mystery how 10 judges failed to support Sobers, indisputaby the greatest all-rounder since WG Grace."

Both Henderson and CMJ, who have had their differences in the past, agreed that three of the five choices were tricky to make. "The identity of the other three players was always likely to set friend against friend and unite enemies," mused Henderson, who suggested Dennis Lillee, Hammond and Richie Benaud as selections with which "nobody could have quibbled". CMJ mentioned Hammond as well, concluding that he and SF Barnes were "the most dubious omissions." He also looked further ahead: "It is as certain as passing time itself that there will be more than one Asian when the exercise is repeated a hundred years from now."

But Henderson still stuck up for the top five's two most-modern members, arguing that Viv Richards and Shane Warne "would have been great players in any era, despite what certain old-timers might allege." The Telegraph, whose coverage of the vote was more thorough than anyone else's, also featured the views of Nasser Hussain, who queried the selection of Jack Hobbs.

Derek Pringle, writing in the Independent, was staggered by the absence of Lillee and Malcolm Marshall. Their omission, he argued, "reflects the lowly status in which bowlers, especially fast ones, still seem to be held." In the Guardian, Mike Selvey had an original slant, noting that the real losers were the Five Cricketers of the Year (Chris Cairns, Tom Moody, Saqlain Mushtaq, Rahul Dravid, and Lance Klusener), for whom it must "seem like winning the county championship on the day England regain the Ashes (we can all dream)." Ever cheeky, Selvey lamented his own failure to get a single nomination, but points out that he received the same number of votes as Brian Lara, Greg Chappell and Barry Richards.

In Australia, the Melbourne Age were understandably jubilant about the inclusion of local boy Warne, calling it "a further giant leap forward" in a "brilliant career." Not so brilliant, however, that Warne himself seemed a little confused by the tribute. "Obviously, it's been a huge couple of months for me," he said, "breaking Dennis Lillee's record, being named in the Australian Team of the Century, 10 successive Test wins and now named as one of Wisden's Team of the Century." That's one award not even Wisden knew about.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Daddy Blair gives short shrift to inquisitive Hague

fields.headline: Daddy Blair gives short shrift to inquisitive Hague
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: You can always tell when Tony Blair is rattled. He starts telling people that they are wrong, plainly and simply wrong.
fields.body:
You can always tell when Tony Blair is rattled. He starts telling people that they are wrong, plainly and simply wrong.

Edward Heath was much the same. He would say of an argument which he did not like, "That, of course, is wrong. So, moving on ... "

In this, both of them resemble parents explaining why their offspring should keep their elbows off the table. "Because I'm the daddy and I say so," is as intellectually valid as anything Mr Blair said to William Hague yesterday.

"I think what you are saying is absolute nonsense," he said when Mr Hague dredged up again the question of who knew what and when about the Rover crisis.

Mr Hague was focusing on that question "when surely the real issue is what we do about thousands of families that face losing their jobs," Mr Blair said. He found this "absolutely ridiculous".

Actually, when tens of thousands of people are likely to lose their jobs, the question of whether this is the government's fault seems rather important, and not ridiculous at all. If I had broken your 24-place Meissen dinner service by carelessly dropping it from the millennium wheel, you would be rather cross if I responded by saying: "It is pathetic and completely ridiculous to worry about the whats and whens of how the porcelain came to be damaged. What we need to do is concentrate on the real issue - which is, what are we all going to eat our pizza off now?"

Mr Hague quoted various BMW statements in which executives claimed to have given ministers warning of the looming Rover closure. One BMW executive had said that "'Mr Blair's attitudes and opinions seem to be many and varied. I've heard him say different things.'

"Well", Mr Hague went on, "that seems like a pretty honest account to me."

Mr Blair decided that this was wrong. He found it "both pathetic and ridiculous" that the Tory leader "should be concentrating on backing BMW's claims against the secretary of state, rather than trying to make sure that those people who do face the loss of their job get a new job - which is what I intend concentrating on!"

The sub-text was, I surmise, "how can you believe a German when you could believe a decent, non-Teutonic, English minister with the impeccably British name of Byers?" But of course a good European like Tony Blair could not say so.

Mr Hague wondered when he was going to sack Mr Byers. Mr Blair replied: "It is only because you have nothing serious to say on this issue that you have to carry on in the way that you have" - which translates as "you're wrong". In fact, Mr Hague had made an important point - that the Department of Industry had doctored a statement from BMW last December to make it appear that the Rover situation was less serious than it was. But "pathetic" and "ridiculous" were the only replies Mr Hague was going to get.

A few minutes later Mr Hague tried again. Hi-tech companies were threatening to leave Britain because of the extra national insurance being levied on freelance computer nerds (my phrase, not his). What's more, the nerds themselves were also heading out. Every airport would be stuffed with chaps wearing ties with V-neck pullovers and those annoying soft shoes shaped like chicken kievs, all heading for Silicon Valley. (I paraphrase.)

The prime minister had a swift and convincing answer. While he was glad to see one economic migrant coming home (a reference to Lord Ashcroft), "what you are saying really is nonsense".

So that's all right then. As Sir Edward would say at this point, "So, moving on ..."

webTitle: Credit card company 'lays shoppers' fears to rest'

fields.headline: Credit card company 'lays shoppers' fears to rest'
fields.trailText: A multi-million pound TV advertising campaign aimed at laying to rest internet shoppers' fears about credit card fraud could see a huge surge in the number of online purchases.
fields.body:
A multi-million pound TV advertising campaign aimed at laying to rest internet shoppers' fears about credit card fraud could see a huge surge in the number of online purchases.

Europe's leading credit card issuer, Barclaycard, is planning to promote its guarantee against internet shopping fraud with a series of adverts starring Have I Got News For You presenter Angus Deayton, after research revealed that two-thirds of customers with net access lacked the confidence to buy online.

It is thought that by the end of 2000, two million customers would use credit cards to buy on the world wide web, if their transactions were protected against fraud.

James Davison, managing director of e-commerce at Barclaycard, hopes the promotion will persuade consumers that they can shop as safely on the net as they can on the high street.

"Shopping online is not a fleeting trend. It is becoming the norm and we want to ensure our customers know they are protected when making purchases in this way," he said.

webTitle: Pirc backs green plan to force BP out of Alaska

fields.headline: Pirc backs green plan to force BP out of Alaska
fields.standfirst:
BP Amoco
Pirc
fields.trailText: Pirc, the corporate governance watchdog, has thrown its weight behind a controversial attempt by Greenpeace to make BP Amoco withdraw from Alaska.
fields.body:
Pirc, the corporate governance watchdog, has thrown its weight behind a controversial attempt by Greenpeace to make BP Amoco withdraw from Alaska.

In a report sent out to fund managers yesterday, Pirc urged its clients to vote for a Greenpeace resolution demanding that the oil group redirects investment towards renewable energy sources.

The move could trigger an embarassing show of dissent at BP's annual general meeting later this month - Pirc believes its clients own between 3% and 5% of the company. Pirc director Alan MacDougall said: "We don't think BP has a strategy to deal with the transition away from carbon."

Greenpeace's resolution calls on BP Amoco to cancel all plans for oil exploration around the Arctic region. This would mean abandoning the company's half-complete $700m (£450m) Northstar project, which involves the construction of an artificial island off the Alaskan coast.

The resolution argues that the money should go towards enlarging BP Solarex - a scheme aimed at producing solar energy.

In a highly critical report, Pirc says BP is taking too little action to address the long-term shift away from fossil fuels, which cause global warming: "We regard the company's approach at present as too passive and would consider it more appropriate for it to show stronger leadership."

BP, which has gained praise for its statements on the environment in recent years, argues that there is insufficient demand to justify more investment in solar energy. However, Pirc says: "A company with the resources and scale of BP Amoco can play an important role in creating the conditions for increased demand."

It says demand could be generated "through lobbying, marketing and promotional activity as well as through investing in research and development and production".

Pirc admitted there would be a "short-term cost" associated with this strategy but said there would be "compensatory gains" for shareholders in positioning BP Amoco to take advantage of the future market for renewable energy.

Pirc's clients include many of the City's biggest pension funds, managing investments of more than £250bn. The organisation provides analysis of companies' approaches to executive pay, boardroom appointments and environmental policy.

Mr MacDougall admitted there was no chance of Greenpeace's resolution being carried but said support of at least 5% would "send a strong message and provide a basis for ongoing dialogue with the company".

BP Amoco rejected Pirc's analysis - a spokesman said the company was "moving as fast as is practical and sensible" towards renewable energy.

The company has commited itself to increasing the size of its solar business ten-fold by 2007, making it a $1,000bn enterprise. The spokesman added: "it is Pirc's prerogative to advise their clients on how they think their shares should be used."

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Flag of inconvenience
fields.body:
Flag of inconvenience

My dictionary defines insurance as a "means of avoiding risk, loss, damage" - a consoling guarantee that justifies the chunk of salary siphoned off each month. Too often, though, it seems the only thing guaranteed about insurance is that the premiums keep on rising.

Michael Rayment was left stranded when his car broke down and Green Flag declined to assist him. His membership, it explained, had lapsed because his direct debits had ceased. Later he found that three payments had been missed - because Green Flag had failed to request its dues from his building society. When he complained, Green Flag promised temporary cover while it investigated, but the certificates it sent were out of date. Since then he has received several letters advising him of missed payments, despite the direct debit instruction and a buoyant bank balance.

The culprit is the usual one: the computer system. "We took a major upgrade to the system and, due to a technical difficulty, Mr Rayment's payment was not recognised by his building society. Normally we send automatic confirmation of any such difficulty within a matter of days."

Rayment has now been reimbursed for his alternative recovery costs and offered a year's free breakdown cover.

Lack of cooperation

Amid the outcry over new fees for using cash machines, the Cooperative Bank has stood virtuous and disapproving. But, says Dermod Quirke of Halifax, the ethical bank has introduced clandestine charges of its own. To spare customers the need to seek out its scanty branches, it provided prepaid envelopes to be used for deposits by post. Now, says Quirke, this free service has ceased without any warning or announcement. The reason given was that the post office will now accept cheque and cash deposits over the counter: bad news for those who don't have a post office handy and those who, like Quirke's disabled mother-in-law, chose the Co-op because it was effectively as close as the nearest postbox.

Ninety per cent of the population lives within a mile of a post office, says a Co-op spokesman, pointing out that the over-the-counter service takes a day less than the postal method. "Anyone who finds it inconvenient or is disabled can make representations to us and we will consider their case," says the spokesman co-operatively. "Tried that," retorts Quirke. "It didn't work."

Wheel of misfortune

Helen Betts of London pleads for help after trying vainly to book tickets on the London Eye. "I've tried phoning several times a day for a week and can't get through," she says, "and my faxes go without reply."

The excuse is that demand for the giant ferris wheel has exceeded all expectations and the system has been overloaded. "We have doubled the number of lines to enable us to take 6,000 calls an hour," says a spokeswoman. Betts eventually got her tickets by visiting the office in person.

C&W: a wait off his mind

A tip for the beleaguered masses still on the end of Cable & Wireless's helplines. A despairing Neil Wareham gave up waiting for help with his C&W internet service and sent an email to customer services. He was delighted to get "a polite, helpful reply from a real person and an apology for the quality of the phone-based staff." My advice is, email them at support@cwcom.net.

Write to us at 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: The best Oliver Platt scene
fields.standfirst: Lake Placid
fields.trailText: Maine. After reports of divers going missing on the hitherto aptly named Lake Placid, research scientist Kelly Scott (Bridget Fonda), Fish and Game Warden Jack Wells (Bill Pullman) and local sherrif Hank Keough (Brendan Gleeson) gather by the water. Suddenly, a helicopter begins descending over the lake.
fields.body:
Maine. After reports of divers going missing on the hitherto aptly named Lake Placid, research scientist Kelly Scott (Bridget Fonda), Fish and Game Warden Jack Wells (Bill Pullman) and local sherrif Hank Keough (Brendan Gleeson) gather by the water. Suddenly, a helicopter begins descending over the lake.

"If this is who I think it is..." mutters Scott. She peers at the helicopter.

"It is."

Wells steps forward.

"Who?"

"Hector Cyr. Mythology Professor. He's done some work for our museum. He also..."

"What?"

"Swims with crocodiles."

The copter lands. Cyr (Oliver Platt) dismounts, then shambles amiably towards the group, scratching his beard. He beams at Kelly.

"You beat me! Balls!" He glances at the water.

"Splendid lake, eh? You could be a man on a lake like this. So, who do we have from Fish and Game." "Me", answers Wells. Cyr ignores him.

fields.headline: Net ads swell Granada coffers
fields.standfirst:
Dot.com mania brings in £8m

E-finance: special report
Granada
fields.trailText: Dot.com mania has provided a fillip to the earnings performance of Granada, the media and hotels group, with the internet driving an overall growth of 12% in advertising revenues for the three months to March 31.
fields.body:
Dot.com mania has provided a fillip to the earnings performance of Granada, the media and hotels group, with the internet driving an overall growth of 12% in advertising revenues for the three months to March 31.

In a trading statement the company said that advertising revenues had risen from a 9% increase in the December quarter to more than 12% in the March period.

Granada is predicting that the trend will continue upwards and expects a jump of 17% in ITV advertising revenues in April.

The group said advertising revenues from internet and technology companies increased from £5m during the December quarter to over £8m by the end of March.

Industry expectations are that total dot.com spending on advertising will exceed some £200m this year.

Granada's media division reported a 10% rise in sales for the six months to March, with its operations benefiting from higher programme sales and better subscriber numbers from its 50%-owned pay television service, ONdigital.

Charles Allen, Granada's chief executive, said: "We have had a very good first half-year performance, with excellent results from our media division and strong progress in hospitality. With good second-half prospects in both this leaves us in very good shape for the year as a whole."

Analysts are forecasting Granada to report a pre-tax profit of £869m in 2000. The company's shares yesterday fell 12p to 620p.

Mr Allen said programme sales had increased 13% in the half-year to March and predicted this growth would be more than 20% over the next six months.

Strong sales have been from programmes such as Lost for Words, The Royle Family and Longitude. Granada also produces the longest running TV soap, Coronation Street.

ONdigital, which Granada's jointly owns with Carlton Communications, revealed that its subscriber numbers rose to 552,000 in December, 18 months since it began operating. Subscriber numbers are expected to reach 1m by the year's end and Granada said that its share of the investment from ONdigital in the first half was £82m.

Analysts have estimated that if ONdigital were spun off in a public offering Granada's 50% shareholding would be worth about £1bn.

There is also the question of the value of Granada's stake in internet search engine AskJeeves UK, which would deliver the company significant value if it were ever sold via a flotation.

The cloud that hangs over Granada's share price, however, is the uncertainty over whether the government will allow it to bid for Carlton Communications or United News & Media. The latter have proposed a merger to consolidate ITV ownership in the UK.

Granada said revenues per available room for its Meridien hotel chain grew by 8%, with total sales up by 9%. The rise was underpinned by the expansion of the Meridien brand, with another 12 hotels opened in the past six months, taking the chain total to 121.

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Cage and Arquette call the calling-off off, Heather Graham to co-star with Johnny Depp, Jason Biggs signs up for Prozac Nation, and Wachowski Brothers woo Jet Li for Matrix sequel
fields.body:
 Nic Cage and Patricia Arquette clearly can't quite decide about each other. Six weeks ago, the couple looked set to call the whole thing off. Today they're apparently back together again. Cage's publicist last night admitted that the actor had withdrawn the divorce papers he served in February but would not explain exactly why, or at what form the couple's relationship now takes. The pair married in May 1995 and appeared together on screen in last year's Martin Scorsese movie Bringing Out the Dead. But on filing for divorce (citing "irreconcilable differences"), Cage argued that they had actually been effectively separated since January 1996. They're different from us, these Hollywood folk.

 Heather Graham is in final talks to co-star alongside Johnny Depp in From Hell, the Hughes Brothers' London-set re-telling of the Jack the Ripper story. The Austin Powers temptress will play an imperilled Irish prostitute. Depp is already on board as a Scotland Yard cop and the Ripper will be played by Nigel Hawthorne. The film is slated to start shooting at locations around London in July.

 Hot from the success of American Pie, actor Jason Biggs has signed up to play Christina Ricci's boyfriend in the upcoming adaptation of Prozac Nation. Based on Elizabeth Wurtzel's best-selling memoir, the film follows the rollercoaster ride lifestyle of a pill-popping over-achiever from Harvard to a career in Manhattan's media circles. The picture marks Ricci's first stab at film producing and will be directed by Norwegian film-maker Erik Skjoldbjaerg, previously best known for his snowbound 1997 thriller Insomnia.

 The Wachowski Brothers are rumoured to be wooing Chinese martial arts expert Jet Li to join the cast of their two sequels to The Matrix. Li, who is currently starring in the hit American movie Romeo Must Die, would join original cast-member Keanu Reeves in two films scheduled to begin production later this year. A breakthrough hit on its release last summer, The Matrix scooped an impressive four technical awards at last week's Oscars.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: The best bits of the papers cut out and pasted into our virtual scrapbook
fields.trailText: Teamtalk Internazionale have begun discussions with Arsenal to sign Emmanuel Petit in the summer for £7m. Lazio and Real Madrid are also ready to get involved.
fields.body:
Teamtalk Internazionale have begun discussions with Arsenal to sign Emmanuel Petit in the summer for £7m. Lazio and Real Madrid are also ready to get involved.

Planet Football Portuguese midfielder Manuel Rui Costa may sign for Manchester United within the next few days. The Fiorentina player, long admired by Alex Ferguson, has fallen out of favour with Viola chairman Cecchi Gori and is likely to be on his way sooner rather than later. But United have competition - Juventus, Milan and Barcelona are also tracking the 27-year-old playmaker.

Chelsea are interested in Internazionale forward Andrea Pirlo. The 20-year-old has scored five goals in 17 starts while on loan at Reggina this season. If Chelsea land him, he'll be replacing George Weah, who is set to return to Milan in the summer.

Manchester United and Chelsea are both chasing Fiorentina striker Abel Balbo, but it is unlikely the Argentinian would want to move to the Premiership.

The Mirror Newcastle and Sunderland are involved in a tug-of-war for Belgian international Bart Goor. The 26-year-old Anderlecht winger will cost £2.5m.

webTitle: Sayles to script new Hanks film

fields.headline: Sayles to script new Hanks film
fields.trailText: Indie film-maker John Sayles has been hired by Tom Hanks's production company to script a star-vehicle for the actor
fields.body:
Indie film-maker John Sayles has been hired by Tom Hanks's production company to script a star-vehicle for the actor. Sayles will adapt a New Yorker magazine article, entitled A Cold Case, for the screen, Variety reports today. Universal will back the project which will be produced by Hanks and his business partner Gary Goetzman. The Oscar-winning actor will take the lead role of a Manhattan DA who labours for thirty years to catch the killer of a city restaurant manager.

Sayles is best known as the creator of such low-budget, rugged, individualist pictures as Lone Star, City of Hope and Limbo, but has always supplemented his personal projects with lucrative stints as a Hollywood script doctor. The director has collaborated with Hanks once before, when he was employed to polish up the script for Apollo 13 back in 1994. Hanks was Oscar-nominated for his role in the finished film and clearly regards Sayles as a man he can trust. That said, this trust appears to only extend as far as his writing skills. Despite Sayles's experience in the director's chair, he is being employed as a scriptwriter only. A director for A Cold Case has yet to be announced.

A Cold Case was researched and written by New Yorker journalist Paul Gourevitch, and the article was optioned for a six figure sum by Hanks's production company, Playtone, when it was published in February. While Hanks is playing an active role in its development, the film remains just one of several projects the actor currently has on the go. Last month he announced that he will produce and take the leading role in a children's Christmas film The Polar Express. More recently, he has hired Oscar-winning American Beauty screenwriter Alan Ball to script an as yet untitled thriller for Playtone. Once again, Hanks will both produce and star.

webTitle: Life of Olivier: British Library acquires 'archive beyond compare'

fields.headline: Life of Olivier: British Library acquires 'archive beyond compare'
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The British Library has acquired the vast archive of the actor and director Laurence Olivier, it announced yesterday
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The British Library has acquired the vast archive of the actor and director Laurence Olivier, it announced yesterday.

The avalanche of paper reveals a man who knew he was marked for greatness and began to hoard evidence for his life history from his early teenage years.

The 150 boxes, each holding dozens of files of letters, photographs and papers - he kept not only all the letters he received but in most cases his replies - contain his first Equity card, his RAF logbook and treasures such as a first draft of John Osborne's The Entertainer, which launched one of his greatest roles on stage and film.

The library's director, Brian Lang, called it "an archive beyond compare".

The papers were "an extraordinary insight into his family life", a staff member said. "They reveal an amazingly meticulous man." Complaints about trivial things from members of the audience at the National Theatre received "a proper letter in reply".

The library has bought the papers by private treaty from the Olivier family for about £1m, far less than they would have fetched on the open market. It was offered the archive because of its linked collections, including the papers of the playwrights Terence Rattigan and Harold Pinter and the critic Kenneth Tynan.

The money came from a £500,000 heritage lottery grant and grants from the Pilgrim Trust and the Foundation for Sport and the Arts. The library still has to raise £180,000 to complete the purchase.

fields.headline: 'Invalid' Bergman considers suicide
fields.trailText: Speaking in a recent TV interview, Swedish film-maker Ingmar Bergman has admitted to feelings of depression after the death of his wife, and said he would commit suicide if he grew to frail to look after himsel
fields.byline: By Film Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Speaking in a recent TV interview, Swedish film-maker Ingmar Bergman has admitted to feelings of depression after the death of his wife, and said he would commit suicide if he grew to frail to look after himself. Such news is almost comforting. Bergman may have not made a film in nearly 20 years, but it's good to know that the great man remains as majestically gloomy as ever.

Now 81, Bergman lives as a semi-recluse in his native Sweden and only agreed to the Swedish TV interview (yet to be aired) because it was structured as a casual conversation with his actor friend, Erland Josephson. But in Bergman dramas, even the most casual conversation soon veers towards a contemplation of the infinite, and this one was no exception. "The thing I consider appalling would be to suddenly become a vegetable and a burden on other people," Bergman chirruped. "A soul slowly dying out, trapped in a body in which the insides gradually sabotage me I think that would be terrible."

Suicide, he admitted, would be the only option in that case. "That's not idle talk on my part. For me, that would be a completely natural end. I hope I will have enough sense left to have the capacity and opportunity to plan and organise it."

The director also discussed his feelings of desolation following the death of his wife Ingrid in 1985. "It was the grimmest thing that happened in my life," he said. "It has made an invalid of me. I just think living is a burden. That I will never meet Ingrid again feels devastating. It is a horrible thought."

Having trained in the theatre, Bergman made a crop of films that were little seen outside Sweden until the huge art-house success of both Wild Strawberries and The Seventh Seal in 1957. He effectively retired from film-making with 1982's Oscar-winning semi-autobiographical masterpiece Fanny and Alexander, which was filmed in a six-hour version for Swedish television and a three-hour edit for cinema audiences. In the intervening years, he has worked sporadically as a theatre producer and writer, but has insisted he has no plans to return to the cinema.

fields.headline: The method in my  madness
fields.standfirst: Christian Bale began his acting career as a lost little boy in Empire of the Sun. Now he's a murderer in American Psycho. He tells Libby Brooks about his battle to get the part - and why it cost him his teeth Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Christian Bale began his acting career as a lost little boy in Empire of the Sun. Now he's a murderer in American Psycho. He tells Libby Brooks about his battle to get the part - and why it cost him his teeth
fields.body:
The devil is in the dentistry. Christian Bale smiles a newly even smile. Those suggestively vampiric incisors and the feminising gap between his top front teeth are gone. And it's all the fault of an American psycho.

"I liked my old teeth. I have a moulding of them on a shelf. But with Patrick Bateman, his physicality is much more important than with most characters. He deals totally in the superficial, and he's incredibly narcissistic. I looked at myself in the mirror and it just wasn't right. I was warned that if I got caps I could get a lisp, and you might still be able to tell in close-up. So I thought, I like my teeth, but I'm not so attached to them that I'm going to ruin this whole movie because I refuse to get them done."

He moves his arm and a still, buff bicep strains the knit of his tidy jumper. Preparation for the role of serial-killing 80s alpha-male Patrick Bateman in the screen adaptation of the Bret Easton Ellis novel required dumb-bells as well as braces. Just as Bateman's bloodlust is the amoral mirror of his lust for things, so his bankrupt soul is the necessary continuum of his empty obsession with bodily perfection.

"Working out took over my life," says 26-year-old Bale in his nowhere English accent. "I became fascinated with talking about the body, and diet, and the gym. It made me very judgmental of other people's bodies as well." But it is that obsession with surface minutiae that defines the era and its most extreme literary personification, American Psycho.

It was a role to perform, rather than understand, Bale insists, echoing his director Mary Harron, who says she believes that a degree of detachment was the only way to prevent a disturbing film becoming an offensive one. "He's acting in his own life. On paper, of course, he should be hateful, but he's incredibly entertaining."

Bale's Bateman is a supremely confident confection, and entirely at odds with the engaging naturalism of his recent performances in suburban morality tale Metroland, and Todd Haynes's Velvet Goldmine, in which he starred alongside Jonathan Rhys-Meyers and Ewan McGregor. Whether expounding the life lessons to be found in Whitney Houston's The Greatest Love of All, or spinning into frantic despair at the sight of his fag friend's better-looking business card, Bale offers a slicky modulated performance that distills the essence of Bateman, and the book.

Published in 1991, American Psycho was Easton Ellis's savage and bloody satire of late 80s extremity. The material fetishism and moral vacuity of the money-drenched, Manhattan-dwelling protagonists were gruesome enough. But it was the lovingly detailed scenes of obscene and often highly sexualised torture and murder (which may or may not have occurred in Bateman's own drug-fuelled imagination) that whipped up a storm of controversy, resulting in accusations of misogyny and exploitation.

The screen adaptation is far less graphic. It is the context, rather than the killings themselves, that creates the horror, argues Bale. "Bateman is neither an anti-hero nor a typical villain. There's no resolution, and his only punishment by the end is his own existence. But the scariness comes from his whole crowd, from that society and their thought processes. Bateman's very much an idiot, and much of the humour comes from the difference in perception between how he views himself and how we view him."

The basic theme of American Psycho is reason without heart, he says. "It's like capitalism without any spiritual component. I think that given the correct situation everyone can drop to levels of extreme depravity. We train armies to adopt the opposite of the everyday moral code. It's no wonder that in conflicts you get soldiers out of control, doing horrendous things, raping. These are ordinary people who, given the situation, become something else."

Perhaps like Bale himself - a personable presence who happens to enjoy the immersion of being someone else. And rather like his first film role as Jim Graham, a little boy making sense of a big war, in Empire of the Sun, Stephen Spielberg's second world war epic. Watching the 13-year-old Bale as he battles for sense and self in a Japanese PoW camp, it is as though he fell to earth fully formed. It's an astonishing performance, utterly fearless, wholly acted.

Bale talks about the experience with the gentle confidence of a hurt resolved. "At an age when you're supposed to be going out and doing things for the first time, making your mistakes, suddenly I lost that anonymity. Adults say you should know better, other kids are jealous, and you feel like a freak. I became pretty reclusive for a couple of years. For me, it had been a great experience, but it didn't sum up my whole life. But it did for everyone else."

In 1992 he moved from England to Los Angeles, where he has worked quietly but consistently since, establishing himself as a versatile, if not entirely bankable, actor. There are two reasons why his transition from child to adult performer was so painless, he says. "I got a dislike for what small fame I had early on, so I attempted not to let it disrupt everything. Also, [Jim] was a very adult, complex part, that didn't rely on my being cute. I didn't get a shock when I got older and started getting hair," he concludes, stroking a lightly bronzed chin that is destined always to look clean-shaven.

He believes he is an instinctive actor, untrained he reminds me, who works on the principle that his job is to be unafraid of making a fool of himself. Talking about acting is one of the most boring conversations you can ever have, he adds cautiously. But Bale is big on lack of pretension - and bigger on being seen to be lacking pretension. He is not an actor , he emphasises, as though it's evidence of something unseemly, like ego, or ambition, or consuming passion.

The palaver surrounding the making of the film is well documented: Harron cast Bale, project owners Lion's Gate wanted box office friendly Leo DiCaprio, Harron protested and was replaced by the laughably inappropriate Oliver Stone. Only after DiCaprio bolted to make The Beach did the original team reconvene.

It was an epiphany for Bale. "I wanted to get the film made to keep myself convinced that this was a profession where you could still be an actor. American Psycho became an issue for me of whether I still enjoy doing this craft and being in this business"

webTitle: Join the euro or watch jobs vanish. It's Brown's choice

fields.headline: Join the euro or watch jobs vanish. It's Brown's choice
fields.standfirst:
There's one way to bring sterling down, but the government is wilfully blind

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is in denial. The strength of the pound is the biggest problem facing the British economy, and he refuses to address it.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is in denial. The strength of the pound is the biggest problem facing the British economy, and he refuses to address it.

Yes, there are balancing considerations, to be reflected in today's interest-rate decision by the monetary policy committee. In all economies, the exchange rate is only one of many issues. It happens that at present the exchange rate is the most pressing issue for Britain. The pound is at least 20% over-valued against the market where most British exports go. But the chancellor, fresh from a triumphant Budget which also ignored it, doesn't care to look at it straight on.

He has colleagues whose eyes also sheer away. The speech he gave to the British Chambers of Commerce yesterday was prefigured by the same message to the same audience from the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George. Mr George did at least say he'd like the pound to fall, though he didn't know how it could be done.

Mr Brown is more interested in stressing the merits of non-intervention. Business must simply live with the high pound as a product of stability and a price of sustaining it. Tough potatoes. In the psychology if not the language of Mr Brown, the sounds of therapeutic Thatcherism, defending the industrial destruction of the early 1980s, begin uncomfortably to echo.

He has, of course, a case that's partly irrefutable. The government does have little control. To admit officially that the decimation of Rover had anything to do with the pound would break the market rules which say that politicians opine about currencies at their peril. It cannot be disputed, either, that a lower pound would bring inflationary risks. The hard-won context of stability, avoiding late-Thatcher's boom-and-bust, is enormously worth defending. It shouldn't be jeopardised simply for the sake of saving an industry that has much else going against it as well.

But the risks aren't all on one side. This is becoming more painfully apparent every day. After Rover, we may very well give you Ford at Dagenham. There has already been Harland & Wolff in Belfast. The reasons for investing or locating in Britain, while by no means demolished, begin to be eroded. If the pound makes it impossible to expect maximal exports, why not look elsewhere? No responsible businessman can fail to ask the question. Heavily though politicians deny the pattern of the answers, economic logic, proceeding from the premise that there's nothing to stop the pound staying strong for years, inexorably supplies it.

For the euro, the main competitor currency, will remain weak. Why shouldn't it? The weak euro has been good for the whole of euroland, the centre and the fringes. Business is booming, and a recovery has begun. An economic unit bigger than the US is deploying a lower interest rate strategy behind the same immunities the US enjoys: mainly the fact that, when the vast majority of trade is within the unit, the external exchange rate doesn't matter much. When did the US last have a political convulsion over the weak dollar? If Mr Brown is seriously blaming the British problem on the weak euro, it's to be hoped he's not pinning recovery on a strong one.

British interest rates, in other words, look like indefinitely remaining two points higher than in euroland. A double whammy takes shape. Investment in capital, the key to curing our terrible productivity record - 50% worse than the US, 20% than France, 10% than Germany - remains too expensive to make, while investment in the pound is 2% more attractive than in the euro, which ensures that it will remain a barrier to exports. The current account trade deficit is set to rise from zero to £28bn in two years, while Germany and France move into surplus.

Why are the great men and women who run the British economy so reluctant to look this combination of downside prospects in the eye? The reason is simple. The scenario invites them to consider the policy that has become once again undiscussable in high political circles, the case for joining the euro. That is why the Conservatives are in even more rigorous denial than the chancellor. The opposition, who should be holding the government to account for potentially the most damaging failure of their economic policy, have nothing whatever to say about the high pound, except that it is high.

Short of a total market collapse, a convincing statement that Britain now intended to join the euro has become the only policy likely to bring sterling down. Perceiving that sterling could not enter at its present rate, the markets would assist the lowering of it. Perception is how markets work. But how could they be sure? That is the question. Plainly they do not believe it at the moment, even though entry is the government's stated intention - and was, incidentally, the expectation BMW were entitled to incorporate in their plans for Rover.

It's unlikely that anything will become clearer before the election. That means at least another year of the over-valued, job-destroying pound, and of Mr Brown's evasive silences. What is now harder to obscure, though, is the cost that goes with this.

It may not be dramatic, though the closure of Dagenham would put into the shade the unbearably petty excitement over when Stephen Byers got to know what BMW were playing at. It may not be sudden. It may be deniable, as other reasons are desperately adduced for every exporting setback. But the leeching, draining, life-denying, incremental erosion by sterling will go on, while industry continues to be lectured about a bad productivity record which the exchange rate itself only helps to reinforce.

Hitherto, the economic argument about the euro has focused mainly on the sublime advantages to Britain of economic sovereignty, and the dangerous non-convergence of economic cycles. These points carry weight.

In my opinion, the economic case, considered on its own, is never going to be settled by overwhelming proof one way or the other. But the effects of the strong pound, working against a strengthening European economy based on the weak euro, are beginning to change the argument. They are visible, dangerous, and deniable only by officials and propagandists who have their own reasons for pretending otherwise.

The government have often told us that the only case that will sway them into recommending entry is the satisfaction of its economic tests, to be measured after the election. Politics will not be allowed to intrude. Politics, they say, would warp their judgment of the British national interest.

Yet here we have an economic trend, a negative development of the utmost gravity to investment and jobs, which politics prevents from being addressed. There is a black hole in government policy, shaped by genuine economic tensions - but also by a wilful and craven blindness.

fields.headline: Agency 'too poor' to police regulations
fields.standfirst:
Case study: Undercut waste firm tracks rival's dump trucks

Landfill tax scandal: special report
fields.trailText: When a "muckshifter" lorry left Manchester city centre loaded with contaminated waste, the driver did not know he was being tailed .
fields.body:
When a "muckshifter" lorry left Manchester city centre loaded with contaminated waste, the driver did not know he was being tailed .

The Manchester Tippers lorry headed for Europe's largest shopping centre at Trafford Park, and not to a regulated official site. Under watchful eyes a load of soil polluted with arsenic, lead and various sulphates was disposed of on ground being developed for a golf driving range next to the shopping centre. However, at the site the waste was mixed with soil, thus reducing the pollution level to meet with the standards of the environment agency.

This meant the owners of the waste were not liable to pay a landfill tax. Rules allow waste from designated contaminated sites to escape tax, provided it is disposed of in a safe way - but usually this done at a very high cost to the developer, not at an "unofficial" site.

The designated Great Northern railway warehouse site in Manchester had a tax exemption. Biffa Waste Services tendered for the removal contract and was outbid by Manchester Tippers - which quoted a fifth of the price. Biffa , knowing its costings were sound, decided to investigate. Peter Jones, Biffa's external affairs director, said: "We are talking about potentially polluting materials here - [our bid] is a premium price for what we regard as a premium risk. This is a price-driven market; if [the waste] has not gone to a regulated site, we find out where the stuff does go."

The Trafford Park site was registered as an exempt site for the dumping only of inert, harmless materials. Biffa complained in April 1999 to the environment agency (set up to police dumping of waste) that Manchester Tippers was in breach of the rules.

Surprisingly, the agency replied five weeks later: "The situation has been investigated - the agency is satisfied the arrangements put in place by the developers comply with the requirements of the duty of care legislation."

However in an interview with Channel 4's Dispatches programme, the agency admitted it had no idea what had been dumped at Trafford, having done no tests. "We don't police those sites, we've got no money," an official said. And he accepted borehole tests at the warehouse site showed higher than acceptable contamination that was against regulations.

During these five weeks, however, records kept by Manchester Tippers show 9,902 cubic metres of contaminated waste was moved from the warehouse site to Trafford Park.

Morrisons, the company demolishing the site, and Playgolf, the company developing the range, said they acted properly when the waste was moved. "When it reached Trafford, we carried out twice weekly tests, which suggested contamination below the agency limits. We are satisfied we acted properly," said a joint statement.

Meanwhile the range next to the shopping centre is going ahead - even though the site contains contaminated materials in breach of regulations for exempt sites. The agency said that, as the data it received showed the contamination was not at dangerous levels, it would take no action.

Alastair Hay, an environmental consultant, said: "In reality, what's happening is taking pollution from one site and dispersing it on another. That's not what the agency recommends, and it's not good practice."

webTitle: £1,000 fine is cost of more than £1m profit

fields.headline: £1,000 fine is cost of more than £1m profit
fields.standfirst:
Case study: Woodland for golf course disappears under mound

Landfill tax scandal: special report
fields.trailText: When Joan Rudkin came back from holiday one bright morning and drew the curtains at the Bricket Wood country club in Hertfordshire it was eerily dark. Instead of a view of home counties countryside she was staring at a huge mound of earth, writes David Hencke.
fields.body:
When Joan Rudkin came back from holiday one bright morning and drew the curtains at the Bricket Wood country club in Hertfordshire it was eerily dark. Instead of a view of home counties countryside she was staring at a huge mound of earth, writes David Hencke.

What she saw was one of the most blatant ever exercises in dumping waste and removing topsoil under the auspices of development, estimated to have netted the developer well over £1m profit - at a cost of a £1,000 fine and a 28 day suspended prison sentence. It was also an opportunity for a tax evasion scam by the waste owners.

This scandal centres on the so-called Bricket Wood golf course granted planning permission in 1995 by St Albans district council. The wooded rolling countryside, accommodating a posh nursing home, detached houses and pony clubs, would seem an idyllic location.

But it is close to where the M1 crosses the M25, making it idyllic for heavy lorries from all over the south east to travel to disgorge their waste.

Five years after planning permission was granted, there is still no sign of a golf course; instead there are 23.5 hectares of earth mounds guarded by an old Centurion tank.

What has happened has been a nightmare for residents, for local authorities trying to enforce the laws and for agencies trying to protect the environment.

In 1997, the site owners engaged Ironside Leisure Developments to turn it into a nine hole golf course. Under an exemption the developer had obtained permission to import 41,250 cubic metres of inert, safe waste to build a large mound to shield the golf course from the M25. The rules are very strict: no material bought on to the site can be contaminated or a danger to health.

Ironside quickly went over the 41,250 cubic metre limit: by June 1998 it was 132,700 cu m; and by December 1998 223,000 cu m, more than five times the legal limit.

By then Hertfordshire county council, the environment agency and a private detective company had logged damaging details of the vast scale of the operation. The agency reported that, in one hour on November 12 1997, 20 heavy lorries entered the site; private detectives reported that on a single day at 6am "there would be 10 to 15 queuing to get in". One detective, George Placebo, said: " It seems everyone was getting in on the act of dumping on this site."

More damagingly, one haulier (who was dumping waste and being paid £40-£50,000) tipped off the council. He told officers in December 1998 that "he had seen two to three lorryloads of asbestos sheeting tipped on the site".

The county served numerous enforcement notices, and finally got Ironside Leisure's owner, Harvey Gibson, into court. He was given a 28 day suspended sentence for contempt of court after refusing to remove the waste. The company went into liquidation and the dumping stopped -leaving the many tonnes of waste in place.

Then a new exercise started, the illegal removing of high quality top soil that remained on the site, and its sale to housing developers. fields.headline: Tide of polluted landfill 'beyond control'
fields.standfirst:
3m tonnes of contaminated waste missing as dumpers dodge new tax

Landfill tax scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Millions of tonnes of contaminated waste are being illegally dumped across Britain - on golf courses, farms, beaches and in city centres - to avoid the new landfill tax, an investigation by the Guardian and the Channel 4 programme Dispatches reveals today.
fields.body:
Millions of tonnes of contaminated waste are being illegally dumped across Britain - on golf courses, farms, beaches and in city centres - to avoid the new landfill tax, an investigation by the Guardian and the Channel 4 programme Dispatches reveals today.

The situation has become so bad that the environment agency now admits it has lost control of policing and monitoring one Britain's biggest environmental problems.

Illegal dumping is on such a huge scale that official figures from the Department of the Environment, which claim the landfill tax has led to a 10m tonne drop in officially buried waste, are being challenged by reputable waste companies.

The companies claim that illegal dumping operates on a massive scale, affecting almost every corner of the country.

Peter Jones, a director of Biffa, the waste arm of the Seven Trent water company, told the investigation: "I believe 3m tonnes of material which would otherwise have come to properly controlled and regulated landfill sites has been disposed of as land-raising material at golf courses, retail development parks, sports facilities and even private residential developments."

Companies are allowed by law to dump what are known as "inert materials" - earth and building rubble - on unregulated sites, provided they pose no health risk to humans or animals. Until recently, the environment agency, which is responsible for policing unregulated dumping, believed there were 14,000 such sites in the country. However, a report commissioned from Ecotech, an independent environmental consultancy, to be published this month, will reveal there are now 32,000 such sites - most of which are never checked - in England and Wales alone.

The environment agency admits it has neither the money, resources nor the expertise to ensure that all these sites comply with the law. The agency is only given money to inspect regulated sites - unregulated site inspections are funded from its limited budget.

"We do not have the money", a spokesman told the Guardian and Channel 4.

Councils, which are responsible for giving consent for inert waste to be dumped, admit they are in a similar position.

Roger Hockney, the chair of the waste planning advisory group of the Planning Officers Society, said he had no national picture. "Our group has members representing only 20 different authorities - so there are about 300 other councils we have no information about. From the information we do have, it is clear that there is widespread dumping against the regulations."

Harold Collins, a planning officer for Cheshire county council, and a member of the group said: " Often the first indication of something going wrong is when a resident rings up to say a cricket pitch has risen 10 feet overnight."

Information gathered in Cheshire has revealed three golf courses - at Mollington, Capenhurst and Hankerlow - where illegal dumping has taken place. At Hankerlow 500,000 cubic metres of waste were dumped when planning permission was given for only 80,000 cubic metres.

Other golf courses where waste was dumped include the former municipal course in Sunderland; Hinksey Heights near Oxford and Waterstock in Oxfordshire. Altogether 30 golf courses are under investigation for illegal dumping.

A similar picture emerges of illegal dumping on farms. In Cornwall, 120 suspected illegal sites are under environment agency investigation. In Hertfordshire, at Valley View farm, near South Oxhey the agency is planning to prosecute 240 hauliers after they discovered hospital and household waste had been dumped to a height of 40 feet. The county council tried to stop the dumping by blocking an access road - but the lorries smashed though a barrier to continue their work.

Enforcement is a big problem. Hertfordshire, which has pursued two illegal dumpers - at Bricket Wood, near St Albans and Valley View farm - says the penalties are too low to be effective. When enforcement orders are made they are often ignored until expensive court procedures have been exhaustively followed. On conviction, magistrates can fine people up to £20,000, but most fines are about £1,000, which is no deterrent.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, was challenged on Dispatches to act on the problem - particularly the environment agency's inability to police dumps because of a lack of cash.

"Those who have the advantage of the exemption [from using regulated sites] certainly ought to pay the costs of the agency to ensure that a sufficient sample of sites can be properly inspected. That is one of the changes that we will look at very carefully," he said.

No moves are in hand to increase fines or use to customs and excise powers to pounce on firms that evade landfill tax.

Mr Jones from Biffa said: "There should be tougher fines for illegal dumpers. If firms have to lose a huge amount of their turnover for breaching the law, that would be a real deterrent to stop this - £1,000 fines mean nothing."

webTitle: Millions dig in as cyclone hits coast

fields.headline: Millions dig in as cyclone hits coast
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: Cyclone Hudah lashed the Mozambique coast with driving rain and high winds yesterday as residents were kept guessing where and when it would come ashore.
fields.body:
Cyclone Hudah lashed the Mozambique coast with driving rain and high winds yesterday as residents were kept guessing where and when it would come ashore.

Meteorologists said the cyclone strengthened overnight as it crossed the Mozambique channel after battering Madagascar, where it killed at least 27 people and left about 100,000 homeless.

Hudah veered south shortly before reaching the coast in northern Mozambique. Officials believe the cyclone's impact on the country will not be catastrophic if it keeps running along the coast or comes ashore in the north, which has escaped the worst of the floods that devastated other regions.

But if the cyclone were to dump large amounts of rain on areas already flooded, or to move inland in the area of the Limpopo and Incomati rivers, then a new crisis could be brewing.

United Nations workers in Nampula province said the heavy winds and rains had destroyed traditional mud and wood homes on the coast, but the damage was still being assessed.

"It's basically a wait-and-see situation," said Ian Macleod of the UN's children's agency, Unicef. "We do not expect people will need to be rescued, but strong winds could destroy a lot of homes. Shelter is expected to be the immediate concern."

The government has issued warnings on state radio telling several million people who may be in the path of the cyclone to stay at home or to seek out brick buildings, to stay away from power lines and to make sure that their food and farm implements are protected.

The UN and aid agencies say they do not expect a repeat of the extensive flooding that hit large parts of central and southern Mozambique in February, claiming at least 800 lives and driving hundreds of thousands from their homes. But they do not rule out the possibility.

In Madagascar, the UN said Hudah destroyed a town and much of the world's vanilla capital, Antalaha.

webTitle: British chief who was eased out is ready to return

fields.headline: British chief who was eased out is ready to return
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Four years ago John Towers quit as chief executive of the Rover group, furious at the way it was being run by its new owner BMW.
fields.body:
Four years ago John Towers quit as chief executive of the Rover group, furious at the way it was being run by its new owner BMW.

His resignation was interpreted as an early sign that BMW might be losing patience with the pace of progress at its £800m acquisition, and it swiftly brought in a relatively unknown executive of its own, Walter Hasselkus.

The official line from the German company was that it knew Mr Towers would be leaving from the moment it bought Rover, claiming he had always wanted to move on and had only gone after its takeover had bedded in.

BMW insisted that it intended to continue to invest in Rover, spending about £500m a year to maintain its British identity and boost output.

Yet BMW's stance in the months leading up to his departure painted a different story, as it allowed its dissatisfaction over Rover's financial performance to leak into the public domain.

Mr Towers, who joined Rover six years before the takeover, was excluded from negotiations for the sale of the company, and privately expressed doubts about it. When he went, he was the last of the senior British executives to have been in place before the takeover. The £400,000 payoff he received for leaving his £300,000-a-year post no doubt sweetened the departure, but his potential return at Rover's darkest hour speaks volumes for his feelings for the company.

He is understood to have been none too happy with the idea of BMW ownership from the start, taking the view it was always bound to put Rover at a disadvantage when there was competition for resources. At the time of the BMW purchase competition had become intense, due to the sluggish fortunes of the European economy, and the situation served to fuel his misgivings.

For those outside the new BMW management clique, the view was that Mr Towers was deeply unhappy about the loss of Rovers' links with Honda, which he had personally nursed during the six years before BMW's intervention.

Mr Towers believed Honda had helped to turn Rover around from its lowest point, and felt that the Japanese partner was wrongly treated in the change of ownership.

As one senior manager for a rival firm said at the time: "John is an individual who needs his space as a chief executive. There have been signs that his space has been progressively moved into by others. When he took on the role, he didn't do it to be managing director of a subsidiary of a foreign company."

Now the 52-year-old, who received a CBE for his services to the motor industry, is ready to return to the company as part of a broad-based consortium hoping to salvage mass car production at Longbridge.

Since his resignation Mr Towers has found extra time to brush up his golf skills. At the 1995 Geneva motorshow he was asked if people would be able to fit a golf bag into the boot of the new MG-F. "Yes, but not mine," he answered.

While not on the links he has been working for a relatively small Midlands engineering company, Concentric.

When he joined the company, its shares jumped nearly 20%. He can only hope the workers of Longbridge will welcome him back with similar enthusiasm.

Mr Towers is known to be a personal friend of the trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, and the embattled politician will certainly be hoping he can pull something out of the bag.
