fields.headline: BMW deception 'proved by leak'
fields.standfirst:
Rover crisis: Unions claim memo is evidence that Germans deliberately misled Byers as embattled minister fights for his political life

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Rover unions last night made public a BMW memorandum that, just weeks before the German car manufacturer decided to ditch Longbridge, declared its "total commitment" to the factory. The leak came as the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, faced further calls for his resignation.
fields.body:
Rover unions last night made public a BMW memorandum that, just weeks before the German car manufacturer decided to ditch Longbridge, declared its "total commitment" to the factory. The leak came as the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, faced further calls for his resignation.

Mr Byers insisted yesterday he had been given "no hint" from BMW that it was to sell Rover, despite a warning by the company last month that it was considering cutting 8,000 jobs.

Unions released an internal BMW note to British staff officially denying reports it intended to sell Rover and the West Midlands site. The memo, given a high priority "amber" status, was sent out to all 18,000 employees on February 14 to scotch rumours that Longbridge was doomed.

It stated: "BMW's commitment to Rover and to the plant in Birmingham remains total, and we are pressing for an early decision on state aid so that the new medium car programme can be implemented and the £1.5bn transformation can get under way."

The letter was seized on by union officials and by Mr Byers as proof that the Munich firm had deceived the government and the Rover workforce. Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU engineering union, said: "The whole of the West Midlands will be shocked to learn that the workforce was assured their jobs were safe at a time when they were in fact up for sale. BMW will be under increased pressure to work with the unions to find an alternative buyer and, if necessary, to regenerate the West Midlands."

Minutes of private conversations on March 10 between Mr Byers and the Rover chairman, Werner Sämann, disclosed yesterday, show that BMW made clear it was in "survival mode" with losses of £2m a day at Rover, and that it must recoup £800m losses. In a two-hour grilling by the Commons trade and industry select committee, however, the trade secretary said he had trusted BMW to implement a rescue plan outlined at the meeting, which was less than a week before the sell-off was announced.

Tory committee member Tony Baldry said later: "It beggars belief that if you are told by a leading employer they are going to have to invoke fairly nuclear options, including large job losses, that you as secretary of state do nothing."

The row over the government's handling of the crisis blew up again at prime minister's questions in the Commons, when William Hague called for a new trade secretary. Challenged to back Mr Byers, Tony Blair answered "Of course I do". Labour MPs believe Mr Byers's job is safe, but he is seen to have suffered longer term damage.

There was some support for his insistence that BMW had "played its cards very close to its chest" even at the 11th hour, when it emerged that BMW's memo was deceiving Rover workers by declaring its "total" commitment to Longbridge, months after entering negotiations with venture capitalists to sell the factory. BMW's decision to hand Longbridge to Alchemy leaked out on March 13 and was formally agreed by its supervisory board on March 16. Alchemy's offshoot, the MG Car Company, is expected to sack up to three-quarters of Longbridge's 8,500 workers and to pull out of mass production.

Minutes of the March 10 meeting with Rover at Mr Byers's offices revealed to the committee that even the rescue plan would have included job losses at Rover and at its UK suppliers. But Mr Byers, appearing alone before the committee, said: "We were not given information that BMW were considering breaking up Rover and selling Longbridge."

He said he had no recollection of remarks, said by BMW to have been made by Prof Sämann, that the clock was standing at "five minutes to 12", later interpreted as a clear warning that drastic action was about to be taken.

webTitle: Loyal high-flyer left to take the flak keeps cool under fire

fields.headline: Loyal high-flyer left to take the flak keeps cool under fire
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Appearing before the trade and industry select committee yesterday, Stephen Byers kept his cool during two hours of close questioning over what he knew and when of the fate of the Rover car plant at Longbridge. He met each MP's gaze and answered calmly, sipping occasionally from a glass of mineral water. And yet, sandwiched between a semi-circle of interrogators and a crush of reporters, civil servants, political opponents and a handful of German observers, he looked very much alone.

He met each MP's gaze and answered calmly, sipping occasionally from a glass of mineral water. And yet, sandwiched between a semi-circle of interrogators and a crush of reporters, civil servants, political opponents and a handful of German observers, he looked very much alone.

For all his well-known loyalty to his leader and swift rise to cabinet rank, the trade secretary is being left to take the full force of the flak over the Rover sell-off and consequent thousands of job losses in the West Midlands and elsewhere.

Yesterday he lacked even the comfort of officials alongside him to absorb some of the fire, and was forced to rebut accusations that he and his department should have identified the scale of BMW's plans more quickly and reacted accordingly.

At question time in the Commons Tony Blair came to his defence as the Tories once more demanded the trade secretary's scalp, but the vote of confidence did not have quite the ring of enthusiasm Mr Byers might have hoped.

The bleakest fortnight so far for the trade secretary looks all the worse in the context of his steady promotion. Famously, he transformed himself from a scruffy leftwing councillor from north-east England with an ill-advised moustache, to a smartly-suited moderniser, efficient, trustworthy and with more than a touch of the bureaucrat about him.

Vying with his contemporary, fellow north-easterner and moderniser Alan Milburn, for promotion, he skipped early from education into the cabinet as chief secretary to the Treasury (150 days ahead of his rival), moving into the DTI slot in December 1998 after Peter Mandelson's downfall.

Labour MPs monitoring Mr Byers's progress agree that things have begun to fall apart this year precisely because of the scale of his good fortune so far. One said: "Byers, and Milburn too, are both going to be done in, make no mistake. They played along with a very, very dangerous game and they are reaping the effects of that."

All the talk of the pair's role as the next Blair and Brown has ultimately led knives to be sharpened at the very top of the party, MPs say.

While Milburn has seen his health portfolio somewhat usurped as the prime minister seizes "personal responsibility" for the area, Byers is perceived to have suffered the greater backlash. The source of a series of unfavourable stories against him in recent months, observers agree, is not far from number 11 Downing Street, where the chancellor is said to be keen to ensure the trade secretary does not get above himself.

"Byers did not speak in the budget debate and that was down to Gordon," said one MP sympathetic to the trade secretary. "There have been one or two little things coming from Gordon's side, and it is all because Byers is viewed as one of the heirs."

"I would not be putting too much money on the long-term future of these guys," said a generally loyal MP, referring to both Byers and Milburn.

Most, however, have less harsh predictions. The trade secretary's job is secure at present - not least because the Conservatives have failed to target their attacks with precision.

Rover's demise has been a bleak chapter for Stephen Byers and one which will scar him, even if ultimately it does no more than slow or perhaps level off his ascent through the government ranks. Only if there are more such disasters in British manufacturing - if Ford's Dagenham plant, for example, were to be hit - would his fate look permanently grim.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe faces state of emergency
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The prospect of a state of emergency looms over Zimbabwe as President Robert Mugabe's government threatens sweeping action in response to the upsurge of politically motivated violence across the country.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  and Cris Chinaka  in Harare
fields.body:
The prospect of a state of emergency looms over Zimbabwe as President Robert Mugabe's government threatens sweeping action in response to the upsurge of politically motivated violence across the country.

Opposition leaders and white farmers yesterday reported a wave of arson attacks and assaults by supporters of Mr Mugabe, pushing the country closer to the brink of anarchy.

The minister of home affairs, Dumiso Dabengwa, said yesterday that he is "urgently considering various strict measures to deal with public demonstrations until the completion of elections".

Eight policemen were ambushed late on Tuesday and had their automatic rifles taken when they tried to investigate a reported assault on a farm northeast of the capital.

The sources said the policemen were being held hostage by war veterans who had occupied the farm.

"Although the farmer is being allowed to move around with his family, the atmosphere is very intimidating," a farm community source told Reuters.

The opposition Movement for Democratic Change said a candidate in the parliamentary election, Biggie Chigovera, had his home burned in a fire-bomb attack early yesterday.

In almost all the violent incidents in recent days the instigators have been Zanu-PF supporters. Yet Mr Dabengwa blamed the MDC for the violence. He said it had "worked out a strategy to create anarchy in the country to force the government to cancel the forthcoming elections", according to the state-run Herald newspaper. Mr Dabengwa said the government would take all necessary action to foil the strategy.

"The Mugabe government is frightened by the groundswell of support for the opposition. The government is creating a climate of violence in the country and then blaming the opposition for the violence," said John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe. "I think they are creating this atmosphere of violence in order to justify imposing a state of emergency in the country."

Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the MDC, warned that the government is planning to increase its oppression against his party and other opposition groups.

"A chronology of violence has been perpetrated by the state against the MDC," said Mr Tsvangirai. "It is ghastly. It is like infanticide against our young party. The government is working to induce fear and intimidation across the country. But elections cannot be won on a basis of intimidation."

Mr Tsvangirai said the imposition of a state of emergency was "a possibility but not a probability. This country cannot afford not have democratic elections. The situation is very tense, it is risky for the opposition. But there can be no reversal of the transition to a new government that is already taking place."

Mr Tsvangirai said the government "has no option but to go forwards and restore order in the country. It must carry out elections which they know they will lose."

He criticised Mr Mugabe for trying to divide Zimbabwe along racial lines. "Mugabe wants to use the race card and to win support by attacking whites. But race relations are good. The blacks and whites of this country have never been as united as we are now in standing against Zanu-PF. In the past 100 years we have never achieved such harmony."

Mr Mugabe's government yesterday continued to rush through parliament a constitutional amendment which will give it power to seize land without paying. It is expected to be given its third reading today before being signed by Mr Mugabe.

The minister of justice, Emmerson Mnangagwa, introduced the amendment to parliament, saying "we now must grant unto ourselves the right to acquire land unfettered with colonial laws which require compensation to be paid for stolen land." The amendment, the 16th enacted since 1980, states that if Britain does not pay compensation for land acquired for resettlement the government would be under no obligation to do so.

Mr Mnangagwa said: "the current Labour government has reneged on the issue of paying compensation on land acquired for resettlement."

The Blair government has stated repeatedly that it will fund land redistribution in Zimbabwe, so long as it is designed to reduce rural poverty and is open and transparent.

 Mr Mugabe cannot stand the sight of the British foreign office minister Peter Hain, the official Zimbabwe news agency reported yesterday.

Mr Mugabe, returning from the two-day Africa-Europe summit in Egypt, said: "I insisted that the meeting with [foreign secretary Robin] Cook would not include Peter Hain as I do no want to have sight of him. [He] has already predicted we are going to rig the elections. I told Cook we have never rigged elections."

 Cris Chinaka is a Reuters correspondent

fields.headline: Banking without Barclays
fields.standfirst:
Abandoned rural communities could be revived by credit unions

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The decision by Barclays Bank to close nearly 100 small local banks is, in one way, nothing very new. Barclays is not the first, or the only, high-street bank to be cutting back on unproductive outlets, and it would be unfair to single them out for special reproach. But this move brings into dramatically clear focus one of the barely noticed areas of social blight in Britain over recent years.
fields.body:
The decision by Barclays Bank to close nearly 100 small local banks is, in one way, nothing very new. Barclays is not the first, or the only, high-street bank to be cutting back on unproductive outlets, and it would be unfair to single them out for special reproach. But this move brings into dramatically clear focus one of the barely noticed areas of social blight in Britain over recent years.

The economic arguments are, as usual, powerful. As someone professionally involved with issues concerning the maintenance of costly and under-used premises in thinly populated regions, I feel a twinge of wry sympathy. But - just as with small rural churches - some kinds of premises have more significance than a straight cost benefit analysis immediately shows up.

A healthy local economy, the small-scale economy of a village or a council estate, relies on dependable, accessible and relatively cheap credit. For the vast numbers of people who are elderly, poor, frightened of figures, frightened of institutions or of correspondence, the local bank still provides something impossible to replace.

I have watched what this means in recent years as my own parents struggled to make sense of their finances as these were drained away in the expenses of daycare and related matters. I had good reason to thank a local branch of Barclays for their patience and availability. But the same holds for the young lone parent on the estate or the unemployed single man of 45. These are people who are going to have little or no chance to find their way into electronic banking.

The closure of the local bank also spells disaster for small business. It is a signal that, financially speaking, the evacuation helicopters have arrived. It is commonly the beginning of, or an intensification of, a permanent shift in shopping habits. For the not very mobile, it aggravates some of the problems of household management.

It sends out the message that this community is not worth investing in, in any sense. And whether we are thinking about a smallish town in the countryside or a self-contained council estate on the edge of a conurbation, or a post-industrial village in the South Wales valleys, the message that you're not worth investing in is being heard so frequently and clearly that this further underlining of it can be a death-knell to hopes of a revived local confidence and enterprise.

Given the severity of the situation in the countryside as far as low morale is concerned, and the acute problems of the sink estates, it's not a good time to make credit less accessible. One unwelcome effect may be to raise the unpleasant profile of the kind of loan company that can successfully seal the poverty trap for good.

It's a bit utopian to imagine that government can intervene to make the banks behave. More to the point, we might ask what more government might do to encourage different sorts of credit arrangement.

The credit union movement is one of our unsung treasures. Developing the provision of local small-scale credit, in a way that fosters saving habits, promotes professional confidence and self-reliance among people with little economic power in the usual style and offers a way out of the debt trap, is surely one of the most potent tools we could have in the regeneration of communities.

There are signs that government is interested in loosening up some of the rules under which credit unions operate, so that, for example, they can do more with the launching of small businesses. Is there more to be done here?

The cooperative principles on which the movement is based don't immediately sound very New Labour; but the emphasis on cultivating a proper confidence in your own skill and dignity ought to ring a few bells in Westminster. Is the government interested in making more money available for training in micro-credit skills of this sort? In identifying regions where this is going to be needed more and more urgently as banks withdraw?

A social investment of this sort creates people who themselves have an investment in "sociality", in cooperation and the recognition and nurturing of self-reliance at the same time. It's an investment well worth while in the formation of a society of people who have a stake in the health of their environment, economic, personal and material.

Substantial areas of rural Canada and Ireland use the credit union system as their major banking method - not just because it avoids problems or deals with crises, but because it is socially constructive and personally positive. If we really are faced with irreversible trends in the policy of the high-street banks, perhaps we should think of what would be involved in developing the shop-front bank - and the personal skills that go with it.

 Rowan Williams is Archbishop of Wales

fields.headline: Ethics body backs cloning move
fields.standfirst:
Report seeks legalisation of embryo research to tackle disease

Gene patenting: special report
Chief Medical Officer on cloning
fields.trailText: Therapeutic cloning in the UK came a step closer yesterday with the publication of a paper from a leading medical ethics body which urged that such embryo research should be legalised in the quest to grow human tissue for transplants and find new treatments for disease.
fields.body:
Therapeutic cloning in the UK came a step closer yesterday with the publication of a paper from a leading medical ethics body which urged that such embryo research should be legalised in the quest to grow human tissue for transplants and find new treatments for disease.

The authoritative Nuffield Council on Bioethics published a paper that is likely to be highly influential on the thinking of the government's expert working group on therapeutic cloning.

The expert group, chaired by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, is expected to rule in favour of cloning for therapeutic purposes when it reports in a few weeks' time.

The Donaldson committee was set up last summer after the government outlawed cloning for the purposes of reproducing a human being. But the Department of Health postponed a decision on the cloning of embryos to obtain stem cells - the earliest, basic cells created by the division of the fertilised egg.

These have the potential to grow into any part of the human body, such as muscle, heart or nerves.

A draft of the paper on stem cell research released yesterday by the Nuffield Council was submitted to the Donaldson committee in November. It looks at a number of methods of obtaining stem cells and concludes that it is ethically acceptable to take them from either donated embryos or embryos cloned by replacing the nucleus of an egg with DNA from a patient.

Such research "does not indicate lack of respect for the embryo", says the paper, adding that the embryo is not destined to become a human being and would otherwise perish.

Sandy Thomas, director of the council, said yesterday that it was possible that growing tissue from an embryo cloned from a transplant patient might be the most useful way forward because it would provide an exact match.

"Some researchers believe it holds the most promise," she said. "If it works, it would get around the whole problem of graft rejection."

There was little doubt within the scientific community that this sort of research should be permitted, Dr Thomas said. "There is a lot of support among scientists who are involved in this work."

In theory, stem cells could be used not only to grow new hearts but also - and probably sooner - to develop therapies for debilitating diseases such as Parkinson's, stroke and rheumatoid arthritis, by regenerating cell growth in damaged areas. Cells from aborted foetuses have already been implanted in the brains of people with Parkinson's disease.

The council says there should be no need to create embryos for research purposes. Women who undergo fertility treatment are asked if they want to donate unused embryos to science, but under the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act those embryos can only be used for research into fertility problems and congenital disease.

The council recommends that the act be amended to allow these embryos to be used in stem cell research. "We consider that the proposed creation of embryos using SCNT [somatic cell nuclear transfer, or cloning] for research into the derivation of stem cells offers such significant potential medical benefits that research for such purposes should be licensed," the paper says.

But there is a caveat. Women who donate embryos must give consent for their use in stem cell research, the council insists, because the DNA in the material could be traced back to donors.

Dr Thomas said a lot more research into stem cell therapies was needed. She hoped the government would give serious consideration to changing the law.

webTitle: Yeltsin collects pension, on time and with perks

fields.headline: Yeltsin collects pension, on time and with perks
fields.trailText: Russia's former president, Boris Yeltsin, was formally pensioned off yesterday when he received a plastic senior citizen card at an official presentation just outside Moscow.
fields.body:
Russia's former president, Boris Yeltsin, was formally pensioned off yesterday when he received a plastic senior citizen card at an official presentation just outside Moscow.

In a moment of supreme irony, the head of Russia's pension body assured Mr Yeltsin that his pension would be paid on time. It was a barbed pledge, given that severe delays in the payment of benefits to millions of Russian pensioners during Mr Yeltsin's presidency caused his popularity to plummet.

As he handed Mr Yeltsin his documents, Mikhail Zurabov said that he thought Russia's current government would "not be ashamed over any delays with pension payments like those that existed in the past".

"We will confidently pay pensions to all retired people - including you," he said.

Mr Yeltsin, 69, dressed casually in a zip-up jacket, looked healthier than usual, if extremely stout. Accepting the documents with a smile, apparently oblivious to any affront - intended or otherwise - he said: "Even in this post as a pensioner, I will serve Russia."

After a moment's pause, he added in his customary growling slur: "With as much strength as I've got."

During his 1996 campaign for presidency, Mr Yeltsin repeatedly promised Russia's impoverished pensioners that he would ensure that their pensions were paid on time. But after his re-election, severe delays in payment persisted, with hundreds of thousands of former state workers receiving their money months late and struggling to survive.

The exact level of the former president's pension was not revealed yesterday - but there was no doubt that it would be considerably higher than the average monthly pension of around 400 roubles (£8.70) paid to Russian citizens.

Very soon after Mr Yeltsin's resignation on New Year's Eve, his newly appointed successor Vladimir Putin signed a decree ensuring that his predecessor would have no concerns, financial or otherwise, during his retirement.

As well as giving him immunity from prosecution, Mr Putin set Mr Yeltsin's pension at 75% of his presidential salary, granted him the use of one of the state-owned country residences for life, special medical care and personal bodyguards, and allowed him to finance a team of aides out of the government budget.

Mr Yeltsin - who insists on being referred to as Russia's first president instead of former president - has remained largely out of public view since his retirement.

As he handed Mr Yeltsin his documents, Mikhail Zurabov said that he thought Russia's current government would "not be ashamed over any delays with pension payments like those that existed in the past". "We will confidently pay pensions to all retired people - including you," he said. Mr Yeltsin, 69, dressed casually in a zip-up jacket, looked healthier than usual, if extremely stout. Accepting the documents with a smile, apparently oblivious to any affront - intended or otherwise - he said: "Even in this post as a pensioner, I will serve Russia." After a moment's pause, he added in his customary growling slur: "With as much strength as I've got." During his 1996 campaign for presidency, Mr Yeltsin repeatedly promised Russia's impoverished pensioners that he would ensure that their pensions were paid on time. But after his re-election, severe delays in payment persisted, with hundreds of thousands of former state workers receiving their money months late and struggling to survive. The exact level of the former president's pension was not revealed yesterday - but there was no doubt that it would be considerably higher than the average monthly pension of around 400 roubles (£8.70) paid to Russian citizens. Very soon after Mr Yeltsin's resignation on New Year's Eve, his newly appointed successor Vladimir Putin signed a decree ensuring that his predecessor would have no concerns, financial or otherwise, during his retirement. As well as giving him immunity from prosecution, Mr Putin set Mr Yeltsin's pension at 75% of his presidential salary, granted him the use of one of the state-owned country residences for life, special medical care and personal bodyguards, and allowed him to finance a team of aides out of the government budget. Mr Yeltsin - who insists on being referred to as Russia's first president instead of former president - has remained largely out of public view since his retirement.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Nothing is more important than learning from our mistakes, and Mr Tony would agree that after the Welsh and London fiascos the last thing New Labour needs is further embarrassment with an internal election. And so to Birmingham, where Raghib Ahsan wishes to stand alongside Mark Seddon and the usual leftie suspects for the Grassroots Alliance at this year's NEC election. That's what he wants. What Millbank and the Birmingham party (which he is suing for racial discrimination, after being removed as a councillor) want is something else.
fields.body:
Nothing is more important than learning from our mistakes, and Mr Tony would agree that after the Welsh and London fiascos the last thing New Labour needs is further embarrassment with an internal election. And so to Birmingham, where Raghib Ahsan wishes to stand alongside Mark Seddon and the usual leftie suspects for the Grassroots Alliance at this year's NEC election. That's what he wants. What Millbank and the Birmingham party (which he is suing for racial discrimination, after being removed as a councillor) want is something else.

Although Raghib's nomination went through the Perry Barr general committee earlier this year, as required, the new local secretary passed it to West Midlands officials. They in turn are hanging on to it, and unless it reaches Millbank tomorrow, Raghib will be too late to enter. West Midlands regional secretary Fiona Gordon claims the nomination is invalid because the meeting was "inquorate", while friends of Birmingham organiser Ron Stevenson are worried he'll be "dead meat" if Raghib's nomination goes through. Will they never learn, eh? Will they never bleedin' learn?

David Blunkett seemed to enjoy his outing yesterday to the British Chambers of Commerce conference. While the education secretary was there the business people were ballotted on their preferences for London mayor, and Ken and Shagger all but dead-heated (with 42% and 41% respectively) while dear old Dobbo puffed in last with 4%. "It's nice to see Old Labour lives on in the BCC," observed a smiling David when he took the podium. "And I think that's all I better say."

With William Hague calling for his sacking, what better day for Stephen Byers to underline his competence by publishing civil service notes on his conversation with BMW management on March 10. "If the D-Mark increases in value," said Steve, "this may lead to a strengthening of the euro." Ah, the depth of his mind - and yet one tiny correction: the D-Mark is subsumed into a single currency known as the euro, and can't therefore go up or down by itself. I know it's obtuse, even pedantic, but perhaps Steve could brush up a bit on the theoretical side (it was he who once calculated seven times eight as 52). To this end, we will ask the FT's Sir Samuel Brittan, the doyen of financial journalists, to give Steve an economics masterclass through the Diary.

Speaking of which, I am delighted to announce that the Diary is close to clinching a new car sponsorship deal with Steve's old pals at BMW. Barring disaster, an M Roadster will shortly take its place in succession to the Beetle lent to us (by delightful and sweet-natured VW press officer Kate Thomson), and will receive the usual succession of gratuitous plugs of the kind inconceivable in all but the most corrupt column in Fleet Street history (and no, City Slickers, I haven't forgotten you).

While the Diary contemplates how best to pray for my friend Jonathan Aitken (we will ask God to show Jonathan how to pray for me), news arrives of what may prove a useful interim measure. CAAT (campaign against the arms trade) announces that on June 18 it will be holding a Christian Network day of prayer. "The focus of the day is to pray for those who are involved in the arms trade, that they may consider the consequences of their business." Among those people we will be asked specifically to pray for is not, oddly, Jonathan, but Mr Tony Blair "who in January called for the new millennium to be an age of faith and values, but then lifted the arms embargo on Indonesia".

Everyone knows that Mr T was offering a peerage to anyone without a criminal record who would pretend to be a New Labour convert - but can it be true an approach was made to as confirmed a semi-Thatcherite free marketeer as Sir Jocelyn Stevens?

fields.headline: Zurich spends $1bn to reach 100m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: One of Europe's largest insurance groups, Zurich Financial Services, yesterday pledged a radical overhaul of its business strategy - focused on a $1bn (£627m) expansion of its e-commerce business over the next three years.
fields.body:
One of Europe's largest insurance groups, Zurich Financial Services, yesterday pledged a radical overhaul of its business strategy - focused on a $1bn (£627m) expansion of its e-commerce business over the next three years.

The group, which spans from Eagle Star and Allied Dunbar in Britain to Farmers in the United States, said it was looking to reach 100m customers - almost three times as many as it has at present - through the expansion of the internet operation. Zurich is also looking to increase the number of products it sells to individual customers from an average of 1.8 now to four.

The move will mean substantial reshaping as Zurich opens up its web sites to other companies' products, beginning with fund management.

"The opportunities offered by the internet will enable Zurich to develop entirely new business models involving the formation of a network of partnerships and alliances. We will separate marketing from production, re-shape our processes and cut costs," chairman and chief executive Rolf Hüppi said yesterday.

The group plans to extend the geographical coverage of its online banking operations and to expand them to include internet brokerage services. Clients would be offered customised web pages with de tails of their policies, investments, bank statements as well as related news and direct broker access.

At present 47% of transactions at the group's US investment manager Scudder Kemper are carried out over the internet. In Britain, 11% of Eagle Star's business is carried out electronically.

Sandy Leitch, chief executive of Zurich's operations in Britain, Ireland and South Africa, said the group was learning from its internet ex perience in the US, which was probably two or three years ahead. "We are taking that experience and applying it in the UK. We are not having to relearn everything. This is the advantage of being a global player."

Allied Dunbar allows customers to track their mortgage application via the web while Eagle Star offers home and motor insurance online. "We now have something like 50 online initiatives in e-commerce in the UK," Mr Leitch said. The scale of Zurich's planned investment is expected to increase the pressure on other financial services providers. With $1bn to spend, Zurich's e-commerce operation is thought to be equal to the combined spending of Britain's three largest insurers.

Zurich acknowledged that in the short run, the scale of its spending on developing e-commerce initiatives could have an impact on profits.

The investment programme might "cause profit growth in the short term to be less than it would have been otherwise," said Mr Hüppi but added that "we will maintain our ambitious targets."

The expenditure was needed to enable Zurich to remain at the top of the industry. "It is an aggressive step forward."

The new e-strategy came alongside full-year figures from the group which showed pre-tax operating income rising by 21.5% to $5.34bn while net income was up by 15.9% to a record $3.26bn.

webTitle: US man arrested in Moscow on spying charges

fields.headline: US man arrested in Moscow on spying charges
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Western hopes of establishing a working relationship with the new Russian president Vladimir Putin suffered an early setback yesterday when a US businessman was arrested in Moscow accused of spying.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Moscow and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
Western hopes of establishing a working relationship with the new Russian president Vladimir Putin suffered an early setback yesterday when a US businessman was arrested in Moscow accused of spying.

The detention by the federal security service FSB came three weeks after a Russian was held on suspicion of spying for Britain. The move appears to be part of a campaign against western intelligence services by Mr Putin, who is a former KGB career officer and, until last summer, headed the FSB.

The Russians said the unnamed American was a former career intelligence agent who was now the director of a private company. He had been seeking information about Russia's defence industries, paying Russian scientists for the material, the FSB said. A Russian defence expert, alleged to have passed state secrets to him, was also detained. A large sum in foreign currency was allegedly found on the Russian.

"Materials that have been obtained in the course of searches and investigations provide direct evidence that the foreigner has been making contacts, methodically and for a long time, with Russian scientists in Moscow, Novosibirsk, and other cities with the aim of collecting information that constitutes Russian state secrets," a statement said.

It said a large quantity of documents had been confiscated which were "evidence that he has been engaged in illegal activities", together with "records of conversations between him and Russian citizens which deal with their work in the national defence industry, as well as receipts for money they received".

In Washington, the state department spokesman, James Rubin, said no formal charges against the American had yet been made. The man had been visited by a US embassy consular representative in Moscow. He appeared to be in good health and made no complaints of mistreatment. "He indicated that he expects this matter to be resolved in a short time," Mr Rubin said.

The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said the Clinton administration was in touch with the man's family, but refused to identify him or say whether he was working for a US agency. "I understand he was in Moscow on business," Mr Lockhart said.

Last December a diplomat at the US embassy in Moscow, Cheri Leberknight, was expelled from Russia after the FSB said it had caught her seeking military secrets from a Russian. The US expelled a Russian diplomat a little later for bugging the state department.

In a case the Russian media described as the start of a new spy war between Russia and Britain, Moscow last month announced the arrest on treason charges of a former Russian intelligence officer who was said to have been recruited by an MI6 agent in Tallinn, capital of the former Soviet Baltic state of Estonia.

fields.headline: Vote for suspension
fields.standfirst:
The west has been lax over Chechnya

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Council of Europe will decide today whether to suspend Russia because of its conduct in Chechnya. It must not hesitate. The 41-nation council, whose proudest achievement is the European convention on human rights, has a rare chance to strike a blow for common decency. By taking a stand, it will give vicarious expression to the real disgust felt in Europe at how Vladimir Putin, trading blood for votes, equated election campaigning with military conquest
fields.body:
The Council of Europe will decide today whether to suspend Russia because of its conduct in Chechnya. It must not hesitate. The 41-nation council, whose proudest achievement is the European convention on human rights, has a rare chance to strike a blow for common decency. By taking a stand, it will give vicarious expression to the real disgust felt in Europe at how Vladimir Putin, trading blood for votes, equated election campaigning with military conquest. By its symbolic action, the council can show that the thousands of Chechen dead are not forgotten. By punishing Russia, however mildly, it will put to shame those European leaders who have appeased Moscow's new man; the terrible twins of EU foreign policy, Chris Patten and Javier Solana, who shuttled and waffled and did diddly-squat; the grand-sounding, ineffectual Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, bamboozled by Boris Yeltsin in Istanbul last November; and the Clinton administration, which has done for Chechnya what Roosevelt and Churchill did for Poland.

Lack of respect for human rights is a longstanding Russian government tradition. Not much effort is needed to recall the eras of Sakharov, Bonner and Andropov; of Stalin's deportations and purges; of the terrors inflicted by Beria's NKVD and its Tsarist predecessors. In their disdainful treatment in Moscow this week of the valiant Mary Robinson, the UN's human rights chief, the supposedly modernising Mr Putin and his sharp-suited cronies showed how little they understand (or care about) the way expectations and responsibilities have changed since then. Mrs Robinson, backed by Kofi Annan, demands an independent commission of investigation in Chechnya. The Council of Europe wants an inquiry, too, plus a ceasefire and peace talks, all to be under way by June 1. This is reasonable. But Mr Putin, emboldened by victory, believes more than ever that he can bluff, block, bluster, fib and finagle his way out of his fix, whatever the outside world may say.

He may be right. For no mechanism exists for a thorough international probe of the Chechnya bloodbath without Russia's agreement. One is planned. The UN international criminal court, launched in Rome in 1998, could be the ideal instrument for handling such a situation. But the treaty setting up the court is opposed by a handful of countries. The US is one; and, yes, Russia is another.

webTitle: Dalai Lama may be invited to Taiwan

fields.headline: Dalai Lama may be invited to Taiwan
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Taiwan's president-elect, Chen Shui-bian, may invite the Dalai Lama to attend his inauguration, but will consider China's attitude before making a final decision, a spokesman said yesterday.
fields.body:
Taiwan's president-elect, Chen Shui-bian, may invite the Dalai Lama to attend his inauguration, but will consider China's attitude before making a final decision, a spokesman said yesterday.

"There have been proposals to invite the Dalai Lama, but we have yet to finalise the invitation list," said Li Wang-tai, spokesman for the Democratic Progressive party (DPP), which swept Mr Chen to power in presidential elections last month.

A Hong Kong television channel reported that an invitation had already been sent to the Dalai Lama, who was said to be unable to attend the event on May 20.

The Dalai Lama "will not attend the inauguration because this conflicts with his planned European visit", the channel quoted a spokesman at the Dalai Lama's office as saying. The spokesman reportedly denied that the Tibetan spiritual leader was under pressure from Beijing to stay away.

On Tuesday, China criticised reported plans by the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan, saying he would use the trip to promote separatism.

Mr Li said the DPP was aware that China opposed a visit by the Dalai Lama, but added: "Being the president-elect, Chen Shui-bian has the right to decide who to invite to his inauguration."

The exiled Tibetan spiritual leader visited Taiwan in March 1997, his first trip to Chinese territory since fleeing his homeland with thousands of followers in 1959 after an anti-Communist uprising failed.

Beijing later condemned the 1997 visit, saying it was aimed at severing both Tibet and Taiwan from China.

Mr Li said the DPP would consider China's attitude as it drew up the invitation list but added that "we shouldn't quit just because we are afraid of being criticised".

The DPP has always campaigned for independence from China and was seen by many as Beijing's least favoured party, though Mr Chen soft-pedalled the issue during his presidential campaign.

Beijing, which sees Taiwan as a breakaway province which must be brought under its rule - by force if necessary - has said it would watch Mr Chen's words and deeds.

webTitle: Choice on hunting may end deadlock

fields.headline: Choice on hunting may end deadlock
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Labour MPs opposed to fox hunting yesterday welcomed a government compromise that aims to settle the issue once and for all.
fields.body:
Labour MPs opposed to fox hunting yesterday welcomed a government compromise that aims to settle the issue once and for all.

Under the plan, the home secretary, Jack Straw, would present a multi-choice bill to parliament which would give MPs the chance to vote on options ranging from an outright ban on fox hunting to leaving the law unchanged.

It is designed to take the wind out of the sails of staunch Conservative supporters of fox-hunting, who have vowed to use every parliamentary trick at their disposal to block any ban.

Mr Straw's bill is modelled on the multi-choice bill which John Major's government presented to MPs in 1993 to resolve the impasse on Sunday trading.

The Conservative government gave MPs four options which ranged from total deregulation to keeping most shops closed.

Michael Foster, Labour MP for Worcester, whose anti-fox hunting bill failed to make it onto the statute book despite winning the overwhelming support of Labour MPs in 1997, said he was encouraged by Mr Straw's initiative.

"This would enable people like me to vote for a ban while lessening the opposition in the Lords, because a range of views would have been taken into account," Mr Foster said. The new bill, which would be allocated government time - unlike Mr Foster's ill-fated private member's bill - would probably be introduced after the general election.

By then the former treasury mandarin, Lord Burns, will have produced his report on the employment implications of a ban. His inquiry is expected to recommend proposals backed by the Middle Way pressure group to license hunts.

Labour MPs have turned their attention to Mr Straw's proposal because an attempt by Ken Livingstone, MP for Brent East, to introduce a new private member's bill will fail.

fields.headline: Brainwaves over mobiles
fields.trailText: There is more scientific and anecdotal evidence available about the health effects of mobile phones than GM food and the equivalent of GM field trials in mobile phone technology has been you and me since 1984 (Hands-free mobiles 'increase radiation risk', April 4). Have the NRPB, Which and NPL when undertaking SAR tests (specific absorption rates) on laboratory dummy heads also considered that in the real world we have metal fillings, facial and body piercing, children with dental braces and metal rimmed spectacles? All of which would affect SARs and hence brain functions.
fields.body:
There is more scientific and anecdotal evidence available about the health effects of mobile phones than GM food and the equivalent of GM field trials in mobile phone technology has been you and me since 1984 (Hands-free mobiles 'increase radiation risk', April 4). All of which would affect SARs and hence brain functions.

Should the telecoms industry and government be trusted in matters of public health when £11bn is on the table in the auction for new mobile phone frequencies? Phone masts next to schools and hospitals is an appalling indictment of profit before people.

I worked for seven years installing and using mobile phone equipment until 1990 and have had appalling illhealth ever since including the "usual" chronic tiredness, short-term memory problems, sleep patterns that leave me exhausted and a permanent ringing in the head. "Gagging" clauses have silenced telecoms workers who fall ill with microwave sickness so cases do not get to court.

All schools and libraries are to be microwave-linked to enable "access for all to the internet". I would expect nothing less than microwave emission standards that are the safest in the world (not NRPBs) and that the opportunity is used to locate monitoring equipment of microwave levels from mobile phone sources, especially near schools and hospitals.
Jim Mochnacz
Street, Somerset jim.mochnacz@ukonline.co.uk

 Should not the government insist that the mobile phone companies use satellite relays, rather than the masts that will soon be sprouting like mushrooms every 200 yards? We may not be able to escape the phones, but we might be able to avoid the relay aerials.
Julian Dunn
Oxford eisendora@compuserve.com

 Julie Burchill (Slaves to the mobile, G2, April 5) is, of course, correct, mobile phones are an intrusion and, most certainly, a symbol of enslavement rather than a status symbol. However, as a recently qualified mature graduate the first thing I was asked when I tried to sign on with staff agencies was: "what's your mobile number?" Working eight to 12 hours a day in various menial capacities means that I am dependent on the thing to arrange, and be on hand to discuss, freelance work during office hours. Oh to be free, like Julie, to discard what can only be regarded as a self-inflicted stigma. Conversely, when you are as disorganised as I am, they are handy for explaining why you are late for appointments. "Hi, I'm on the wrong train!"
Dave Juson
Southampton
djuson@uk.packardbell.org

 Julie Burchill is wrong to equate mobile phone use with being "online". The joy of email is that you choose when you want to receive your mail - it cannot intrude uninvited on your privacy.
Caroline Ewans
London
carolineewans@budd.demon. co.uk

 You suggest a move away from representative democracy and an experiment with a digital direct form of democracy to determine how the windfall from the mobile phone licence auction should be spent (Leader, April 4). The result would certainly be more democratic, but it might bring some less welcome results with other issues. What do you think the result of a Sun/Daily Mail encouraged vote on capital punishment or immigration would be?
Rodney Saunders
London
home01@globalnet.co.uk

webTitle: Ignorance about drugs is the real scandal

fields.headline: Ignorance about drugs is the real scandal
fields.trailText: Teenage heroin and crack use are serious matters: equally worrying is the poor drugs knowledge reported (Heroin: abusers start at 15, April 5), but this does not justify alarmist reporting of a very small survey. Between 5% and 20% of 86 respondents in four towns means no more than four teenagers have reported being offered heroin in each place. This is hardly news. I'm sure I could find as many within 24 hours, and without any Department of Health funding, in my village.
fields.body:
Teenage heroin and crack use are serious matters: equally worrying is the poor drugs knowledge reported (Heroin: abusers start at 15, April 5), but this does not justify alarmist reporting of a very small survey. Between 5% and 20% of 86 respondents in four towns means no more than four teenagers have reported being offered heroin in each place. This is hardly news. I'm sure I could find as many within 24 hours, and without any Department of Health funding, in my village.

HIV prevention and drugs workers have known heroin use was widespread in these places for at least 10 years, but if agencies are not reaching younger users, it is because they have not had the resources to expand their services: underfunding of drug treatment and care is a scan dal the Guardian has recently mentioned. What can be the excuse for researchers from Manchester University to be unaware of the publications from Manchester Lifeline? McDermott's Guide to Brown for Beginners, for example, is just one of numerous drugs leaflets for young people using their own language. Neither is the present relative ubiquity of crack, compared with the late 80s, a shocking new development. Ten years ago crack was rare everywhere except in the fevered imagination of tabloid journalism.

Hilary Kinnell
European Network for HIV Prevention in Prostitution

 The real insight of your report is the breath-taking ignorance in official circles. Two experts, funded by the Department of Health on be half of Drug Scope, tell us cities like Hull, Bradford and Bristol have been "untouched" until recently by heroin. I have just checked with police who deal with all three cities. The fact is heroin made its home there years ago, as it did in every other city and in almost every town. Bradford has a particularly successful heroin trade from Pakistan. As for Hull and Bristol - tell a social worker or police officer that they haven't had to deal with the heroin blackmarket for years. At least you'd get a laugh.

The government's disastrous prohibition policy survives primarily because the ministers and officials who defend it do not know what they are talking about.

Nick Davies
London

fields.headline: One club won't do
fields.standfirst: The pound is doing too much damage
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown was given a rough ride at yesterday's annual conference of the British Chambers of Commerce in London amid increasing signs that industry's love-in with a Labour government is under severe strain. The Bank of England's monetary committee meets today and is under pressure to raise interest rates, a move that would alienate business further.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown was given a rough ride at yesterday's annual conference of the British Chambers of Commerce in London amid increasing signs that industry's love-in with a Labour government is under severe strain. The Bank of England's monetary committee meets today and is under pressure to raise interest rates, a move that would alienate business further.

Business leaders did not take kindly to the chancellor's suggestion that industry should learn to live with the strong pound by improving its productivity. He was told that it was "not realistic" for industry to improve efficiency to compensate for an 11% rise in costs last year induced by sterling. That is right. Productivity would only improve if the overvalued pound pushed weaker companies out of business. It's like trying to improve the batting average by removing the weakest players. That is exactly what Labour criticised the Conservatives for during the 1980/81 overvaluation when up to 20% of Britain's manufacturing base was removed. We are, sadly, in danger of a re-run of that disastrous situation now as manufacturers struggle to overcome the effects of a currency 30% above its trade-weighted value four years ago. Rover's losses - half of them attributed to the pound - and the apocalyptic condition of the coal industry (where competitiveness is directly related to the pound) are the surface indicators of a malaise that runs through the whole of manufacturing industry.

What should be done? Business believes that if the government had cooled down the overheating economy by tightening the fiscal stance more in the budget (ie by cutting spending or raising taxes) then the Bank would not be under pressure to raise interest rates. This may seem bizarre when the Treasury has actually tightened the fiscal stance com pared with a year ago and is sitting on a budget surplus of £12bn. But there is some truth in it. Tighter fiscal policy would make it easier for the Bank to lower (or at least not increase) interest rates that are far higher than in the rest of Europe. But that means either raising taxes (and affronting the Daily Mail) or cutting back on the increases in health and education spending that middle England wants as well. If interest rates are raised today it will largely be Mr Brown's fault for not using fiscal policy more selectively. If housing inflation is a big worry, then it should be targeted with property taxes to dampen the market. If consumer spending is the problem, it could have been dealt with by removing purchasing power - temporarily - by higher taxes (though election promises forbid it). Instead, the chancellor has adopted the "one-club" option of relying too heavily on monetary policy which Labour denounced when in opposition.

In the situation bequeathed to it the Bank's committee will be under pressure to raise rates. But they should make sure they are not misreading the economy. The concern of the governor, Eddie George, that a falling pound will rekindle inflation, is debatable. When the pound is falling from an overvalued position it doesn't necessarily worsen inflation. In the early 1980s the pound fell and so did prices. There is still no evidence of resurgent inflation - and we have only just entered a strong deflationary period arising from globalisation and the downward pressure exerted on prices by the internet. Only the services economy is overheating. Manufacturing is in recession. To clobber it yet again to quell a boom in services that could have been dealt with separately is misguided. And will do nothing to bridge the ominous gulf between Labour and industry.

fields.headline: Food yields and famine
fields.trailText: Prof Anthony Trewavas (GM is the best option, March 31) asserts that because the modification is "increased biological yield, impact on mother earth will be kept to a minimum". How can he possibly know?
fields.body:
Prof Anthony Trewavas (GM is the best option, March 31) asserts that because the modification is "increased biological yield, impact on mother earth will be kept to a minimum". How can he possibly know?

Field trials on GM crops in the north, let alone the south, have so far concentrated on agronomic factors, such as yields, rather than on environmental effects such as gene transfer and biodiversity. Elsewhere he acknowledges that the "green revolution came at a price; dependence on intensive agriculture and fertilisers". GM crops are designed for intensive agriculture and are frequently linked to specific chemical use. Will the new rice require more or less chemicals and water; might it produce unexpected results as Sue Mayer suggests?

At least Prof Maurice Ku, who has worked on GM rice, acknowledges the need for further testing. He also demon strates the realities of marketing the genetic modification when he states "to transfer the trait we need to do traditional breeding to introduce the genes to the elite commercial varieties". The control of patented crops is one of the biggest issues for those developing countries. The risks must be properly assessed and each nation must have the right to remain GM free if it wishes.
Joan Ruddock MP

 On January 6, TV news showed that a colossal famine was once again emerging in Ethiopia. On last night's news, three months later, the same message was broadcast to us. Has nothing changed in the last three months? Could not the rest of the world organise its relief efforts in time to avoid the several hundred thousand deaths that have traditionally been due to inertia?
Paul Farber
Leicester

fields.headline: Artists on the warpath
fields.trailText: I'm grabbing 10 minutes in my lunch break to answer Polly Toynbee's vitriol against artists (Labour has only itself to blame for Ken's new coup, April 5). As against Toynbee's image of the artist as a "butterfly" alighting on the latest trendy thing and hanging out with the "chatterati", nearly all artists have at least one job to subsidise making their work. The artists gave their work so generously to London Calling, the auction in support of Ken Livingstone, out of a commitment to what he stands for in relation to the arts. Because they have the "political sense" that Toynbee says they don't possess.
fields.body:
I'm grabbing 10 minutes in my lunch break to answer Polly Toynbee's vitriol against artists (Labour has only itself to blame for Ken's new coup, April 5). As against Toynbee's image of the artist as a "butterfly" alighting on the latest trendy thing and hanging out with the "chatterati", nearly all artists have at least one job to subsidise making their work. The artists gave their work so generously to London Calling, the auction in support of Ken Livingstone, out of a commitment to what he stands for in relation to the arts. Because they have the "political sense" that Toynbee says they don't possess.

This is no bandwagon. Artists are aware of Ken's policies at the GLC, which enabled art to reach new audiences. To refute her image of all of us hanging around polishing our nails, it is artists, many of whom donated work to Monday's auction, who have been at the forefront of the free entry campaign for museums. Artists, more than anyone, know that it is vitally important that art should be available free to all. As she claims artists have no "political sense", we should surely get rid of Goya's Disasters Of War and Picasso's Guernica from the art history books.

Peter Kennard
Contributing artist and co-organiser, London Calling

 What excellent reasons Tracey Emin gives for supporting Ken Livingstone. It might have been said by any number of people sending in their contribution to Ken's campaign. People give their support to politicians for all sorts of reasons, most of which would probably irritate Polly Toynbee. Somebody might even make a contribution because he doesn't like an opponent's comment about the colour of his hair.

As for her call to artists to campaign for free museum entry, they are. Except that such entry concerns far more than artists, since plenty of charging museums have nothing to do with the arts and plenty of visitors are not artists. Which does not stop artists from supporting Ken Livingstone because, in addition to the good reasons Tracey Emin has given, Livingstone is a vigorous opponent of museum charging.

Perhaps if Labour, and Tony Blair in particular, had not been so implacably opposed to artists' interests, they might have been more sympathetic. Take artists' resale royalties. Blair is adamant that artists should not enjoy a royalty of 2% on the resale of their work, on the grounds that this would damage the art trade. But when one of our big auction houses announces recently that it is increasing its own premium by the same percentage, where is the prime minister?

René Gimpel
Gimpel Fils gallery

fields.headline: Border lines
fields.trailText: Your report (On the long road to Britain, March 27) on the trail that takes human traffic from Iraq to western Europe is moving, but inaccurate regarding Greece. Greece's eastern border with Turkey may be rugged but it is not an "open frontier". It is heavily guarded for national security reasons and the smugglers find it extremely difficult to cross.
fields.body:
Your report (On the long road to Britain, March 27) on the trail that takes human traffic from Iraq to western Europe is moving, but inaccurate regarding Greece. Greece's eastern border with Turkey may be rugged but it is not an "open frontier". It is heavily guarded for national security reasons and the smugglers find it extremely difficult to cross.

Moreover, the team of "Schengen experts" who visited Greece in October 1999 were satisfied with the measures taken by the Greek authorities so that since January 1, Greece's ports and, as of March 26, five international airports are now regulated by the Schengen agreement. The increased effectiveness of Greek surveillance methods have made it very difficult and very costly for the criminal gangs to operate in Greece.
Dr Nicos Papadakis
Embassy of Greece

webTitle: Who is to play the King?

fields.headline: Who is to play the King?
fields.standfirst:
This watchdog must be able to bite

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Tom King is a Tory of an old school (Rugby, actually), Kenya rifles, a Heathite who found place under Margaret Thatcher. He was meant to enjoy a statesman's sunset after John Major appointed him to chair the intelligence and security committee (ISC). But this turned out to be no job for a gent.
fields.body:
Tom King is a Tory of an old school (Rugby, actually), Kenya rifles, a Heathite who found place under Margaret Thatcher. He was meant to enjoy a statesman's sunset after John Major appointed him to chair the intelligence and security committee (ISC). But this turned out to be no job for a gent. Behind the asterisks and omissions in his reports, it became clear just how unwilling the agencies were to play the game even with a relative patsy. Mr King was left fulminating over excessive building costs of the security services' palace on Millbank; on the Mitrokhin archive, it turned out this parliamentary supervisor had been hoodwinked and lied to with the best of them.

Mr King's retirement from the Commons creates an opening. The formula says the ISC is a committee of parliamentarians not a committee of parliament; in other words an instrument of executive patronage. It need not be. webTitle: US troops fled Serb mob and lost prisoner

fields.headline: US troops fled Serb mob and lost prisoner
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: American troops were forced to release a suspect, abandon vehicles and trek over a mountain path to escape stone-throwing Serbs in the latest humiliation suffered by international peacekeepers in Kosovo.
fields.body:
American troops were forced to release a suspect, abandon vehicles and trek over a mountain path to escape stone-throwing Serbs in the latest humiliation suffered by international peacekeepers in Kosovo.

As full details emerged yesterday of the worst clash involving US troops since they arrived last June, it became clear that Tuesday's incident in an area close to the Macedonian border amounted to a fiasco. It also showed how well the Serbs have set up a network of vigilantes who can mobilise crowds at short notice.

The trouble started after US military police and Polish troops entered the isolated Serb village of Sevce to search the home of a man detained for illegal possession of two hand grenades. His neighbours quickly pulled logs across the only road out of Sevce and fighting broke out.

The Americans called up reinforcements but before they could arrive were forced to abandon their vehicles and trek through a narrow canyon to the next settlement, Jacinze.

"There were Serbs up on the sides of the canyon throwing rocks," Major Debbie Allen, a US spokeswoman, said. The mile-and-a-half walk took the soldiers two hours.

At Jacinze the peacekeepers joined up with the reinforcements who had arrived by helicopter, and there was fighting with some 300 Serbs. The peacekeepers fired rubber bullets and used stun grenades and dogs. In the melee, a Serb woman dragged the arrested man away from the troops. "The man escaped," another US military spokesman said yesterday, adding that the villages were now calm. The abandoned military vehicles and equipment were retrieved.

The incident follows a clash last month when stone-throwing Serbs, organised by men with walkie-talkies, forced US troops to cut short an arms search in northern Mitrovice. That was in the French sector of Kosovo, and the Pentagon later said that US troops would be confined to their own region in south-eastern Kosovo, except in emergencies.

Tension has been high between the Serbs and Americans because the US led the Nato air strikes, but there is mounting suspicion that the Serbs want to highlight the chaos in Kosovo during the US presidential campaign. George W Bush, the Republican front-runner, has hinted that he might withdraw US troops.

US efforts to restrain armed former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army from crossing into southern Serbia have also suffered a set-back. An agreement brokered by US diplomats with Hashim Thaci, the political leader of the now dissolved KLA, has broken down, and Albanian paramilitaries have again been spotted in Serbia by US monitors.

The gunmen claim they are defending Albanians from the threat of Serb repression, but their avowed aim is to join the region to Kosovo.

fields.headline: Closing in on Iraqi torturers
fields.standfirst:
British organisation near to indictment of first key figure in Saddam regime

Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: An organisation set up to hunt down the Iraqi leadership for alleged human rights abuses claimed yesterday it was poised to indict the first member of the regime.
fields.body:
An organisation set up to hunt down the Iraqi leadership for alleged human rights abuses claimed yesterday it was poised to indict the first member of the regime.

The British-based organisation Indict, which was awarded $2m in funding by US Congress, said it had accumulated enough evidence to make a case stick against an Iraqi accused of torture.

Fearful of the Iraqi intelligence service, Indict operates from a secret location in London and carefully guards the identity of its staff.

The Labour MP Ann Clwyd, who is president of the organisation and has long campaigned on behalf of the Iraqi Kurds and other victims of the regime, said yesterday: "We are excited at the quality of evidence we are getting which we hope will enable us to indict."

To prevent a recurrence of an episode last August in which a senior member of the Iraqi government, Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri, fled from Vienna 24 hours before legal action was initiated, secrecy is paramount and even Ms Clwyd does not know the identity of the Iraqi being targeted or in which country the indictment will take place. But she said the indictment would be "soon, within the next few weeks or months".

Staff at Indict's office were more secretive, uneasy that Ms Clwyd had gone too far.

Indict, which was set up in 1996, aims to mount an operation similar to that which led to the arrest of General Augusto Pinochet in Britain but hopes to secure a successful prosecution.

On a wider front, Indict is lobbying, alongside the US, for the UN security council to set up a war crimes tribunal for Iraq similar to the ones for Rwanda and the Balkans.

Ms Clwyd said: "We want to send a signal to the Iraqi government that there are no safe hiding places anywhere in the world for those charged with the horrendous crimes of Saddam Hussein and those round him." She said she found it extraordinary, given the scale of the accusations against them, that members of the regime could travel freely round the world.

Although the US state department agreed to provide $2m two years ago, the first tranche of that money - $600,385 - only came through last July. Since that time, Indict's eight-strong team has gathered evidence from around the world and made clandestine trips to Iraq.

Indict insisted it had not been ready for Mr al-Douri as it had only received the funding from the US the previous month and had not accumulated the evidence necessary to make a convincing case.

The top 12 on Indict's wanted list are: President Saddam Hussein; two former heads of the intelligence service, Barzan al-Tikriti and Sab'awi Ibrahim al-Hassan; Saddam's two sons, Uday and Qusay; Ali Hassan al-Majid, the former Iraqi commander in Iraqi Kurdistan and first governor of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait; Mohammed al-Zubaydi, who took part in the coup that brought Saddam to power; Aziz Salih al-Noman, Saddam's former special adviser; Tariq Aziz, the deputy prime minister; Mr al-Douri, the former interior minister; Watban al-Tikriti, a former interior minister; and Ta Ha Yassin Ramadan, the vice-president.

The accusations range from actions against the Iraqi Kurds in the 1980s to those against the Marsh Arabs in the 1990s. The organisation said indictment was possible under various international laws, such as the genocide, Geneva and torture conventions.

Indict, whose board includes the former US ambassador Peter Galbraith and the former British ambassador Sir John Morgan as well as leaders of the Iraqi opposition, has had a short but turbulent history.

It has had a torrid time in the last year trying to establish credibility: questions have been raised about why the US should fund an organisation headed by a leftwing Labour backbencher and there have been rows over money. Legal action is being taken by Ms Clwyd over articles in Punch and Private Eye.

US state department officials visited the office yesterday to check on progress.

Ms Clwyd said of the internal rows: "Of course, in any multicultural organisation there are going to be different norms of behaviour and it is sometimes difficult to balance people's expectations and desire to indict."

But she said the arrival last year of the money from the US and the employment of Tony Cunningham, a former Labour Euro MP, as chief of staff - the only member of staff prepared to be named publicly - had helped create a tightly run organisation.

In addition to the $600,385 from the US, Indict has received $600,000 from an anonymous backer, whom Ms Clwyd is prepared to disclose privately but not publicly.

Indict claimed the necessary majority for the establishment of a war crimes tribunal existed on the UN security council but the danger was of one of the permanent members exercising its veto. As part of its lobbying campaign, a conference has been organised in Paris next Friday.
