fields.headline: Another country
fields.standfirst: Once, country stars were sweet, docile women who knew their place and stood by their men. But now one of America's bestselling groups, the Dixie Chicks, have outraged the industry with a revenge song about domestic violence. Lucy O'Brien reports on the good ol' gals who are raising hell in Nashville
fields.trailText: Once, country stars were sweet, docile women who knew their place and stood by their men. But now one of America's bestselling groups, the Dixie Chicks, have outraged the industry with a revenge song about domestic violence. Lucy O'Brien reports on the good ol' gals who are raising hell in Nashville
fields.body:
They are one of the best-selling groups in the US, but female country trio the Dixie Chicks are finding it difficult to get airplay. Their latest single, Goodbye Earl, a humorous Thelma & Louise-style revenge song, in which two women kill a violent husband, has become a huge hit, reaching number eight in the Billboard charts and number two in the country charts. Many radio programmers and male DJs, however, have problems with the content of the song (ironic considering the amount of woman-hating rap and heavy rock that regularly graces the airwaves), and are refusing to play it.

With their punchy delivery and penchant for swearing, the twentysomething Dixie Chicks are part of an assertive new breed of country gals. Originally from Dallas, sisters Emily Erwin (banjo) and Martie Seidel (fiddle), played bluegrass at street corners and county fairs until they were joined four years ago by vocalist Natalie Maines, daughter of the Texan steel guitar legend Lloyd Maines.

Despite three critically acclaimed albums, they found themselves stuck playing corporate events dressed as novelty cowgirls. They decided to go their own way one night after Seidel overheard a male punter calling them the "Dallas Cowboy cheerleaders." Seidel says, "I just wanted to shove my bow up his ass." Their exuberant new country pop soon caught on, and their top label debut, Wide Open Spaces, won two 1999 Grammys and became the bestselling release by a group in country music history. The follow-up, Fly, which features the offending single, has already sold more than 4m copies.

The US country music industry traditionally liked its women long-suffering, submissive and sweet, but the indications are that radio programmers and the good old boys of Nashville are out of step with the new female artists. "The majority of female country stars are not the withering flowers they once were," says the US entertainment writer, Don Moorhouse. "You have artists like Wynona and Mary Chapin Carpenter, whose approach to songs is very affirmative, very self-willed."

The debate over the Dixie Chicks's song has spread from Nashville and become a national hot potato. "We've supported the song, we feel it works well," says Chip Miller, programme director for Kix County Radio in Massachusetts. "Some people have complained that it glamorises killing. We're one of the few stations that doesn't buy into the idea that it's offensive. Feisty women are fine."

Country music has always had strong women performers, but until recently they had to keep up the appearance of being docile and dedicated to the men in their lives. Until the 80s, religious fundamentalism dominated the genre, and Nashville was intensely conservative.

Fifties female star Patsy Cline, for instance, literally broke her neck trying to keep her various marriages together while tearing around promoting her records. Once after a car accident, she went into the recording studio with her broken ribs barely healed. The brassy, braided cowgirl from Virginia was killed in 1963 at the age of 30 in a plane crash, in a mad hurry to get home through wintry fog to cook the dinner. Cline's life was a wrestling match between her desire to be a star and a moral imperative that expected her to be at home tending to her man.

Tammy Wynette also typified the old country view of woman-as-victim. Her second husband, songwriter Don Chapel, traded nude photos of her via porn magazines, and when her 1969 anthem Stand By Your Man was at the top of the charts she was being beaten and bruised by her third husband, the country star George Jones, who was famous for his drunken benders. When she met her last husband, producer George Richey, Wynette claimed she felt as contented as a little girl, "when Daddy was always there to take care of me". She died two years ago, aged 55, after years of severe stomach ailments and an addiction to painkillers. Right up to her death she was pasting on a smile and performing, even though she looked like a walking cadaver.

Previously portrayed in songs as angels of the hearth or downtrodden, hapless victims of men, it is fair to deduce that women have not had an easy ride in country music. Country originated from working class hillbilly folk music, and reflected some of the more reactionary aspects of that culture. But in the same way that women have hit back in hip hop against misogynist rap, with strong, dignified figures such as Queen Latifah, there are a steadily growing number of women in country music who fight fire with fire.

A strongly male-dominated genre seems to breed rebellion. For every George Jones crooning about the little wifey at home, there was a self-possessed woman itching to sing about her life. Country music is, after all, meant to be about direct, down-home honesty.

Dolly Parton was one of the first to break the mould, launching an attack on sexual double standards with her 1967 hit Dumb Blonde. Although she presented an exaggerated version of femininity, with her wasp waist, bouffant hair and balloon-shaped bust, Parton was adept at sending herself up. A shrewd, self-made woman from poverty-stricken Tennessee, she sang of women's independence. Parton proved early on that it was possible for a woman to be a prolific songwriter and a successful country star on her own terms.

These days, a new country act doesn't have to disguise assertiveness behind a blonde beehive, though there is still pressure to sing formulaic love ditties. Women such as Shania Twain and Mindy McCready have found the commercial route to be most effective, but other artists remain committed to singing realistically about romance and relationships. Alabama-born Shelby Lynne, for instance, recorded five albums in Nashville and became increasingly frustrated with its strictures. "I wanted to play guitar," she said, "and in Nashville that's kind of taboo - you just don't do that." She moved back home, started writing songs "and taking control." The result, I Am Shelby Lynne, was one of 1999's strongest new country albums, mixing a laconic country twang with rural Southern soul. Intensely personal and melancholic, it would have been too outre, too angry, for the more conservative companies of Music City.

Female country artists have become more defiant, yet they still have to be careful about who they might offend. Even though the Dixie Chicks sugared their musical pill with black comedy, singing about domestic violence, it seems, was just a little too real.

Intensely personal and melancholic, it would have been too outre, too angry, for the more conservative companies of Music City. Female country artists have become more defiant, yet they still have to be careful about who they might offend. Even though the Dixie Chicks sugared their musical pill with black comedy, singing about domestic violence, it seems, was just a little too real.

fields.headline: Bland ambition
fields.standfirst: Girls may be leading the pack while at school but a new report shows they are being led into less challenging jobs than boys.  Terri Apter asks why
fields.trailText: Girls may be leading the pack while at school but a new report shows they are being led into less challenging jobs than boys.  Terri Apter asks why
fields.body:
Each new generation of women has, since the middle of the last century, been hailed as the one that will smash inequalities in the workplace, in the home, in politics. And so far, each generation has experienced mysterious impediments that allow it to move only so far, and no further. While most recent explanations point to prejudices embedded in the workplace and in the division of labour within the home, a government report due out next week locates problems much earlier on in women's lives.

Listen Up: A Dialogue with Young People is the result of consultation with more than 500 young people and explores the aspirations and ambitions of young women and men. It shows that while more young women stay on in education than young men (73% compared to 64%), and while girls out-perform boys at GCSE level (53% of young women achieved at least 5 A-C grades, compared to 43% of boys), occupational choice and career strategies remain in a gender rut. For example, 75% of year-11 students entering managerial and professional occupations are boys whereas 65% of those entering clerical and secretarial positions are girls, as are 75% of those entering personal services. Skilled construction and skilled engineering show the greatest disparity, with less than 5% of girls entering these occupations.

The research shows that gender stereotyping occurs at all points of young people's careers, and young women say they have insufficient help in resisting these roles. Rather than uncovering something new, the report has revealed the persistence of something old. Girls are still shuttled into "feminine" jobs such as supermarket sales for work experience. When they seek career guidance, they report being given information that neither matches their interests nor meets their needs. One young woman quoted in the report says: "If you want to do something else you have to organise it yourself and it's not easy. I was worrying about my GCSE grades, not about what I wanted to be." So while girls are dedicated to getting the grades that make us have such high hopes for them, they are actually losing hope for life beyond school.

Adolescence is the time that girls' aspirations flounder. Boys' confidence tends to grow, while that of girls tends to plummet. Hanging over girls is the vision of the perfect woman - thin, beautiful, well-dressed and much-desired, an ideal to which many girls long to conform, but know they never will.

Adolescence is called the age of rebellion, but it is in fact a phase of great conformity. Fitting in becomes of the utmost importance. Being different is only fun if it means differing from the norm in the company of like-minded friends. A girl who aims for a career in a male occupation may worry about leaving her friends behind.

When girls are formulating career plans, being ambitious becomes socially dangerous. Some 30 years ago, the Harvard psychologist Matina Horner observed that in certain situations in which achievement is measured, women became anxious far more often than did men. Stories of successful women stirred fears of social rebuke and isolation, while men associated stories of a man's professional success with good personal fortune. Though we think we have left behind the injunction to be "nice", girls are reluctant to set themselves above other girls, concluding that they cannot be ambitious and remain acceptable to either men or women. As much as any man's ridicule, they fear the familiar girlfriend's chant: "Just who does she think she is?"

Protecting young women from the teenage plague of low self-esteem will involve blasting away the ideal of physical perfection and replacing it with realistic options. Role models - noted women who have achieved success in atypical careers - are often called in to inspire young women, but they sometimes just present another impossible ideal: the woman who does it all in a way that has no precedent among the people these young women know.

Visions have to link up with these young women's realities. They need mentors who can provide intensive career guidance that will point not only to distant goals, but also to the paths that lead there. As we act as guides, we also have to acknowledge how difficult bucking the gender trend can be, even for seasoned women. Many are unsettled by the charge of being ambitious (and therefore ruthless), of not fitting in with either the male or female crowd, of leaving friends behind as they move on. Teenagers are expert at sniffing out hypocrisy, and shut their ears in its presence. Unless we say: "Yes, there are personal risks in pursuing our goals" and "Yes, we have to manage these problems day to day" we will lose the golden opportunity of passing on what we have gained.

fields.headline: New inquiry into ship disaster
fields.trailText: The families of the victims of the MV Derbyshire were praised yesterday as a new inquiry began in London into the sinking of the biggest British vessel lost at sea.
fields.body:
The families of the victims of the MV Derbyshire were praised yesterday as a new inquiry began in London into the sinking of the biggest British vessel lost at sea.

Attorney general Lord Williams paid tribute to the families' "persistence and fortitude" in bringing about the second inquiry into why the 169,000-tonne bulk carrier sank in 1980 in a typhoon in the Pacific Ocean off Japan with the loss of all 42 of its British crew and two wives.

Stephen Cantor, solicitor for the Derbyshire Families Association, said: "Everyone is hopeful there will be a proper outcome to the investigation and that the true reason for the loss of the Derbyshire comes out. The families have been seeking the truth since they started their campaign 20 years ago."

But Lord Williams told the families not to expect the impossible. "There will never be an absolute certainty about what happened during the last few minutes when the Derbyshire sank because there is no means of knowing for sure," he said.

In 1998 the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, ordered the formal investigation to be reopened.

The Derbyshire was one of six identical vessels built in Teesside by Swan Hunter shipbuilders in the late 1970s. The Tory administration ruled out an investigation as impractical and it was only after a sister ship, the Kowloon Bridge, went aground off the coast of Ireland in 1986 that the first public inquiry into the Derbyshire began.

That inquiry, completed seven years before the wreckage of the Derbyshire was located, concluded that the vessel was "probably overwhelmed by the forces of nature" when waves up to 80ft high pounded the ship.

webTitle: Peer's 'moral' duty to tear up GM crops

fields.headline: Peer's 'moral' duty to tear up GM crops
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Melchett, the executive director of Greenpeace, yesterday told a court he set out to destroy a field of genetically modified maize because he felt "a strong moral obligation" to villagers living in the area.
fields.body:
Lord Melchett, the executive director of Greenpeace, yesterday told a court he set out to destroy a field of genetically modified maize because he felt "a strong moral obligation" to villagers living in the area.

The Old Etonian and former Labour minister decided to uproot the herbicide-tolerant plant after attending a "very moving" public meeting a fortnight earlier in the village of Lyng, Norfolk, where the six acre trial crop of the substance had been planted and was close to flowering.

He denied his action was arrogant, and insisted: "My feeling from the meeting was that the arrogance was on the side of a farmer who planted something without telling people before he did it."

He is one of 28 Greenpeace members who are accused of ripping up and stealing £750 worth of GM maize at Walnut Tree Farm in Lyng on July 26 last year. It had been planted as part of a four-year, £3.3m trial into environmental biodiversity.

The activists, who come from Edinburgh, Leeds and Aberdeen, and include a Baptist minister, beauty therapist and ice cream seller, have all pleaded not guilty at Norwich crown court to theft and causing criminal damage.

In the first case to put the issue of GM foods before a jury, they argue that their actions were legally justified be cause they acted to prevent serious damage to other crops and the environment by genetic "contamination" via the GM maize pollen.

Yesterday the 52-year-old hereditary peer told the court that he had decided to act after the crop's owners, the German based agro-chemical firm AgrEvo, now known as Aventis, failed to repond to his requests that the crop be destroyed.

"I don't normally get involved in this action," he told Judge David Mellor and the jury. "I felt if anyone was going to stop the crop flowering I should get involved."

The 4th Baron Melchett, who served in the Wilson and Callaghan governments, added: "I felt a strong moral obligation to do something following the meeting at Lyng. I was asked to speak at that meeting and a lot of people were there. There was a crowd outside the door."

The court had already heard that he had held meetings with the prime minister, Tony Blair, but felt unable to turn the tide of government policy, and had also been advised by lawyers that there was no way of stopping the trial of GM crops, which was being sponsored by the government, through the courts.

"I thought we had been through a long process... my view was that at that stage the only choice we had was to go and remove it - as we did."

The case continues.

fields.headline: Lawyers question Scot's drugs plea
fields.trailText: Lawyers acting for a British grandmother jailed for almost seven years for trying to smuggle £500,000 worth of cocaine out of Venezuela yesterday said they believed her conviction was untenable.
fields.body:
Lawyers acting for a British grandmother jailed for almost seven years for trying to smuggle £500,000 worth of cocaine out of Venezuela yesterday said they believed her conviction was untenable.

Less than a week after being apprehended at an airport on the holiday island of Margarita while carrying eight kilos of the class A drug, Irene Campbell, from Glasgow, was sentenced to six years and nine months.

Mrs Campbell, 56, a residential carer working with under-privileged children, had previously campaigned against drugs and her family said they were devastated by the conviction.

As her daughter, Linda Miller, flew to Venezuela in an attempt to discover why Mrs Campbell pleaded guilty to the charges, Joe Beltrami, the family's lawyer, said he had no confidence in the sentence.

"I am concerned about the indecent haste of this conviction - sentence within 48 hours of appearing in court," said Mr Beltrami. "This is a decent woman with no previous connection to drugs. I believe pressure has been brought to bear on Mrs Campbell."

Mrs Campbell's family claimed that she had been duped into carrying the drugs, but British consular officials in Venezuela who have spoken to her confirmed yesterday that she had admitted attempting to smuggle the drugs.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said that the British vice consul had flown from Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, to Margarita to see Mrs Campbell. She confirmed that Mrs Campbell had been represented by a public defender at her trial.

"The vice consul will report back to London today. We cannot comment further until we hear from him," added the spokeswoman.

Mrs Campbell's family first discovered the smuggling charges last Friday. They had expected her to return from her two week package holiday on Wednesday and when she did not come home they presumed she had missed her flight and had been unable to telephone.

But on Friday they received a phone call from the Foreign Office informing them that Mrs Campbell was in jail on Margarita after being apprehended by customs officials while attempting to board her flight with a suitcase stuffed with cocaine.

Mrs Campbell's daughter, Audrey Jamieson, 31, said: "My sister Linda telephoned me and said: 'Mum has been arrested in Venezuela'. I thought there had been some sort of mistake, it could not be my mother. It was like a nightmare."

Mrs Campbell, a divorcee with five children and 14 grandchildren, has been employed by Glasgow city council's social work department for 23 years.

webTitle: EU condemns factory farming of chickens

fields.headline: EU condemns factory farming of chickens
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Factory farming methods for chickens in Britain were yesterday condemned by EU scientists who are demanding big changes in the way poultry is reared for the dinner table.
fields.body:
Factory farming methods for chickens in Britain were yesterday condemned by EU scientists who are demanding big changes in the way poultry is reared for the dinner table.

They say welfare has been given a low priority by producers in the search for ever-quicker growing birds, causing widespread lameness and heart and skin disorders.

The scientists blame much of the problem on overcrowding of poultry houses, and advocate the need for cuts in stocking rates of between 10% and 20%, a move that the British poultry industry warned could put many farms out of business.

Their conclusions go much further than the voluntary minimum standards for home producers published last week with government approval.

Animal welfare groups welcomed what they believe is a landmark report from the European commission's animal health and animal welfare committee on conditions in broiler houses packed with thousands of birds.

It will now be considered by commissioners and individual governments. It follows damning indictments from EU vets on standards of hygiene in poultry slaughterhouses in several EU states, including Britain.

The food standards agency has also attacked high levels of salmonella.

Welfare changes would mean small increases in the price consumers pay for chicken - Britons eat nearly 800m, most home produced, and consumption accounts for two-fifths of all meat eaten in this country. The scientists say low price and a healthy image have helped boost chicken's profile.

Although pressure from British consumers was forcing the industry to abandon the use of growth promoting antibiotics, throughout the EU "there has been little pressure from consumers on the broiler producers to improve the welfare of the animals".

The report concludes that the industry's genetic selection of new types of chicken is geared to faster and more efficient production, which has cut the birth-to-slaughter time for broilers from 10 to six weeks in 30 years. Attention given to breeding out leg disorders or resistance to infection "is often low and up to now has not improved welfare".

The report implies that stocking rates should fall from the EU average of 38kg of chicken per square metre (17-19 birds), to 30kg (14 or 15). Most of Britain's 2,000 poultry farms are thought to operate between 34kg and 38kg. '

The RSPCA's Freedom Foods scheme, covering about 5% of the industry, sets a maximum of 30kg.

That level would increase prices to the consumer, at present around £4 for a bird just over 2kg , by about 2.5%. Farmers would face increased production costs of 5% and chicken might take as long as 10 more days to prepare for slaughter.

The RSPCA said the report underlined many of its concerns about welfare of broilers, while Peter Stevenson, political and legal director of Compassion in World Farming, said it "shows the modern intensive broiler industry inflicts great suffering on many of the chickens".

Peter Bradnock, of the British Poultry Meat Federation, said any EC action on the report "would have severe implications - most European chicken farms would be out of business".

The new self-policed industry standards run by Assured Chicken Production Ltd assume a 34kg density.

webTitle: Pakistan lays claim to Surrey mansion

fields.headline: Pakistan lays claim to Surrey mansion
fields.standfirst: Bhutto's husband 'corruptly bought £4.5m home'
fields.trailText: Pakistan's military government is drawing up plans to move part of its high commission in London to a mansion in Surrey which was allegedly bought and renovated by Benazir Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, with money made in corrupt deals while the couple were in power, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Pakistan's military government is drawing up plans to move part of its high commission in London to a mansion in Surrey which was allegedly bought and renovated by Benazir Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, with money made in corrupt deals while the couple were in power, the Guardian has learned.

The plan to turn Rockwood House near Brook into an out of town residence and country club has been mooted as a way of "flushing out" the real owners of the £4.5m property.

If anyone does come forward to claim ownership, Pakistan's national accountability bureau will seek to question them about the estate, which was bought by an offshore firm, Romina Properties, five years ago.

Refurbishment of the mansion was abandoned in October 1996, shortly before Mrs Bhutto's government fell from power. It is currently being minded by a builder, Paul Keating, who is living in one of its outhouses. Mr Keating is suing a friend of Mr Zardari's, Javaid Pasha, for £375,000, which he claims he is owed for renovation work.

Last month Mr Keating was interviewed in London by Pakistan's two leading anti-corruption investigators, Lieutenant General Syed Mohammad Amjad, chairman of the NAB, and Farouk Adam Khan, the NAB's prosecutor in chief.

The NAB was set up by General Pervez Musharraf, who led last October's coup, to investigate allegations of corruption in Mrs Bhutto's administration, and that of her successor, Nawaz Sharif.

Mr Keating, who met the men separately at the Pakistani high commission, was asked to provide details of the people he worked for and the building work carried out on Rockwood House.

Mr Keating told them that the project was top secret. He said he was "in no doubt" that Rockwood House was bought by Mr Zardari and that he intended to move to the mansion, which boasts nine bedrooms, an indoor swimming pool, stables and polo pitches.

He told them Mr Zardari was in overall charge of the refurbishment - approving designs and visiting the site to make sure the work was going according to schedule.

Mr Zardari has been in jail since November 1996 accused of making millions from illegal kickbacks which he received from government contracts.

When Mr Keating became caretaker of the property, he found a framed picture of Mrs Bhutto and a commemorative plate, on which her name was engraved, locked in the safe.

He also found a plaque displaying two first world war bayonets. Its inscription read: "Presented to Asif Zardari from Wilkinson's Swords."

He showed Farouk Adam Khan photographs of artefacts, wooden carvings and precious stones that were left in the house and was told that some of them were stolen from a museum in Pakistan.

Mr Keating has agreed to fly to Pakistan to give evidence in any forthcoming trials.

Mrs Bhutto has strongly denied that she knew anything about the purchase of Rockwood House.

She told the Guardian: "I have never even been to Surrey. I don't know anything about this house. I have been told by people for a long time that my husband bought the house. I have asked my husband on 10 occasions if this is true and he said it is not. I have never seen the paperwork to prove it. I do not believe he had anything to do with it."

Mr Keating said yesterday: "The NAB believes Rockwood House was bought by Mr Zardari with corrupt money, and therefore the property is owned by the Pakistani people.

"They told me they want to use Rockwood House as an auxiliary to the high commission, like our prime minister uses Chequers. I was appointed to look after Rockwood House by associates of Mr Zardari 18 months ago, but nobody has contacted me since. If the high commission does come here, I can't imagine anyone coming forward to complain."

Mr Keating is suing Mr Pasha and his wife Shabnam, and their company FMS International, claiming that they masterminded the renovation work on behalf of Mr Zardari.

Mr Pasha is defending the claim on the basis that he was not acting as an agent for Mr Zardari and does not know who bought the property.

The next hearing in the case is due at the central London county court in five weeks.

It is currently being minded by a builder, Paul Keating, who is living in one of its outhouses. Mr Keating is suing a friend of Mr Zardari's, Javaid Pasha, for £375,000, which he claims he is owed for renovation work. Last month Mr Keating was interviewed in London by Pakistan's two leading anti-corruption investigators, Lieutenant General Syed Mohammad Amjad, chairman of the NAB, and Farouk Adam Khan, the NAB's prosecutor in chief. The NAB was set up by General Pervez Musharraf, who led last October's coup, to investigate allegations of corruption in Mrs Bhutto's administration, and that of her successor, Nawaz Sharif. Mr Keating, who met the men separately at the Pakistani high commission, was asked to provide details of the people he worked for and the building work carried out on Rockwood House. Mr Keating told them that the project was top secret. He said he was "in no doubt" that Rockwood House was bought by Mr Zardari and that he intended to move to the mansion, which boasts nine bedrooms, an indoor swimming pool, stables and polo pitches. He told them Mr Zardari was in overall charge of the refurbishment - approving designs and visiting the site to make sure the work was going according to schedule. Mr Zardari has been in jail since November 1996 accused of making millions from illegal kickbacks which he received from government contracts. When Mr Keating became caretaker of the property, he found a framed picture of Mrs Bhutto and a commemorative plate, on which her name was engraved, locked in the safe. He also found a plaque displaying two first world war bayonets. Its inscription read: "Presented to Asif Zardari from Wilkinson's Swords." He showed Farouk Adam Khan photographs of artefacts, wooden carvings and precious stones that were left in the house and was told that some of them were stolen from a museum in Pakistan. Mr Keating has agreed to fly to Pakistan to give evidence in any forthcoming trials. Mrs Bhutto has strongly denied that she knew anything about the purchase of Rockwood House. She told the Guardian: "I have never even been to Surrey. I don't know anything about this house. I have been told by people for a long time that my husband bought the house. I have asked my husband on 10 occasions if this is true and he said it is not. I have never seen the paperwork to prove it. I do not believe he had anything to do with it." Mr Keating said yesterday: "The NAB believes Rockwood House was bought by Mr Zardari with corrupt money, and therefore the property is owned by the Pakistani people. "They told me they want to use Rockwood House as an auxiliary to the high commission, like our prime minister uses Chequers. I was appointed to look after Rockwood House by associates of Mr Zardari 18 months ago, but nobody has contacted me since. If the high commission does come here, I can't imagine anyone coming forward to complain." Mr Keating is suing Mr Pasha and his wife Shabnam, and their company FMS International, claiming that they masterminded the renovation work on behalf of Mr Zardari. Mr Pasha is defending the claim on the basis that he was not acting as an agent for Mr Zardari and does not know who bought the property. The next hearing in the case is due at the central London county court in five weeks.

fields.headline: Tests reveal transsexual was killed
fields.trailText: The killer of a transsexual whose naked body was found wrapped in chains on a Suffolk beach last month attached too few weights to his victim to prevent him being washed ashore, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
The killer of a transsexual whose naked body was found wrapped in chains on a Suffolk beach last month attached too few weights to his victim to prevent him being washed ashore, police said yesterday.

The body of Bryan Hooley, 28, who had a sex change operation in 1994 to become a woman, was dumped in the sea with three 2.5kg gym weights padlocked to it.

But it resurfaced within days at Kessingland, near Lowestoft in Suffolk.

Detectives believe that Mr Hooley, from Roxwell, Essex, was probably killed by someone he knew, who then used what was to hand to weigh his body down.

Until yesterday, police were unsure whether they were investigating a murder or a suicide. They were puzzled by bruising to Mr Hooley's face and head, but the divorced father-of-one had told neighbours he was unhappy with his sex change and he had recently lost his job.

A second postmortem revealed that his injuries had not been caused by the weights or another object hitting him in the water.

Instead, he had been hit at least once by a flat object and had been dead for several hours before his body was either dumped from a boat, or hauled into the sea.

Detectives believe Mr Hooley may have been dumped in the sea at Covehithe, a beach four miles south of Kessingland, after a bodybuilder's weight, identical to the three padlocked to his body, was found there a week ago. They think the killer may have been a bodybuilder.

fields.headline: Young get £150m sport boost
fields.trailText: Youngsters are to benefit from a multimillion pound programme that will not only help to identify world class talent but encourage children of all abilities to take part in sport.
fields.body:
Youngsters are to benefit from a multimillion pound programme that will not only help to identify world class talent but encourage children of all abilities to take part in sport.

The government's strategy on sport, unveiled yesterday, will establish 300 sports and arts facilities in or near schools in the next two years, with the emphasis on deprived areas.

Around £75m of new government money is being invested in the project, along with £75m from the lottery and private sponsorship.

Announcing the strategy, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said the government wanted to develop sporting talent at an early age but everyone should get the chance to enjoy sport.

Sports groups have raised concerns that schools are not including sport on their curriculums and that more government investment is needed. Others have argued that sport is too exclusive and that many who are not naturally good at it are put off taking part.

Mr Smith said: "We need to give young people the right facilities to take part in sport and develop their ability. This project, it will enable us to tackle the needs of some 300 primary schools, focusing on areas of real deprivation."

The strategy was attacked by the Liberal Democrat spokesman on sport, Bob Russell, as insufficient to enable Britain to catch up with countries such as Australia and the US.

webTitle: Milburn hints at free care for elderly

fields.headline: Milburn hints at free care for elderly
fields.trailText: Help for elderly people facing costly nursing home bills looked on the way last night after Alan Milburn, the health secretary, dropped the clearest hint that action is to be taken.
fields.body:
Help for elderly people facing costly nursing home bills looked on the way last night after Alan Milburn, the health secretary, dropped the clearest hint that action is to be taken.

Addressing the annual congress of the Royal College of Nursing in Bournemouth, the minister twice spoke of the prospect of free nursing care for all older people.

In a reference to the college's policy that nursing care should be free, wherever delivered, Mr Milburn said: "Your views are very close to my own on this issue."

The government has delayed for more than a year any decision on a report of the royal commission on long-term care, which recommended that "personal" care should be free. At present some 42,500 people in nursing homes have to pay for all their care.

The report said the concession, which would meet about 60% of a typical nursing home charge of £350 a week, would help some of the estimated 40,000 people a year who sell their homes to pay for nursing or residential care.

The cost of the change was put at an initial £1.2bn a year. Personal care would include not only nursing, but also dressing, feeding and bathing.

The RCN says nursing care could be provided free at an annual cost of £220m to £600m. It seems clear that ministers are considering this cheaper option, working on a definition of nursing care that would exclude much of what the royal commission had in mind.

Helen Caulfield, RCN policy adviser, said there was no reason for the minister to procrastinate further. "He can't have failed to notice just how angry nurses are at this delay and the unfairness to patients and their families.

"Every day that goes by, more people are having to sell their homes."

A spokeswoman for the charity Age Concern said it would continue to press for all personal care to be free. "The government raised the hopes of older people when it set up the royal commission, but the continuing delay has led to inequity, disappointment and confusion."

Mr Milburn confirmed he would be enabling hospital sisters to take control of their own budgets, worth a minimum £5,000 a year, for repairs and maintenance on their wards.

He also announced new standards of ward cleanliness, the first for 25 years; a further expansion of nurse prescribing; and a programme of investment in housing for nurses - "not a return to the old style nurses' home" - to be led by John Yates, newly appointed national nurse housing co-ordinator.

Today the Department of Health is expected to publish consultative proposals for a NHS workforce planning body, designed to ensure that doctor numbers increase in step with numbers of nurses and other health workers.

Mr Milburn received a better reception from the nurses than had the Conservative leader, William Hague, who addressed the congress on Tuesday.

Whereas delegates voted by 82% to express no confidence in Mr Hague's assurances on Tory health policy, they gave a 63% vote of confidence in the health secretary.

Earlier Mr Milburn said on Radio 4's Today programme that millions of pounds was being pumped into the NHS to cover budget deficits highlighted by Whitehall's spending watchdog.

The national audit office revealed that health authorities and trusts were heading for deficits of £197m in the last financial year. The health service was also found to be facing a £2.4bn bill for medical negligence claims.

fields.headline: Viagra can counter infertility
fields.trailText: Viagra, the anti-impotence drug, could help some infertile women to get pregnant, a US researcher says.
fields.body:
Viagra, the anti-impotence drug, could help some infertile women to get pregnant, a US researcher says.

Geoffrey Sher, of the Sher Institute for Reproductive Medicine in Las Vegas, said in New Scientist magazine that Viagra helped three of four women to conceive. Each had tried artificial conception at least three times, but this failed even when a perfect embryo was implanted in the uterus.

In each case the lining of the uterus was too thin to support an embryo. Dr Sher thought there might be too little blood reaching the uterus. Viagra promotes a faster flow of blood by stimulating production of nitric oxide, widening blood vessels.

The volunteers used Viagra suppositories for a week. Two of the three women who conceived have had apparently healthy IVF babies.

Concern remains that the extra nitric oxide may have harmed the embryos. But Dr Sher said he had allowed a week between the last suppository and the embryo implant, plenty of time for nitric oxide to clear from the mother's bodies naturally.

webTitle: First sight of Glyn Dwr letters

fields.headline: First sight of Glyn Dwr letters
fields.trailText: Two letters written by the Welsh national hero Owain Glyn Dwr are to go on public display for the first time in an exhibition to mark the 600th anniversary of his rebellion against England.
fields.body:
Two letters written by the Welsh national hero Owain Glyn Dwr are to go on public display for the first time in an exhibition to mark the 600th anniversary of his rebellion against England.

The Pennal letters, named after the Welsh village where Glyn Dwr wrote them, were returned to Wales on loan this week from the French national archives in Paris.

Written in Latin, the letters were sent in 1406 to Charles VI, the French king. They asked for military assistance in Glyn Dwr's struggle against Henry IV of England.

The exhibition, at the National Library of Wales, in Aberystwyth, opens to the public on Saturday and runs until the end of September.

fields.headline: Privacy row on Camilla pictures
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The debate over press intrusion took a new turn yesterday with the publication of paparazzi photographs showing Camilla Parker Bowles, the Prince of Wales's companion, in a swimsuit.
fields.body:
The debate over press intrusion took a new turn yesterday with the publication of paparazzi photographs showing Camilla Parker Bowles, the Prince of Wales's companion, in a swimsuit.

Risking criticism from royal quarters, the Mirror featured a photograph of Mrs Parker Bowles on its front page under the headline "Camilla as you have never seen her". More pictures appeared inside.

The Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, would not comment on his decision to publish the pictures yesterday.

Rival newspapers took the moral high ground. The Sun and the Daily Mail confirmed they had turned down the pictures, showing Mrs Parker Bowles holidaying on a beach in Mauritius. They were taken by a well-known freelance photographer.

The Mirror stressed that the pictures were taken on a public beach. "Her tanned face beaming and her legs cellulite-free, she looks relaxed, carefree and years younger," it enthused.

Press complaints commission rules, to which all national newspapers are signed up, forbid publication of pictures which are taken on private ground without the subject's consent.

The PCC said last night that it had received no complaint. St James's Palace would not comment.

webTitle: Humanist farewell for a diamond geezer

fields.headline: Humanist farewell for a diamond geezer
fields.standfirst:
Stars turn out to mourn singer Ian Dury, who 'inspired all those around him and changed people's lives'

Ian Dury
fields.trailText: Ian, his neighbour Rainbow George said after the service, would surely have been watching somewhere with a great deal of amusement.
fields.body:
Ian, his neighbour Rainbow George said after the service, would surely have been watching somewhere with a great deal of amusement.

As family and friends said goodbye to Ian Dury, who died of cancer last week aged 57, in a humanist service at Golders Green crematorium yesterday, that seemed right.

It was not a big showbiz event, although stars were there - friends such as Robbie Williams, Neneh and Eagle-Eye Cherry, and Suggs from Madness. It was not, despite the multitude of press, a public affair. But fans who loved him but did not know him would have recognised the "diamond geezer" reflected in a service which was warm and moving and funny and emphatically London.

The Blockheads, the band that helped Dury to a number one and, for a time, the sort of mega-fame he confessed to feeling uneasy about, played a new song, You're The Why, that they had been working on when he died. His collaborator, Chas Jankel, sang the words that Dury wrote, brimmed with inimitable Blockhead lines like "then like a ton of bricks the dawn descended".

And when they finished, the assembled gathering, about 250 inside, with a further 50 or so watching on television screens outside, broke into cheers and applause.

In a funeral oration punctuated by laughter, his friend, Ronnie Harris, told how Dury never had his own credit cards or bank accounts, resisted paying the poll tax and, when living in Hammersmith, west London, moaned about paying water rates because he had the river flowing for free under him. Dury's last album, Mr Love Pants, was put on a label called Ronnie Harris Records. "It was the way he could leave me something that didn't cost anything."

When he became famous, Dury tried life uptown. "He got a flat in Baker Street, but he didn't like that. He liked the mess. He liked to be untidy and he couldn't do that being posh." But for all that, he was so proud when that success meant he could buy his mother Peggy a place in Hampstead.

The humanist officiant, Annette Furley, told how Dury, born in Harrow in May 1942, had been disabled by polio. "This didn't make life easy but he never let it stand in his way," she said. "He felt that people could do what they wanted to do if they wanted to do it enough."

"Ian said a sure way not to die a death on stage is to be magnificent," Ms Furley said. Fame with the Blockheads followed, and spells acting - "although he did admit, in his own words, that it was a load of bollocks."

Attending were Dury's children Jemima and Baxter by his first wife Betty - she and Dury remained on good terms after their divorce and until her death from cancer. Also there were his second wife, Sophy Tilson, and their children Billy, four, and Albert, two.

He fought cancer with strength and good humour, Ms Furley said. He was cracking jokes on the day he died. But what made him sad was knowing that he would not see Billy and Albert grow up. "He inspired all those around him and changed people's lives. He brought out the best in people. Many people have said they did what they did because of Ian."

Dury's coffin was carried by a black-plumed horse drawn carriage from Belsize Park, stopping off at his home in Hampstead. Jankel, John Turnbull, Norman Watts-Roy, and Mickey Gallagher from the Blockheads, and Chris Foreman and Lee Thompson from Madness, the group his London poetry inspired, were pallbearers. His coffin was draped with a black and white Blockheads logo.

After the service the Blockheads were planning to play once more, at a private wake later for Dury at the Forum in Kentish Town.

But first the mourners, also including Radio 1 DJ Annie Nightingale and cabinet minister Mo Mowlam, paused by the dozens of floral tributes brought for him. Robbie Williams told of going with Dury to Sri Lanka for Unicef.

They looked on at huge displays from Madness, a simple bouquet from Paul McCartney, one from members of the Clash, and from Ronnie Wood. There was a pint of Guinness in flowers, and for the artist-cum-pop-star, flowers for "Gene Vincent Van Gogh".

webTitle: 'Mile high' duo fined £2,250 for drunken antics

fields.headline: 'Mile high' duo fined £2,250 for drunken antics
fields.standfirst: Pair lost jobs after transatlantic brief encounter
fields.trailText: Two strangers who had a "mile high" sexual encounter during a transatlantic flight were yesterday fined a total of £2,250 for being drunk on board an aeroplane.
fields.body:
Two strangers who had a "mile high" sexual encounter during a transatlantic flight were yesterday fined a total of £2,250 for being drunk on board an aeroplane.

David Machin, 40, and Amanda Holt, 37, were arrested at Manchester airport last October after outraging fellow passengers with their drunken antics on an eight-hour American Airlines flight from Dallas to Manchester.

Machin, of Wakefield, West Yorkshire, yesterday pleaded guilty at Manchester crown court to being drunk on board a plane and was fined £1,250 plus £400 costs.

Holt, of Bacup, Lancashire, had admitted being drunk on the flight at an earlier hearing and was yesterday fined £1,000 plus £400 costs.

Further charges of outraging public decency were dropped.

The couple, who met for the first time in seats 9A and 9B on the Boeing 757, admitted working their way through two complimentary bottles of wine and numerous glasses of cognac and port in their business class seats.

Philip Curran, prosecuting, said fellow passengers saw Holt slouched across her seat and described her as having rolling eyes and smelling of drink.

One passenger, who sat nearby, saw that her blouse and trousers had been removed and, at one point, Machin had his hand in her knickers while she had her hand in his trousers.

Mr Curran told the court how one passenger, sitting in front of the couple, had heard "noises like a naughty child and meowing noises". She later turned round after being kicked by a foot dangling over her seat and was surprised to see Holt in her underwear.

Mr Curran said that when the plane landed at Manchester airport Holt denied anything had happened and Machin said: "We became a little over-familiar, that's all."

However, having sobered up the following morning, Holt immediately wrote a letter of apology to the airline.

Sentencing, Mr Justice Singer said: "They have both already been punished to a great extent. They have been punished by wide-ranging publicity in the newspapers."

Referring to the job losses of both defendants, he said: "They have both suffered considerable financial loss. Machin has lost at least £25,000. A sum probably exceeding that will have been suffered by Mrs Holt."

The judge told the defendants that the fines would have been much higher had they not already been penalised financially.

At an earlier hearing Holt's solicitor, Michael Mackey, told Manchester city magistrates court that Holt had been exhausted before boarding flight AA110 after working a 112 hour week and remembered having "a couple of glasses of wine".

"It is not for me to say that anyone took advantage of anyone else, or that anyone was the prime mover," he said. "It's clear that this defendant simply did not know what was going on - she was that intoxicated."

Pointing towards the press benches, he said: "They have already done more to this defendant than the court could ever do."

Holding up a headline from the Sun, which read: "Mile High Mandy Gets Randy on Brandy," he added: "Having put this woman on the cross they are hoping the court might hammer in a few nails.

webTitle: Nine years for Met officer turned grass

fields.headline: Nine years for Met officer turned grass
fields.trailText: A corrupt Metropolitan police detective turned supergrass was yesterday jailed for nine years at the Old Bailey.
fields.byline: Michael Sean Gillard  and Laurie Flynn
fields.body:
A corrupt Metropolitan police detective turned supergrass was yesterday jailed for nine years at the Old Bailey.

Terry McGuinness, 42, had previously pleaded guilty to nine counts of corruption spanning six years which he mostly served at the flying squad in London.

The corruption offences included burglary, conspiracy to supply 80kg of cannabis, handling stolen goods and conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.

McGuinness confessed after a sting operation by the Met's anti-corruption branch, CIB3, in December 1997.

Officers had planted 80 bars of cannabis inside a bathroom cabinet in an east London flat. Word was then leaked to a recently retired colleague of McGuinness called Kevin Garner, who was the original target of the CIB3 operation.

The men were filmed stealing the cannabis from the flat and four days later both were arrested.

In May 1998 McGuinness, who had initially denied the charges, became one of CIB3's top supergrasses as he fingered dozens of flying squad officers for alleged corruption.

More than 80 officers accused by McGuinness and Garner, who also turned supergrass, were suspended but were later told by the crown prosecution service that there would be no further action.

Both the prosecution and defence insisted that McGuinness had told the truth to CIB3 and was willing to give evidence. The CPS, however, never called McGuinness as a witness in any corruption trial.

In mitigation, his defence barrister, John Coffey, said his client had encountered a "culture of corruption" at the flying squad and wanted to "fit in" with his colleagues.

McGuinness, who is married with children, is likely to serve six years with the time he has already spent in custody counting against his sentence.

This is a heavier sentence than the one received by another CIB3 supergrass, former Met detective Neil Putnam, whose sentence was reduced from 12 years to less than four after pleading guilty and testifying against two colleagues.

The Guardian has learned from senior Met officers that they are "not happy" with the current supergrass system relied on by CIB3. The home secretary, Jack Straw, has refused a request by the Labour MP Andrew Mackinlay to launch an independent judicial inquiry into the conduct of CIB3 after a Guardian investigation last month.

It revealed that CIB3 officers were using discredited practices, including the supergrass system. CIB3 is now the subject of three internal inquiries following the collapse of four high profile trials against serving and former Met detectives. The cleared officers are not satisfied by the existing complaints procedure and point to double standards and score-settling at the heart of CIB3.

Mr Straw told Mr Mackinlay he is awaiting the outcome of a review of the police complaints procedure undertaken by international auditors and consultants KPMG in response to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.

webTitle: Newsman reveals TV deal with Blair

fields.headline: Newsman reveals TV deal with Blair
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: For a man who sets such store by protecting the privacy of his children, it was an odd request.
fields.body:
For a man who sets such store by protecting the privacy of his children, it was an odd request.

Tony Blair was so worried about an incautious remark made by his wife Cherie during an ITN interview that he made a tantalising offer. If the crew agreed not to use the interview, he would allow them to screen rare shots of his son, Euan, playing a piano at home.

The extraordinary request from Mr Blair, whose wife recently won an injunction to prevent their children's former nanny Ros Marks telling her story in a national newspaper, was made to the former ITN political editor Michael Brunson during the contest for the Labour leadership in 1994.

Mr Brunson said the future prime minister became agitated during the filming of a report on the Blairs at their home in Islington, north London, when his wife said how much she was looking forward to moving into Downing Street, even though he had not even been elected as Labour party leader.

In his autobiography Mr Brunson writes: "As we prepared to leave [Mr Blair] could no longer contain his anxieties. He quietly suggested a deal - that we could use the pictures of Euan at the piano in return for not using Cherie's remarks about No 10."

Mr Brunson, who reluctantly accepted the deal, writes that during his interview Mrs Blair "appeared to be mentally measuring up the curtains in the prime ministerial flat".

fields.headline: Trimble gives arms warning
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble yesterday issued a stark warning that the Northern Ireland peace process would be set back by years if the IRA refused to make a gesture on disarmament within the next few months.
fields.body:
David Trimble yesterday issued a stark warning that the Northern Ireland peace process would be set back by years if the IRA refused to make a gesture on disarmament within the next few months.

His gloomy remarks came as the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, attempted to inject fresh momentum into the process with an appeal to the Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein to resolve their differences by the end of next month.

The British and Irish governments, which are holding intensive talks with Northern Ireland's political parties, are to convene all-party talks in the run-up to Easter as part of a final push to reach a deal.

Mr Trimble said: "Unless we can come to a democratic resolution of our difficulties before the summer the chances of resolution afterwards are slight."

The Ulster Unionist leader added: "Unless the decommissioning issue is resolved with clarity and certainty in the next few weeks, I fear the chances of political agreement in Northern Ireland might be postponed for several years."

The former Northern Ireland first minister stressed that May 22 - the deadline for decommissioning set out in the Good Friday agreement - was a "key date".

His remarks were echoed by Mr Mandelson, who yesterday told the Commons Northern Ireland select committee that he hoped to see agreement by then.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Court looks at Ulster killings
fields.body:
Court looks at Ulster killings

The European court of human rights in Strasbourg yesterday ruled admissible claims by relatives of 12 Catholic men shot dead in incidents in Northern Ireland between 1982 and 1992. The families claim the RUC operated a shoot to kill policy and the authorities' failure properly to investigate violated the men's right to life. The court will deliver a ruling later. Clare Dyer

Inquiry into forklift accident

Safety officials yesterday agreed to investigate the death of a driver killed by the forks of a forklift truck which hit his car in Old Trafford, Manchester, in August 1997. At the high court in London the health and safety executive accepted mistakes were made in refusing an inquiry. It is to send an apology to the family of Mohammed Omar Akhtar, 20. David Ward

Back to the 60s for Diana Ross

Diana Ross is to go on a 23-city tour with two other former Supremes, although not Mary Wilson or Cindy Birdsong, who were with the group at the height of its success in the 60s.

webTitle: Query over Briton in drugs case

fields.headline: Query over Briton in drugs case
fields.trailText: Lawyers acting for a British grandmother jailed for almost seven years for trying to smuggle £500,000 worth of cocaine out of Venezuela yesterday said they believed her conviction was untenable.
fields.body:
Lawyers acting for a British grandmother jailed for almost seven years for trying to smuggle £500,000 worth of cocaine out of Venezuela yesterday said they believed her conviction was untenable.

Less than a week after being apprehended at an airport on the holiday island of Margarita while carrying eight kilos of the class A drug, Irene Campbell, 56, from Glasgow, was sentenced to six years and nine months.

Mrs Campbell, a residential carer working with under-privileged children, had previously campaigned against drugs.

Joe Beltrami, the family's lawyer, said he had no confidence in the sentence. "I am concerned about the indecent haste of this conviction - sentence within 48 hours of appearing in court."

Mrs Campbell's family claimed that she had been duped into carrying the drugs, but British consular officials in Venezuela confirmed yesterday that she had admitted attempting to smuggle the drugs and that she had a public defender at her trial.

webTitle: British women vital to Vikings' Icelandic expansion

fields.headline: British women vital to Vikings' Icelandic expansion
fields.trailText: Whether the Vikings leapt ashore on the British Isles as warriors intent on women-snatching, or whether they enticed the native maidens to their longboats with charm and roses, science cannot yet tell.
fields.body:
Whether the Vikings leapt ashore on the British Isles as warriors intent on women-snatching, or whether they enticed the native maidens to their longboats with charm and roses, science cannot yet tell.

But genetic researchers have at last confirmed one thing - that 1,100 years ago the Norse founders of Iceland, desperately short of women for their colony, took about half of their female partners from present-day Britain and Ireland.

The discovery tallies with descriptions of the settlement in the ancient Icelandic sagas - which, though described by Ted Hughes as "one of the great marvels of world literature", had been considered by some scholars to be historically unreliable.

A research team led by Agnar Helgason, of Oxford University's institute of biological anthropology, confirmed British women's perhaps involuntary role in the founding of Iceland by analysing DNA samples from present-day Icelanders. The scientists looked at mtDNA, a genetic material passed on only by women. By comparing mutations researchers can work out where ancestors are likely to have come from.

"If we try to estimate which proportion of [Icelandic] women came from Scandinavia and which from the British Isles, it looks like half and half," Mr Helgason said.

The sagas record how rebel Norwegian earls and their vassals, defeated at Hafrsfjord in AD872, set sail for a new life in Iceland - with stops in places such as Orkney and the Hebrides to pick up women.

"There was a strong Scandinavian component in the Icelandic human gene pool, but the sagas also speak of particular women coming from the British Isles, some as concubines, others as slaves," said Gisli Palsson, the head of Iceland's institute of anthropology.

Andrew Wawn, an expert on the sagas at Leeds University, defended Viking mores: "Concubinage is a feature of the sagas, but so are Victorian family values. There are plenty of exemplary nuclear families with two parents and four children."

webTitle: Chef wins £75,000 over 'drink and drugs' slur

fields.headline: Chef wins £75,000 over 'drink and drugs' slur
fields.trailText: The celebrity chef Marco Pierre White was awarded £75,000 in libel damages in the high court yesterday over a press allegation that he had a bout with drink and drugs.
fields.body:
The celebrity chef Marco Pierre White was awarded £75,000 in libel damages in the high court yesterday over a press allegation that he had a bout with drink and drugs.

Mr White, 38, who is to marry his long time partner, Mati, tomorrow, was in court with her as the jury announced their verdict in London. They found that Mr White had been defamed in an article published in the New York Times and the International Herald Tribune in May 1998.

He had sued over a "bombshell" sentence in the syndicated article alleging that he had had a "well-publicised bout with drink and drugs".

Mr White had told the court that he was angered and upset by the claim. He "very rarely" drank, having only a glass of wine "from time to time" on a social occasion. "I have never taken drugs in my life," he said. "I think it's very destructive."

The court heard that the newspapers now accepted that there was no truth in the allegation. But they argued that the article had not defamed Mr White as it had not lowered his reputation as a chef or a businessman.

The jury awarded him £15,000 against the New York Times and £60,000 against the International Herald Tribune. Mr Justice Morland ordered the newspapers to pay the entire costs of the action - on a punitive indemnity basis - estimated at £480,000.

Mr White's counsel, George Carman QC, had told the jury that the chef was the youngest person to obtain three Michelin stars, and the "only Englishman to be so honoured".

webTitle: Review group presses for tougher sex offence laws

fields.headline: Review group presses for tougher sex offence laws
fields.trailText: Ministers are considering changing the law so a man who forced a woman or another man to have oral sex could be convicted of rape.
fields.body:
Ministers are considering changing the law so a man who forced a woman or another man to have oral sex could be convicted of rape.

The proposal, from an official review set up by the Home Office, is part of a blueprint for the most radical overhaul yet of the law on sex offences in England and Wales.

The package of recommendations, expected to be published late next month or early June, was handed to Home Office ministers on Tuesday by the sex offences review steering group, which was set up in 1998 to bring the law up to date. The main statute, the Sexual Offences Act 1956, is 44 years old.

The government will consult on the proposals until later this year and a bill is expected, though not before the general election.

One of the group's main recommendations is to extend the definition of rape to include penile penetration of any orifice. Forced fellatio currently counts as indecent assault, with a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison. Making it rape will increase the maximum sentence to life imprisonment.

But the steering group has rejected suggestions - widely floated last year - that there should be different degrees of rape, depending on whether the victim knew the rapist.

Under current law, some offences can be committed only by a man, others only by a woman, and some are specifically homosexual offences. The review proposes sweeping reforms to the whole range of sexual offences to make them neutral in terms of gender and sexuality, as far as possible.

Another plank of the review aims to increase protection for children and vulnerable adults. Carers and others in a position of trust would face heavier penalties for targeting or abusing children or mentally handicapped adults.

The group also suggests creating a new offence of necrophilia, having sex with dead bodies, which is not a crime under existing law.

fields.headline: Ministers most likely
fields.standfirst:
When Blair decides who to promote into his next cabinet, loyalty, age and gender will matter as much as policy competence

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: At Tony Blair's behest the cabinet office has started "training" government ministers. So far, they have done business-school-style case studies. One looked at the Home Office's 1999 passport office fiasco. Jack Straw was taken aback to discover that civil servants were "frightened" to tell him in advance of impending disaster.
fields.body:
At Tony Blair's behest the cabinet office has started "training" government ministers. So far, they have done business-school-style case studies. One looked at the Home Office's 1999 passport office fiasco. Jack Straw was taken aback to discover that civil servants were "frightened" to tell him in advance of impending disaster.

Coming next are "audits" of ministers, for example how well they analyse policy problems. If civil servants are to be appraised for their competence, why not their bosses? The answer is that you run into constitutional problems. If civil servants or outside experts "peer-review" ministers, what price Commons accountability? We are a long way from codifying what ministers are there to do.

There is always going to be a tension between their being as politicians and their role as managers. Adam Ingram, the security minister in Northern Ireland, might get a good "objective" rating for his conduct in office; but is his real value there as a counter-weight to Peter Mandelson? Most ministers owe their jobs to a host of a-rational, non-quantifiable attributes - such as luck or a face that fits.

Prime ministers appoint on the basis of party balance as well as loyalty, age, gender and what the media say. Policy competence is well down the list. Besides, Gordon Brown's estimate of, say, Dawn Primarolo's qualities might differ from his Downing St neighbour's. Neither are reliable guides to her "merit".

Yet three years in, performance in office starts to count. Ministers now have track records. Points can be awarded for policy and performance in their departments - even if the PM and his press adviser are more impressed by how they do on the Today programme.

As the next election looms, thoughts turn to how Blair will select his next cabinet. Messages about who is good are passed along the grapevine; Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, can give Blair a more technical view of their competence.

First in the frame for promotion must be the ministers of state - excluding those in the Lords, since Blair surely cannot appoint any more peers to his cabinet. Minister of state is a step above parliamentary under-secretary. They are paid £85,983 a year (combining MP's pay and ministerial supplement) though they take only £66,294. Some are Rt Hons, which means they have been given the mini-gong of membership of the privy council, which could be a signal of their promotability.

Here are the candidates. Not many are household names: the list serves to remind us how obscure the occupants of senior political office can remain. Note how much easier it is to find out their "political" qualities - for example Ian McCartney's union and Prescottian connection - than their skills as policy-makers.

 Agriculture: Rt Hon Joyce Quin , 55, class of 87, ex-MEP. Linguist, useful in selling British beef abroad. Competence rating high but invisible in policy.

 Cabinet Office: Rt Hon Ian McCartney , 48, class of 87, Scot, English seat. Heartlands rating high. Good marks from Whitehall for assiduity if not intelligibility.

 Defence: John Spellar (armed forces), 52, class of 82, bearded ex-union official, scourge of the left. OK on TV; zero policy contribution.

 Education and employment: Rt Hon Tessa Jowell, 52, class of 92, ex-social worker. Expert in previous job as health minister, lately lost policy battles. Fabled 18-hour-a-day worker.

Rt Hon Estelle Morris , 47, class of 92, ex-comprehensive teacher. Rated by A Campbell as performer, interest groups prefer her to Blair or Blunkett - but no hint of policy disagreement with them.

 Environment, transport and the regions: Rt Hon Hilary Armstrong (local government), 54, class of 87, ex-community worker. Moderniser, solid Today performer. Liked by civil servants.

Rt Hon Michael Meacher , (environment), 60, class of 70. Survivor from Labour's Jurassic period. Formidable grasp of details, kept Greens sweet.

Nick Raynsford (housing, planning and London), 55, class of 92 (served as MP pre viously), ex-housing activist. Competence high but odium from London mayor failure may hurt.

 Foreign & Commonwealth Office: Keith Vaz (Europe), 43, class of 87, ex-lawyer. Witty, shallow, hard worker in Brussels, domestic reputation obscure.

Peter Hain (Africa), 50, elected 91. Anti apartheid, leftist. Liked by journalists, so big buzz. Speaks outside his brief.

John Battle (SE Asia, trade), 48, class of 87, ex-poverty activist, councillor. Heartlands factor, bad presentation, better in previous domestic job. Bearded.

 Health: John Denham , 46, class of 92, ex-charity worker. Poor performance over Shipman case. Moderniser; Milburn overshadows both him and_

John Hutton (social care), 44, class of 92 ex-lecturer. Competent, low visibility.

 Home: Charles Clarke (police), 49, class of 97, ex-Kinnock chief of staff. Talks politics outside brief. Says no to drugs. Competence factor high, promotability buzz.

Barbara Roche (asylum), 45, class of 92, lawyer. "Good war" over asylum. Rated in previous small business job. Uncharismatic.

Rt Hon Paul Boateng (deputy home secretary), 48, class of 87, lawyer ex-GLC member. Flashy, oddly low visibility over Lawrence.

 Northern Ireland: Rt Hon Adam Ingram , (security), 53, class of 87, Kinnockite Scot with Scottish seat. Competence high, visibility low.

 Scotland: Brian Wilson , 51, class of 87. Scot with Scottish seat, ex-journalist. Media relations temporarily bad, after temper tantrum. Little admin work; hates Scottish parliament.

 Social security: Rt Hon Jeff Rooker (pensions), 58, class of 74. Talk of running for Birmingham mayor (pooh-poohed locally). Glowing write-up in former job at agriculture. Blunt, competent veteran.

 Trade and Industry: Rt Hon Helen Liddell (energy), 49, elected 94, Scot with Scottish seat, ex-journalist, Maxwell taint. Deemed unsuccessful in previous transport job. Good presentation.

Rt Hon Richard Caborn (trade), 56, class of 83, ex-MEP, trade union official. Heartlands (Sheffield), Prescottian. Did well in previous regeneration job. Low visibility.

Patricia Hewitt (e-commerce), 51, class of 97, Kinnockite, admired for style, competence. Good at previous Treasury job.

 Treasury: Stephen Timms (financial secretary), 44, elected 94, ex-leader Newham Council. Detail man, zero profile, overshadowed by G Brown. Ditto _

Dawn Primarolo (paymaster general), 45, class of 87, ex-councillor. Survived Tory assault. Mastered tax policy details.

fields.headline: I'll be there for you
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Coronation Street (Granada) is like Tombstone these days, with customers being flung out of the Rover's Return and their hats after them.
fields.body:
Coronation Street (Granada) is like Tombstone these days, with customers being flung out of the Rover's Return and their hats after them.

Natalie, the landlady, miffed at her husband and son being murdered in swift succession, is knocking back brandy in the back room and biting the heads off anyone who says they are there for her. ("Has everyone been telling you they are there for you?" the barmaid at The Woolpack asked a bereaved boozer in Emmerdale this week.) When did people start being there for you? At the back of my grandmother's handwritten recipe book there is a selection of letters of condolence suitable for any fatality, however bizarre. They all say that perhaps in the Great Beyond we shall understand. None of them say they're there for you.

Calling the customers, as Natalie does, "A bunch of two-faced hypocrites!" is not the optimum attitude for a licensed victualler, who hopes to maximise profits. Dangerous Company (BBC 2) touched on this. Jerry Walton ran 3,000 off-licences. Less when he had shut down 300 of them. How to boost the boozing? As this engagingly frank man put it "To be honest, we hadn't a bloody clue what to do."

What he did was call in Deborah, a consultant who specializes in making staff happy using, it says here, "techniques learned from, celebrity hypnotist, Paul McKenna". (Look, am I hallucinating or was that a big, blue, inflatable duck in Deborah's office?) She found Jerry's staff lacklustre and proceeded to buff them up to an almost unbearable brilliance.

The can-do course involved a lot of bonding. Bottoms Up hugged Victoria Wine. The prettier the employee, the longer they were likely to be hugged. There were encouraging lists. "Winston Churchill, Charles Darwin, WB Yeats, Hans Christian Andersen, Leonardo da Vinci. These were all people who were classed as failures!"

(It is true that Yeats failed to get the Chair of English he applied for at Trinity College, Dublin. Possibly because he spelled it Proffessership.)

The staff took to this like big, blue ducks. In no time they were breaking planks with their bare hands and making a blob of bluetack on a string swing by the power of the mind alone. The effect was almost evangelical. As Walton said "You come out of it very 'Hey! I can do this!'" Sad that he was sacked.

In their next series Dangerous Company can tackle the recent changes at the BBC. Can't they?

I took against You've Been Trained (Modern Times, BBC 2) quite quickly. The nudge-nudge commentary ("Half of British adults spend less than an hour a week doing it. Twenty per cent never do it at all") was punctuated with orgasmic groaning.

"It" was exercise. Jonathan, Jessica and Tracey all acquired personal trainers. The relationship is not, in fact, unlike a love affair, tending to go through a bumpy bit in the middle. Jonathan, piqued at his trainer's perceived neglect, told him that, if he were a girlfriend, It Would Be All Over.

It was Tracey's relationship with The Major which proved most successful. The Major was a sinewy ex-army PT instructor. Where he wasn't creviced, he was taut. His course involved a great deal of shouting, sprinting, squatting and doing really odd things with balls, like putting your head on them and rotating.

Tracey took against all this in spades and retired to bed feeling frail. She said "I'm very apprehensive about carrying on. I don't like being shouted at At All. It really, really annoyed me. If I'd wanted to be in the army, I'd have joined the army." The Major said she was a bit of a wimp.

With great reluctance she went on his outward bound course in Wales. Welsh hills, one could not but notice, are all bones. Not an once of superfluous fat on one of them. On the mountain it all seemed to come together for Tracey like a revelation. Exhilarated she rang her mother from the peak. "I'm really chuffed! I feel wonderful! Amazing!" Or as Cagney put it ,"Top of the world, ma!"

For £260 Tracey stood under a Welsh waterfall smiling in a mist of deliciousness. Jonathan spent nearly £1,000, lost four centimetres off his bottom and took to riding a bicycle with a baseball cap back to front. Jessica spent £700, found drinking was a barrier to fitness and gave up fitness.

webTitle: Work in progress: Lynne Ramsay, film director

fields.headline: Work in progress: Lynne Ramsay, film director
fields.standfirst: Interview by Jenny Madden
fields.trailText: Right now, I'm one or two drafts away from finishing the script for my next film Morvern Callar. I started it two years ago and it could have been finished sooner if it weren't for Ratcatcher and for the fact that I'm not a disciplined person. A typical day will find me getting up too late, getting in a mad panic, drinking seven cups of coffee, smoking loads of fags and then deciding to hoover the carpet, paint the walls or watch Neighbours - anything to avoid writing. Luckily Liana, my co-writer, is organised and the script is finally coming together enough for me to start thinking about casting for the lead part.
fields.body:
Right now, I'm one or two drafts away from finishing the script for my next film Morvern Callar. I started it two years ago and it could have been finished sooner if it weren't for Ratcatcher and for the fact that I'm not a disciplined person. A typical day will find me getting up too late, getting in a mad panic, drinking seven cups of coffee, smoking loads of fags and then deciding to hoover the carpet, paint the walls or watch Neighbours - anything to avoid writing. Luckily Liana, my co-writer, is organised and the script is finally coming together enough for me to start thinking about casting for the lead part.

Morven is a really brilliant female character because she's immoral, exciting and never analyses herself or her behaviour. She's not an easy character to like - and that's interesting for a woman. I'm looking for someone between 18 and 21 to play her - someone a bit left-of-centre, not conventionally beautiful, ideally with that kind of not-of-this-world quality that Sissy Spacek had. I love Christina Ricci but, as Morvern is Scottish, I'm sure there would be an uproar if I had an American play her!

There are other well known actresses I'd like to see for the part - people like Samantha Morton, Laura Fraser and Kelly McDonald. The only thing against someone like Laura Fraser is that she's very beautiful. And Morvern is more of an oddball - a weird face. That's why I imagine finding a complete unknown to play her.

I'll probably find Morvern in an unlikely place - on the street, in a cafe, on a bus. It's funny - sometimes when you approach people they get freaked out but occasionally you'll find a gem who's unselfconscious in front of the camera.

It'll be about two years before Morvern is released, and people have warned me that the critics will be much harder on me second time around, but I suppose it comes with the territory. I'll just have to try to do the best I can with it.
