webTitle: Experts predict huge eruption at Mount Usu

fields.headline: Experts predict huge eruption at Mount Usu
fields.standfirst: Volcanic activity reports
fields.trailText: Japanese authorities issued masks, goggles and helmets to residents near the rumbling Mount Usu volcano yesterday amid growing fears of landslides and another eruption more devastating than anything seen so far.
fields.body:
Japanese authorities issued masks, goggles and helmets to residents near the rumbling Mount Usu volcano yesterday amid growing fears of landslides and another eruption more devastating than anything seen so far.

Craters on Mt Usu on the northern island of Hokkaido have been belching huge plumes of smoke since the eruption on Friday, the first in 22 years, but scientists warned that the real fireworks may be yet to come.

Huge cracks have appeared around the base of the 2,400ft mountain, swallowing houses and damaging buildings, as magma pushes close to the earth's surface.

Professor Hiromu Okada from Hokkaido University said this indicated the rapid formation of a new lava dome, which was likely to rise up with explosive force in the next one or two weeks to form a new mountain.

Unlike the weekend eruptions, this could create the most dangerous of volcanic phenomena: a flow of superheated ash, gas and molten rock.

"I am more scared of the new cracks that have been discovered over the past few days," an official at the meteorological agency said. "It is possible that an explosion, blowing off the whole area, could occur."

In the nearby town of Sobetsu, town officials began distributing goggles and masks to protect residents against clouds of ash, the longest of which stretched more than 12 miles from the mountain.

Schoolchildren were given helmets to protect them from the flying rocks that are likely to fly through the air if the mountain blows again. NHK news said it had found a huge boulder that flew hundreds of meters at the weekend.

Yesterday huge mudslides, a mixture of volcanic ash and rock, began flowing down the mountain slopes towards the hot spring resort of Akira Miura.

Officials warned that the 1.6 inches of rain expected overnight could further dislodge the loose volcanic ash, rock and debris that has accumulated on the mountain's slopes over the past few days.

By early evening, television footage taken from helicopters showed huge streams flowing down the smoking sides of Mt Usu into channels built after the last eruption in 1978.

Although the towns at the foot of the mountain are now deserted, evacuees feared that the channels would burst and their homes would be ruined.

More than 15,000 people have been evacuated from a 16,000 acre zone around Mt Usu since the volcano showed signs of activity last week.

Thousands are living in gymnasiums and public halls, waiting for the all clear so that they can go back to their homes, farms and offices.

But there is no sign that they will be able to do so any time soon. In 1943 - the last time Mt Usu experienced such intense geological activity - there were more than 10 powerful explosions over a four-month period before the mountain settled down.

Even if people eventually return, it is unlikely that they will ever feel the same about living in the shadow of a volcano.

"You see the smoke rising, and you realise that the mountain is a living thing," one resident, Matsue Takahata, said. "It's frightening."

webTitle: Why the cracks in the volcano's slopes warn of total devastation explosion

fields.headline: Why the cracks in the volcano's slopes warn of total devastation explosion
fields.standfirst: Volcanic activity reports
fields.trailText: The plume of ash roiling into the air out of Mount Usu looks awesome enough. But it is all the more fearful when you realise that Usu is a mere junior branch of a much larger volcano, Toya, on whose rim it lies.
fields.body:
The plume of ash roiling into the air out of Mount Usu looks awesome enough. But it is all the more fearful when you realise that Usu is a mere junior branch of a much larger volcano, Toya, on whose rim it lies.

Fortunately, there now seems little chance of a repeat of the gigantic eruption which ripped open the earth's crust where Toya lies, leaving a lake.

But Toya's power lives on in the regular eruptions of smaller volcanoes like Usu. What Japanese scientists, admired as some of the world's most experienced volcano-watchers, now fear is a fresh explosion leading to the devastating phenomenon known as "pyroclastic flow."

The danger signs are the cracks appearing on the slopes of the volcano below where the most recent explosions have taken place.

This suggests that the molten rock just beneath the surface - called magma when it is inside the volcano, lava when it it outside - is forming a lava dome, a cap of hardening rock plugging the efforts of the magma to burst out.

It is this build-up of pressure, combined with rock falling off the steepening sides of the lava dome, which could be violently released by a new explosion and a pyroclastic flow.

This is an avalanche of hot gas, rock and ash which races from the flanks of the volcano down neighbouring river valleys at speeds of up to 90mph, laying waste to any people, animals or vegetation unfortunate enough to be in its path.

Moving above and with the avalanche is an "ash cloud surge", a cloud of superheated ash which can spread destruction far beyond the main flow.

The devastation is sudden and unpredictable, if localised, hence the need for evacuation.

Between 1995 and 1997, the growth and collapse of lava domes and the subsequent explosions and pyroclastic flows from the Soufriere Hills volcano devastated entire communities and the airport on the island of Montserrat.

Residents, who were ordered to retreat in successive evacuations, were stunned - the volcano had not erupted in 400 years.

Mount Usu's rumblings come as less of a surprise - the volcano last erupted 22 years ago.

webTitle: Heritage threat Penang's colonial capital faces developers

fields.headline: Heritage threat Penang's colonial capital faces developers
fields.trailText: Up to 2,000 families on the Malaysian island of Penang may be forced to move out of one of the region's largest collections of historic buildings, opening the way for the bulldozers and concrete mixers.
fields.body:
Up to 2,000 families on the Malaysian island of Penang may be forced to move out of one of the region's largest collections of historic buildings, opening the way for the bulldozers and concrete mixers.

"There's going to be a very quick spate of demolitions and evictions," warned Khoo Salma Nasution of the Penang Heritage Trust, which has been fighting to preserve the original character of Georgetown's 12,000 pre-war buildings.

Founded in 1786 by Sir Francis Light, Penang's capital, Georgetown, pre-dates Singapore as the first straits settlement of the East India Company; a British trading post for spices and a refuge from pirates.

Today it is a haven for more than 3m tourists who come every year to walk around its white stucco colonial mansions, rows of tiled Chinese shophouses, ornate clan houses guarded by stone dragons and its jumble of old temples, churches and mosques (right).

Already included on a United Nations list of the world's 100 most endangered sites, Georgetown's old buildings have been protected for the past three decades by legislation which kept rents artificially low. Elderly tenants, descended from the artisans, sailors and traders who flocked to Penang in the 18th and 19th centuries, continued to live in the dilapidated buildings undisturbed by the frenzy of construction elsewhere which fuelled Malaysia's impressive economic growth.

In January the Rent Control Act was lifted and rents shot up for 16,000 households. "We want the government to know we have had enough. We are fed up," said local resident Lee Pay Long at a night of protest. About a hundred frail, elderly tenants facing imminent eviction braved the uniformed police and special branch.

"The psyche is still that they are scared of the government," says Mr Lee who describes this sort of protest as "a new thing in Malaysian society".

Led by a longhaired, vegetarian restaurateur known as Organic Ong, who has already been detained for five days without charge, the timid crowd watches as red and white banners are painted saying: "Save Georgetown from becoming a Ghost Town."

Penang's state government sees its role as mediating between conservationists and developers. "It's not realistic to say Georgetown should not change at all," said the chief minister, Koh Tsu Koon, who believes in "adaptive re-use" of old buildings.

"Basically we've run out of time," said Khoo Salma of the Penang Heritage Trust. "Once the tenants move out the next step is the bulldozers come in."

Already in Beach Street six Chinese shophouses dating back to the 1780s are being demolished to make way for a modern commercial building in what is supposed to be a conservation area.

Tan Kee Chai runs a wholesale business importing religious artefacts from China in a building scheduled for demolition. "My heart is troubled because I have always lived here," he said.

"Can you help us," pleaded his 70-year-old father, Tan Ching Eng, who breaks down in tears at the thought of moving away from his friends and neighbours into low cost housing in the suburbs.

fields.headline: Cattle plague threatens Korean economy
fields.standfirst: Farmers fear foot and mouth disease was brought on yellow wind from China
fields.trailText: A deadly plague of foot and mouth disease, believed to be carried by the wind, is threatening to decimate Korea's livestock industry.
fields.body:
A deadly plague of foot and mouth disease, believed to be carried by the wind, is threatening to decimate Korea's livestock industry.

In the past week, the government has closed cattle markets, sealed off affected areas and begun the slaughter of infected animals. But farmers fear that conventional quarantine methods are not enough to contain the apparently air-borne virus.

The highly contagious disease, which does not affect humans, is often described as the "black plague for livestock" and was last seen in Korea in 1934.

It reappeared last month in cattle in Paju, 18 miles north of Seoul, soon after the area was buffeted by one of the yellow dust storms that blow in from China.

Since then, the disease has spread rapidly to the country's main farming region of Poryong, prompting the government to set up an emergency taskforce to try to halt a nationwide epidemic.

"This week will be a critical period that will determine the development of the epidemic," said an official of the National Veterinarian and Quarantine Service.

Officials have slaughtered and buried 255 pigs and cows and closed 85% of the country's cattle markets. Roadblocks established in a 12-mile radius of the affected areas check vehicles and fumigate them before allowing them through.

In a race to beat the disease, agriculture officials have be gun injecting cattle with vaccines, many of which have been imported from Britain.

"If there are more outbreaks of suspected foot and mouth disease in other areas, emergency measures to contain the disease could last until June," a ministry official said.

"We plan to inject vaccine to 11m head of livestock in Korea step by step, beginning in the western coastal areas."

Neighbouring Japan has suffered its first cases of the disease since 1908 at a small farm in Miyazaki, a well-known beef-producing region in the south-west of the country.

Australia, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore have banned imports from both countries.

The infection is believed to have come from northern China, which suffered an outbreak of foot and mouth late last year. Although some experts claim it was carried by humans or infected hay, the main finger of blame has been pointed at the yellow dust winds from the Gobi and Taklamakan deserts.

South Koreans have long lived in terror of these winds, which usually hit the country about four times a year but have become more intense and frequent because of the desertification of northern China.

Known as "spring's uninvited guest", the storms cause visibility problems for airline pilots, and damage machinery. They are blamed for acid rain and respiratory problems because they contain so many pollutants from Chinese factories.

Although the dust takes three or four days to cross the Western Sea, scientists say the foot and mouth virus can survive because of the temperature and humidity of the winds.

If the disease is indeed carried through the air, the epi demic will be difficult to halt. "How can we control something that is in the air?" asked one government official.

Farmers involved in South Korea's nearly £2bn livestock industry fear a repeat of the foot and mouth epidemic that struck Taiwan in 1997, prompting the slaughter of more than 3m pigs. The country's agriculture as a whole accounts for around 6% of GDP.

South Korea does not export beef, but does export pork. Exporters had set a target of $400m for pork sales this year, almost all of it headed for Japan.

"If the outbreak spreads nationwide, the impact on Korea's livestock and related industries will be harsher than the financial crisis of late 1997," an industry source told local newspapers.

Little is known about how the disease is affecting North Korea, which is already suffering an acute food shortage.

webTitle: Japan's new PM faces up to a killing workload

fields.headline: Japan's new PM faces up to a killing workload
fields.standfirst:
Overworked former leader said to be all right when already in coma

Japanese PM's office
fields.trailText: Japan got a new prime minister yesterday as a picture began to emerge of the gruelling work schedule and callous political calculations that may have contributed to the sudden collapse of his predecessor, Keizo Obuchi.
fields.body:
Japan got a new prime minister yesterday as a picture began to emerge of the gruelling work schedule and callous political calculations that may have contributed to the sudden collapse of his predecessor, Keizo Obuchi.

In an unusually swift transfer of power, Yoshiro Mori, a veteran of the ruling Liberal Democratic party, won approval from his party and both houses of parliament and was sworn in by the emperor to replace Mr Obuchi, who has been in a coma since suffering a stroke on Sunday.

"I have been praying for the prime minister's recovery," Mr Mori said in accepting the party presidency. "I will do my best to live up to the nation's expectations."

Although Mr Mori said his main priority will be to hoist Japan out of a decade-long economic rut, one of his first challenges will be to answer the growing suspicion that the ruling party's handling of his predecessor's illness was deceitful and undemocratic.

In a bungled cover-up on Sunday, the government waited 22 hours before revealing that Mr Obuchi was in hospital. During that time, aides told reporters that the prime minister was going about his normal duties. Late Sunday evening, the government senior spokesman, Mikio Aoki, said at a brusque four-minute press conference that Mr Obuchi was in hospital suffering from exhaustion, though by that time he had already slipped into a coma.

Until now, the government has explained its actions by saying that aides panicked and officials wanted to be sure of the prime minister's condition before making a statement.

Yesterday, however, the prime minister's spokesman, Akitaka Saiki, admitted a more cynical motive was behind the cover-up.

Asked why Mr Obuchi was taken to hospital in a private car without an adequate contingent of bodyguards, Mr Saiki said: "The prime minister's health has an immediate impact on politics. That, I think, is the main reason. The prime minister's aides wanted the minimum of information to be provided to people outside the main circle," he said.

This candid admission raises the suspicion that Mr Obuchi's security - and possibly his health - were compromised in an attempt to hide the problem from the public ahead of a general election which must be called by October.

Questions remain about whether the LDP "shadow shoguns" were party to the decision to take the prime minister to hospital without an ambulance or a full security detail.

According to the official line, no one in government or the LDP knew of the prime minister's whereabouts until five hours later. Such an explanation is incredible given Mr Obuchi's character - a party loyalist who rarely makes a move on his own - and the immediate threat of the Mount Usu volcano, which had erupted on Friday.

Details also emerged yesterday of the punishing schedule that the 62-year-old prime minister, who has a heart pacemaker, followed after taking power in July 1998.

Mr Saiki said that his boss has not taken a holiday since a two-day break last August and had barely half an hour to himself each day, which he usually spent reading the newspapers.

Mr Obuchi reportedly slept for only four or five hours a day and would often wake in the middle of the night to pore over official papers, especially since the eruption of Mt Usu.

This crushing workload has a familiar echo in Japan, where courts, the government and the media have recently begun to accept the growing dangers posed by karoshi (death by overwork).

Mr Obuchi may yet recover, but his experience should provide a lesson for Mr Mori.

"We all tried to tell him to take a half-hour or an hour's break. We wanted him to relax," said Mr Saiki. "He was exhausted with overwork. He was a very hardworking premier."

fields.headline: Kenya's coffee wars spread
fields.trailText: Mwangi Githendu might not know much about politics but drumming his fist on the table to emphasise his point, he insists: "I know when I'm being cheated."
fields.body:
Mwangi Githendu might not know much about politics but drumming his fist on the table to emphasise his point, he insists: "I know when I'm being cheated."

It's hard to imagine this kindly old man with his wispy grey beard and permanent smile as a leader of a violent peasants' revolt, but that is what he has become.

Widespread corruption and mismanagement have driven Kenya's coffee industry toward collapse and thousands of coffee farmers like Mr Githendu over the edge.

"I decided one day that enough was enough. It was time to fight back," says Mr Githendu, who armed himself with a bow and some arrows and marched with hundreds of other farmers on the Mutitu coffee factory, which processes his coffee beans, and forcibly evicted the union officials who he says have been cheating farmers for years.

Anger among coffee farmers has become so widespread that the actions of Mr Githendu and his colleagues have been repeated throughout Kenya's coffee-growing heartland in recent months.

The farmers' quarrel is chiefly with corrupt union officials who have developed a complex web of bureaucracy which channels proceeds from the sale of coffee through union bank accounts, where the money is held indefinitely accruing interest.

By employing a credit system to supply the farmers with essential fertilisers and pesticides, the unions have further tied the farmer to a system of dependency and debt.

"They pay us whatever is left after they have paid themselves and their friends," says Muri Kahunyo, Mr Githendu's neighbour. In 1999 Mr Kahunyo produced over 1,000kg of coffee. He should have received at least $1,000 but ended up with less than $200.

Coffee farming is no longer the ticket out of poverty that it promised to be during the boom of the late 70s and early 80s.

"We used to call coffee the Black Gold," says Mr Kahunyo, "Now it seems like a poison."

Farmers made persistent efforts to open dialogue with the union but their approaches were consistently rebuffed.

"That's why we took action. Nothing else would have saved us or our families," said Mr Githendu.

Kenya's Central province, where almost all the coffee is grown, is a bastion of the political opposition but they show little sign of getting involved in the coffee wars. "The politicians have done nothing to help us," says one farmer, "because they are being paid a share by the unions."

In the mid 80s Kenya produced 130,000 tonnes of coffee. By the end of the 90s that figure had fallen to a little over 50,000 tonnes.

John Irungu, the public relations officer for the Coffee Board of Kenya (CBK), which oversees the sale of Kenyan coffee, said that after all deductions, the farmer should receive 80% of the sale price - between $1 and $3 a kilo.

Recognising the scale of mismanagement, the government last week appointed new directors to the CBK to reform of the industry.

But they will have their work cut out. Hezron Nyangito of the Kenya Public Policy Research Institute says: "It is within the societies that the problems lie and if they are to be overcome then the unions must be brought to heel."

webTitle: 'Conflict of interest' in GM food report

fields.headline: 'Conflict of interest' in GM food report
fields.standfirst: Critics dispute claim that modified crops present no risk
fields.trailText: In a report published yesterday the US National Academy of Sciences called for more stringent checks on genetically modified (GM) crops but concluded that there was no evidence that the new foods presented a threat to health.
fields.body:
In a report published yesterday the US National Academy of Sciences called for more stringent checks on genetically modified (GM) crops but concluded that there was no evidence that the new foods presented a threat to health.

US environmentalists criticised the report, which is intended to provide a scientific basis for government regulatory policy. They questioned its finding that there was no "strict distinction" between the risks posed by GM and by conventionally bred foods, and argued that the experts conducting the study had been compromised by their links with the biotechnology industry.

With an estimated 70m acres of US land planted with GM crops last year, the economic interests at stake are considerable. GM seed producers, distributors and food retailers have been under pressure since a European-led backlash against the technology. The Grocery Manufacturers of America welcomed the report, arguing that it "reinforces longstanding analysis that the technology is safe."

The academy's panel of experts, consisting of academic scientists, a lawyer and an environmentalist, focused on plants that had been genetically manipulated to make them resistant to pests.

Perry Adkisson, the committee chairman, said: "We found no strict distinction between the health and environmental risks posed by plants modified through modern genetic engineering techniques and those modified by conventional breeding practices.

"In other words, the breeding process is not the issue; it is the product that should be the focal point of regulation and public scrutiny. That is, just because a plant is trangenic doesn't make it dangerous," Prof Adkisson said.

He said that both GM plants and conventional hybrids bred to resist pests could have an unintended impact on other insects, but added that "the impact is likely to be smaller than that from chemical pesticides".

However, the panel recommended that further research be carried out on the effect of GM crops on biodiversity, and more studies on the threat that pest-resistance could be passed on to weeds.

The report found that the transfer of genes between plants could lead to a concentration of toxins in crops.

Its conclusion that there was no inherent difference between GM and conventional crops was attacked by environmentalists, who argue that the artificial methods used to persuade plant cells to accept DNA from quite different species, pose special risks.

"They are saying that as long as these crops are the same as unmodified foods, we are not going to regulate, and we are not going to label them as different," Andrew Kimbrell, the director of the Centre for Food Safety, said.

"If we were not planting and eating this food, it would be OK to talk about more research. But this report means the US public will remain a guinea pig for these foods without a choice in the matter."

Critics said the report's cred ibility was undermined by the fact that most of the 12 panel members had some professional link with the biotechnology industry.

One of the study's directors, Michael Phillips, left the panel's staff at short notice in July, seven months into the study, to take a job as a Washington lobbyist for the GM trade lobby, the Biotechnology Industry Organisation (BIO).

In a letter to the academy, Dennis Kucinich, a Democratic congressman from Ohio, said four committee members received research funds from GM companies such as Monsanto, Novartis and Pioneer Hi-Bred. He pointed out that two others had worked as a lawyer and as an adviser to the biotech industry.

The report's conclusions, Mr Kucinich said, "are tainted by pervasive conflicts of interest among its authors".

The National Academy of Sciences acknowledged there were conflicts of interests among some committee members, but William Colglazier, executive director, said: "We felt their experience would be invaluable to the committee...We reject claims that their conclusions are tainted."

webTitle: Seattle hosts new Jimi Hendrix experience

fields.headline: Seattle hosts new Jimi Hendrix experience
fields.standfirst: Architect Frank Gehry tunes into guitar legend for music museum in Seattle
fields.trailText: In many ways, Frank O Gehry is to architecture what Jimi Hendrix was to rock music - a wild, original, creative genius with a giddy, international appeal. So it is only fitting that he should be the man to design yet another extraordinary building that is, in part, a memorial to the late guitarist.
fields.body:
In many ways, Frank O Gehry is to architecture what Jimi Hendrix was to rock music - a wild, original, creative genius with a giddy, international appeal. So it is only fitting that he should be the man to design yet another extraordinary building that is, in part, a memorial to the late guitarist.

In June, the Experience Music Project (EMP) in Seattle will finally open its doors. Unless it is plagued by unforeseen glitches, it promises to be yet another triumph for the Los Angeles architect who has rewritten the rule book.

For more than four decades, the Toronto-born Gehry, 70, has been creating eclectic buildings described by architectural critic Paul Goldberger in the New York Times as "from an aesthetic standpoint among the most profound and brilliant works of architecture of our time".

The idea for the $100m (£61m) Seattle project came from Paul Allen, the billionaire who co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates in 1975 and was the company's executive vice-president until 1983. He now owns a raft of digital communications businesses, radio stations and the Portland Trail Blazers basketball team.

Mr Allen was always a Hendrix fan and has what he believes to be the largest collection of Hendrix memorabilia in the world. Part of the aim of the EMP, an interactive music museum, was to pay homage to Hendrix - who died at the age of 28 in 1970 - in particular and to rock music in general, including all its influences from jazz and blues to hip-hop and rap.

Gehry, famous for his "chaotically ordered" style, which he has described as being like a "cocktail party" of ideas and materials, was the obvious choice as architect.

Mr Allen told Gehry that he fancied something "swoopy" and something swoopy is what he got. Gehry, a classical music lover, immersed himself in Hendrix's music before starting work and bought himself a bunch of electric guitars, which he cut up and used as a basis for the design. Perhaps not surprisingly, the colours of the EMP building are essentially those of electric guitars.

At its highest, the EMP will rise to a not-quite-sky-kissing 26m (85ft) and incorporate 13,006 sq metres (140,000 sq ft) of space to house nine different "icons": the Sky Church, which will act as concert hall at night and gathering place by day; Crossroads, the main exhibit area with everything from Quincy Jones's trumpet to Kurt Cobain's handwritten song lyrics; the Sound Lab; the multi-media Artist's Journey; the Virtual Library; the Performance Stage, which seats 200 for masterclasses and smaller shows; the Studio; the Experience Arts Camp, which is for young people up to the age of 15 to study with musicians; and the Electric Bus, which will travel the country.

Oral histories will feature artists from guitarist Chet Atkins to Billy Bragg, from country musician Buck Owens to Ice-T.

The concert hall will have wheelchair-accessible seats available throughout the hall and not just in the front row.

"We set out to create a museum that would celebrate creativity and innovation and believed we had to be creative and innovative in the way that was accomplished," said Jody Patton, the co-founder of the project and Mr Allen's sister.

For Washington state, which has been in the wars of late, the new building comes at a good time. When Seattle hosted the World Trade Organisation last November, anti-globalisation demonstrators brought the meeting to a halt and the police lost control of the streets.

This week Washington state's iconic company, the software giant Microsoft, lost its battle with the government for violating antitrust laws and saw billions drift off its share price.

But, on June 23, the organisers of the EMP are hoping that the building, which houses a shard from the last guitar Hendrix smashed - at the Saville theatre in London -as well as the old instruments of such icons as Muddy Waters and Bo Diddley, will help to rebuild Seattle and Washington state's self-esteem.

Frank Gehry has been responsible for some of the world's most spectacular buildings. His credo is to involve the client in the design process and to make extensive use of design models at an early stage. He now uses advanced computer techniques. Among his best-known works are:

1983 Temporary Contemporary at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles

1989 Vitra Design Museum and International Manufacturing Facility, Weil am Rhein, Germany

1989 Schabel residence, Los Angeles

1992 Frederick R Wiseman art museum, Minneapolis, Minnesota

1994 The American Centre, Paris

1995 Team Disneyland administration building, Anaheim, California

1996 Nationale-Nederlanden building, Prague

1997 Guggenheim museum, Bilbao - perhaps Gehry's most famous building in Europe. Some 1.3m people visited it in its first year, more than three times the anticipated number

2000 The EMP, Seattle

2002 (projected date) Walt Disney concert hall, Los Angeles

2003 (projected date) Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass

Part of the aim of the EMP, an interactive music museum, was to pay homage to Hendrix - who died at the age of 28 in 1970 - in particular and to rock music in general, including all its influences from jazz and blues to hip-hop and rap. Gehry, famous for his "chaotically ordered" style, which he has described as being like a "cocktail party" of ideas and materials, was the obvious choice as architect. Mr Allen told Gehry that he fancied something "swoopy" and something swoopy is what he got. Gehry, a classical music lover, immersed himself in Hendrix's music before starting work and bought himself a bunch of electric guitars, which he cut up and used as a basis for the design. Perhaps not surprisingly, the colours of the EMP building are essentially those of electric guitars. At its highest, the EMP will rise to a not-quite-sky-kissing 26m (85ft) and incorporate 13,006 sq metres (140,000 sq ft) of space to house nine different "icons": the Sky Church, which will act as concert hall at night and gathering place by day; Crossroads, the main exhibit area with everything from Quincy Jones's trumpet to Kurt Cobain's handwritten song lyrics; the Sound Lab; the multi-media Artist's Journey; the Virtual Library; the Performance Stage, which seats 200 for masterclasses and smaller shows; the Studio; the Experience Arts Camp, which is for young people up to the age of 15 to study with musicians; and the Electric Bus, which will travel the country. Oral histories will feature artists from guitarist Chet Atkins to Billy Bragg, from country musician Buck Owens to Ice-T. The concert hall will have wheelchair-accessible seats available throughout the hall and not just in the front row. "We set out to create a museum that would celebrate creativity and innovation and believed we had to be creative and innovative in the way that was accomplished," said Jody Patton, the co-founder of the project and Mr Allen's sister. For Washington state, which has been in the wars of late, the new building comes at a good time. When Seattle hosted the World Trade Organisation last November, anti-globalisation demonstrators brought the meeting to a halt and the police lost control of the streets. This week Washington state's iconic company, the software giant Microsoft, lost its battle with the government for violating antitrust laws and saw billions drift off its share price. But, on June 23, the organisers of the EMP are hoping that the building, which houses a shard from the last guitar Hendrix smashed - at the Saville theatre in London -as well as the old instruments of such icons as Muddy Waters and Bo Diddley, will help to rebuild Seattle and Washington state's self-esteem. Frank Gehry has been responsible for some of the world's most spectacular buildings. His credo is to involve the client in the design process and to make extensive use of design models at an early stage. He now uses advanced computer techniques. Among his best-known works are: 1983 Temporary Contemporary at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles 1989 Vitra Design Museum and International Manufacturing Facility, Weil am Rhein, Germany 1989 Schabel residence, Los Angeles 1992 Frederick R Wiseman art museum, Minneapolis, Minnesota 1994 The American Centre, Paris 1995 Team Disneyland administration building, Anaheim, California 1996 Nationale-Nederlanden building, Prague 1997 Guggenheim museum, Bilbao - perhaps Gehry's most famous building in Europe. webTitle: Turkish coalition shaken as PM loses reform vote

fields.headline: Turkish coalition shaken as PM loses reform vote
fields.trailText: Turkey's prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said last night that his government would stay in office, despite the defeat of an important piece of legislation which he had described as crucial for his coalition and its economic reforms.
fields.body:
Turkey's prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said last night that his government would stay in office, despite the defeat of an important piece of legislation which he had described as crucial for his coalition and its economic reforms.

"Our government will continue its duty in harmony and determination," a solemn-looking Mr Ecevit told reporters. He was speaking minutes after parliament rejected a constitutional reform which would have allowed Suleyman Demirel to serve a second term as president.

Mr Ecevit had made passage of the legislation a personal priority and his political credibility will have been damaged by its defeat. The prime minister had portrayed his old rival, Mr Demirel, as a pillar of stability at a time when Turkey is trying to implement a tough economic programme agreed with the International Monetary Fund.

Supporters of Mr Demirel argued that he had become a respected international statesman who gave Turkey added influence with its western allies and neighbours in the Middle East and the Caucasus.

Critics of the president, however, took heart from opinion polls which suggested that a majority of the public wanted change at the top. Mr Demirel served as prime minister seven times before he was elected president.

Parliament was clearly not convinced that Mr Demirel was indispensable. In a rare display of political independence, dozens of deputies from the ruling coalition took advantage of a secret ballot to reject the constitutional amendment for the second time in eight days.

Now parliament will have to prepare to elect a new president by the middle of next month. Despite putting a brave face on defeat last night, government leaders fear political rivalries could put strain on the coalition as the race for the presidency develops.

Over the past few months, the government has provided an element of stability which has been sorely missed in Turkish politics for several years. But if parliament fails to elect a new president after four rounds of voting, a general election will be held. Most Turks agree that another national election is the last thing they need.

webTitle: Artist sparks row on what it means to be German

fields.headline: Artist sparks row on what it means to be German
fields.standfirst: The Reichstag
fields.trailText: Germany's MPs were last night passionately debating what to do with a trough of soil. In doing so, though, they were touching on one of the country's most divisive questions: whether German-ness should be seen as depending on race or place.
fields.body:
Germany's MPs were last night passionately debating what to do with a trough of soil. In doing so, though, they were touching on one of the country's most divisive questions: whether German-ness should be seen as depending on race or place.

The issue has been thrust into sharp relief by an artist's plans for an installation in the remodelled Reichstag.

Hans Haacke has proposed setting up a wooden container measuring 7m by 21m (23ft by 69 ft). He wants it filled with earth from each of Germany's 669 constituencies. Over the trough would be the illuminated words Der Bevölkerung , or "To the population".

The intention is plain: to highlight a link between a people and the land they inhabitant. But that is precisely the problem. More than 12% of the population is of non-German origin yet, to judge by the outrage that Mr Haacke's plans have provoked, many MPs are alarmed by anything which challenges the traditional, ethnic concept of German-ness.

That concept is often expressed with a word which features in the inscription over the entrance to the Reichstag building, dedicating it Dem Deutschen Volke (To the German people). Volk, like Heimat and Vaterland, has resonance far greater than its literal meaning. The Reichstag inscription could almost as accurately be translated as being "To the German race".

Mr Haacke's planned work is a conscious riposte to that inscription, which many Germans find disturbingly evocative of their country's nationalistic past. The words over his own intended work would be of the same design and size as those above the entrance. The work would not replace the inscription, but would be displayed inside the building.

MPs from the centre-right Christian Democrats objected to what they saw as a parody. They got up a petition against the proposal and succeeded in forcing last night's debate of the full house, despite the fact that Mr Haacke's work had twice been endorsed by the arts committee of parliament.

Others from the left have criticised the work mainly on artistic grounds, while a Hamburg art historian, Martin Warnke, argues that it is Mr Haacke who is guilty of conjuring up the racist past. He said the proposed installation brought to mind the fundamental Nazi "blood and soil" belief - that a successful country would have a people of the same race living on its own territory.

Mr Haacke, who was born in Cologne but lives in New York, is also under attack over his contribution to the Whitney Museum of American Art's Biennial exhibition, which depicts New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, as a fascist.

He claimed yesterday to be surprised by the row in Germany. He said his work was firmly grounded in the constitution which affirms the principle of equality before the law.

"The MPs have sworn an oath to uphold the constitution and ought to have an interest in seeing that the inscription ' Dem Deutschen Volke ' is not interpreted in a nationalistic way," he said.

fields.headline: Bergman contemplates suicide
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Swedish film director Ingmar Bergman said in a rare interview yesterday that he would rather commit suicide than allow his soul to be trapped inside a decaying body.
fields.body:
The Swedish film director Ingmar Bergman said in a rare interview yesterday that he would rather commit suicide than allow his soul to be trapped inside a decaying body.

"The only thing I consider appalling would be to suddenly become a vegetable and a burden on other people. A soul slowly dying out, trapped in a body in which the insides gradually sabotage me, that I think would be terrifying," Bergman, 81, said.

"But you can actually decide for yourself whether you want to go on living and I hope I have enough presence of mind to make that decision," he said in the interview to be aired on Sweden's TV4 today.

"To take your own life?" the interviewer asked.

"Certainly, and that's not idle talk on my part. For me that would be a completely natural end," said Bergman, whose films include Smiles of a Summer Night, The Seventh Seal, and Wild Strawberries.

He said that the death of his wife Ingrid in 1985 had left him indifferent about his own survival.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Reno under fire in Elian case
fields.body:
Reno under fire in Elian case

Between 30 and 50 protesters gathered yesterday outside the south Florida home of the US attorney general, Janet Reno, as relatives of Elian Gonzalez and immigration officials debated how the boy should be reunited with his father.

Some carried signs depicting Ms Reno as a devil. "You might as well send Elian back to the ocean and let him die there," one protester shouted. "President Clinton is responsible for this." AP, Miami

Hunting dogs on rampage in zoo

Hunting dogs broke into the zoo of Vigo in Spain and killed antelopes, deer and a kangaroo, zoo authorities said yesterday.

Police suspect poachers let the dogs in as training for hunting, city councillor Amador Fernandez said. AP, Vigo

'Assassins' extradited

An Argentine judge ordered the extradition of two Paraguayans suspected of the assassination of their country's vice president, Luis Maria Argana, authorities said yesterday.

The two men, Fidencio Vega Barrios and Luis Alberto Rojas, were detained in Buenos Aires. Argana's murder last march led to the downfall of Paraguay's president. AP, Buenos Aires

webTitle: Europe bans cosmetics testing on animals

fields.headline: Europe bans cosmetics testing on animals
fields.trailText: Europe's top cosmetic firms are to be banned from testing their products on live animals, the European commission announced last night. Animal rights groups say the move will save an estimated 38,000 laboratory animals a year.
fields.body:
Europe's top cosmetic firms are to be banned from testing their products on live animals, the European commission announced last night. Animal rights groups say the move will save an estimated 38,000 laboratory animals a year.

The ban will be a bitter blow to the multi-billion pound French and Italian perfume and cosmetic manufacturers who regularly use animal skin and eye tests on new products.

Among the companies affected are L'Oréal, Procter and Gamble, and Laboratoire Garnier, a French group which produces a range of cosmetics in several countries.

Mark Watts MEP, Labour's spokesman on animal welfare said he was pleased that at last testing in Europe has been banned. He said: "There can be no justification for painful skin tests on rabbits or testing burning eye drops on mice, for luxury products which can be tested in other ways."

But he said he was very disappointed at the lack of a blanket ban on the sale of cosmetics which had been tested on animals. The ban had been due to come into force in July this year, but Brussels now says it would breach international trade rules.

Mr Watts called the proposed ban on the testing of cosmetic products on animals "half-baked and wholly inadequate", and said that multinational companies would merely be able to shift labs outside Europe and carry on as before.

The commission said in a statement last night: "On the one hand, animal testing of cosmetics is necessary to ensure that cosmetic products are safe for humans. On the other hand animals rights groups claim that animals are tortured for the sake of unnecessary human vanity. Validated alternatives to animal testing must now be used."

The statement explained that, as currently drafted, the proposed Cosmetics Directive would ban the marketing in the EU of all cosmetic products containing ingredients tested on animals.

It would therefore affect products from non-EU countries: "This would appear to raise certain difficulties in relation to the World Trade Organisation," said the statement.

Labelling would now need to be developed so the consumer was clear whether the cosmetics being purchased had been tested on animals.

The UK banned the testing of cosmetics on animals shortly after Labour came to power but the main manufacturing and lab testing is done on mainland Europe. The EU first proposed a ban in 1993 but has put it off twice to allow the industry to develop alternative testing methods. It will now come into force in June this year.

Animal welfare groups have repeatedly urged Brussels not to delay the marketing ban again, but the proposed compromise is seen by the commission as solving the problem of how to protect animal welfare while also respecting the EU's World Trade Organisation obligations.

A ban on testing of finished cosmetic products on animals would come in as soon as the new directive was introduced into member states' law, while a ban on testing of cosmetic ingredients would follow three years after that.

fields.headline: When faith fails
fields.standfirst: A six-month-old baby has died after his parents, who were firm believers in homeopathy, refused to take him to a GP. Dr Ann Robinson on the dangers of trusting too much
fields.trailText: A six-month-old baby has died after his parents, who were firm believers in homeopathy, refused to take him to a GP. Dr Ann Robinson on the dangers of trusting too much
fields.body:
With a few harrowing exceptions, most parents want the best for their child, but parenting isn't an exact science. We may seek advice from professionals, consult published information, listen to friends and even take heed of what our own parents have to say, but ultimately, whether it's deciding whether to give the MMR jab, choosing a school, or signing our consent for the child to have her tonsils removed, we are forced to trust our instincts and hope for the best.

Now a tragic case in South London highlights how potentially dangerous following your instincts can be. An inquest heard how a six month old baby, Cameron Ayrs, died from a rare but potentially treatable metabolic disorder after his parents refused to take him to a doctor.

The baby's parents, Jeremy, a homeopathic doctor, and his French wife Sylvie, a sales manager, had decided to protect their child from "suppressive" conventional medicine because of their deep faith in homeopathy and naturopathy. The coroner was told that they did not immunise him against a number of common childhood diseases and that he was never taken to see a GP.

Last May, Mr Ayres took Cameron to a homeopath because he was concerned by the child's constant crying and failure to smile. The homeopath, Rita McGovern, who is also a state enrolled nurse, says that she told Ayres to take Cameron to a doctor. "It was a difficult consultation," she told the inquest. "The baby was screaming continually. I felt Mr Ayres was unhappy that I was not alternative enough. I suggested that he try conventional cream for Cameron's nappy rash but he said: 'No, that is very suppressive'."

Mr Ayres did not seek help from a doctor, however, and Cameron died two weeks later, an hour after being taken to the casualty department at Kingston Hospital, south-west London, with a swollen stomach, swollen testicles, extensive nappy rash and an enlarged liver.

The parents will not be prosecuted ("insufficient grounds", according to the Crown Prosecution Service) but Professor Peter Clayton, an expert in child health at Great Ormond Street Hospital, told the inquest: "I feel that if medical advice had been sought then the outcome would have been different."

It turns out that Cameron was born with a hereditary condition known as an "in-born error in metabolism", seen in less than one in 10,000 births. He probably either suffered an intolerance to fructose, the natural sugar present in fruit and vegetables, or there was a defect in the way his body burnt up fat for energy. Both illnesses can be treated by following a specific diet and avoiding long periods without carbohydrates - but only if they're diagnosed, of course.

Although the actions of the baby's parents may have been relatively extreme, in that most people do go to the doctor when their child is unwell however suspicious they may be of conventional medicine, this case has implications for us all. The fact is that the days when the doctor tells us what's good for us and our kids, and we listen and obey, are long gone. Nowadays we all know what doctors have always been taught at medical school: that medicines and treatments can cause harm as well as doing good and the best one can hope for is that the good outweighs the bad.

Today scepticism, and the fear that we are not being told the full story, often drive people to seek advice from sources other than their local doctor, whether it's from an alternative practitioner, a book or the web. As a practising GP, I sometimes feel that if people were as sceptical of information they print off the internet, as they are of anything I tell them, it would be a far more level playing field.

Things have not been helped by the Harold Shipman case, of course, and the inquiry into the poor performance of Bristol's paediatric heart surgeons has also led to a public realisation that some doctors perform better than others, and it's a matter or luck and postal code where you end up. And then of course there's our personal experience of doctors. A patient told me yesterday that she had just discovered that her private gynaecologist was barred from working in the NHS, and later struck off for abusing drugs. She continued to see him while he was still in private practice, however, blissfully unaware that he was under investigation and suspended from his NHS hospital.

So it's not really a mystery that we choose to treat ourselves, that we are flocking to complementary therapists in unprecedented numbers and that we put our trust in practitioners such as homeopaths rather than visiting our GP. We may treat our children ourselves or take them to the complementary practitioners with us simply because we don't want them to have antibiotics (all that we will be offered by the GP) but get concerned when they have one cold after another or seem unwell. Or we may choose to use alternative therapies at every step, abandoning all conventional approaches to healthcare.

Not that there's anything intrinsically wrong with alternative therapies and ideas per se. Homeopathy is a complete therapeutic system that aims to cure like with like. Developed by a German physician more than 200 years ago, it uses very dilute remedies of animal, vegetable and mineral origin. In the past 10 years there have been three major reviews of hundreds of well controlled trials which have shown that homeopathy is more effective than placebos and that the remedies certainly do no harm (more than can be said for many conventional drugs). They are safe in pregnancy and can be given to young children.

Many conventional doctors have taken up homeopathy, which is most often used for conditions that tend to recur, such as ear infections, sinusitis, herpes and urinary infections, or in conditions that cannot be cured by conventional medicine such as ME, irritable bowel syndrome and pre-menstrual tension and in conditions where side effects of conventional drugs may cause severe side effects such as arthritis.

Critics of homeopathy point to the fact that some homeopaths discourage routine immunisations, which may leave children vulnerable to disease, and that many of the scientific studies are flawed. But homeopathy and conventional medicine dovetail nicely together - and that's how they should be used. Consulting a practitioner who is a trained doctor and a qualified homeopath (they will have the letters MFHom after their name) provides a neat way of benefiting from both disciplines.

The real point here - the one that Cameron's parents ignored - is that blind trust in any practitioner, medical or complementary, is unwise. We should follow our instincts - but our instinct should be to explore every avenue possible, and never to trust anyone too much.

If the GP sees your ill child and says it's a minor viral infection, you still need to keep your wits about you. If your child deteriorates and becomes increasingly unwell, it makes no sense to cling to the GP's opinion. You need to revisit the GP, ring NHS Direct, or go to a casualty department if you suspect your child has signs of a developing meningitis.

Neither doctors, parents nor homeopaths get it right every time. Illnesses evolve; most get better but some appear innocent to begin with and then develop into something more serious within few hours. A mild belly ache can become full blown appendicitis, vomiting that continues and worsens may herald a blockage in the gut.

Knee jerk reactions and blind predjudice - for or against conventional medicine - only blunt our ability to make a rational assessment. You don't need to be a doctor or a homeopath to know when a child is seriously sick. And if you're not sure, it pays to keep going back to an objective and trained professional for further checks.

Today scepticism, and the fear that we are not being told the full story, often drive people to seek advice from sources other than their local doctor, whether it's from an alternative practitioner, a book or the web. As a practising GP, I sometimes feel that if people were as sceptical of information they print off the internet, as they are of anything I tell them, it would be a far more level playing field. Things have not been helped by the Harold Shipman case, of course, and the inquiry into the poor performance of Bristol's paediatric heart surgeons has also led to a public realisation that some doctors perform better than others, and it's a matter or luck and postal code where you end up. And then of course there's our personal experience of doctors. A patient told me yesterday that she had just discovered that her private gynaecologist was barred from working in the NHS, and later struck off for abusing drugs. She continued to see him while he was still in private practice, however, blissfully unaware that he was under investigation and suspended from his NHS hospital. So it's not really a mystery that we choose to treat ourselves, that we are flocking to complementary therapists in unprecedented numbers and that we put our trust in practitioners such as homeopaths rather than visiting our GP. We may treat our children ourselves or take them to the complementary practitioners with us simply because we don't want them to have antibiotics (all that we will be offered by the GP) but get concerned when they have one cold after another or seem unwell. Or we may choose to use alternative therapies at every step, abandoning all conventional approaches to healthcare. Not that there's anything intrinsically wrong with alternative therapies and ideas per se. Homeopathy is a complete therapeutic system that aims to cure like with like. Developed by a German physician more than 200 years ago, it uses very dilute remedies of animal, vegetable and mineral origin. In the past 10 years there have been three major reviews of hundreds of well controlled trials which have shown that homeopathy is more effective than placebos and that the remedies certainly do no harm (more than can be said for many conventional drugs). They are safe in pregnancy and can be given to young children. Many conventional doctors have taken up homeopathy, which is most often used for conditions that tend to recur, such as ear infections, sinusitis, herpes and urinary infections, or in conditions that cannot be cured by conventional medicine such as ME, irritable bowel syndrome and pre-menstrual tension and in conditions where side effects of conventional drugs may cause severe side effects such as arthritis. Critics of homeopathy point to the fact that some homeopaths discourage routine immunisations, which may leave children vulnerable to disease, and that many of the scientific studies are flawed. But homeopathy and conventional medicine dovetail nicely together - and that's how they should be used. Consulting a practitioner who is a trained doctor and a qualified homeopath (they will have the letters MFHom after their name) provides a neat way of benefiting from both disciplines. The real point here - the one that Cameron's parents ignored - is that blind trust in any practitioner, medical or complementary, is unwise. We should follow our instincts - but our instinct should be to explore every avenue possible, and never to trust anyone too much. If the GP sees your ill child and says it's a minor viral infection, you still need to keep your wits about you. If your child deteriorates and becomes increasingly unwell, it makes no sense to cling to the GP's opinion. You need to revisit the GP, ring NHS Direct, or go to a casualty department if you suspect your child has signs of a developing meningitis. Neither doctors, parents nor homeopaths get it right every time. Illnesses evolve; most get better but some appear innocent to begin with and then develop into something more serious within few hours. A mild belly ache can become full blown appendicitis, vomiting that continues and worsens may herald a blockage in the gut. Knee jerk reactions and blind predjudice - for or against conventional medicine - only blunt our ability to make a rational assessment. You don't need to be a doctor or a homeopath to know when a child is seriously sick. And if you're not sure, it pays to keep going back to an objective and trained professional for further checks.

fields.headline: It's not what you know...
fields.standfirst: Her customised electronic address book contains as  many names as a small-town phone book. Guests queue around the block to swap cards at one of her VIP-studded parties.  Emma Brockes  meets the shy daughter of a sweet-shop owner who became London's networking queen
fields.trailText: Her customised electronic address book contains as  many names as a small-town phone book. Guests queue around the block to swap cards at one of her VIP-studded parties.  Emma Brockes  meets the shy daughter of a sweet-shop owner who became London's networking queen
fields.body:
In the corridor of Carole Stone's Covent Garden flat, the party is swinging. Stone, Britain's best connected - or at least, most fearsomely organised - networker, is weaving through the crowd doing what she does best. "This is Bill Bachle, he works with Steven Spielberg, this is Julie Mellor, head of the Equal Opportunities Commission, this is Malcolm Singer of the Yehudi Menuhin school, this is Tanya Wheway, she's been married four times." She disappears round the corner, leaving a small group of people blinking at each other under expensive lighting.

Carole Stone is the sort of person who it is easy to hate. She files her "friends" in a database of 13,700 names, logging their marital status, CV outlines and history of attendance at her soirees, with a tick box for whether to invite them to her Christmas party. She holds monthly salons for 90 people, at least half of them regulars in the national press, and spends £5,000 on her Christmas party. She has, on paper at least, all the credentials of a crawly sycophant or a shameless self promoter. And yet, while being one of the most successful socialisers in London, she is none of these things.

The scene in Stone's flat on Monday night is the 57-year-old's picture of heaven. Ruth Evans (former director of the National Consumer Council) and Yve Newbold (former company secretary of Hanson) are exchanging cards in her hallway. Anneka Rice is squeezing past Virginia Bottomley, who is squashed against Joan Ruddock, who is rubbing shoulders with a generous smattering of BBC commissioning editors. "Never thought I'd see Joan Ruddock and Virginia Bottomley having a civil conversation," hisses a delighted guest, before moving on to the room's most popular topics - Tony Blair (what a sinister bloke) and Greg Dyke (what a godsend).

Stone presides over the carnival like an excited child. There is a flower in her hair, and a big, wide smile on her big, wide mouth. It is a party to which guests come alone, safe in the knowledge that however slight their connection to her, Stone will remember their names, occupations and who in the world they would most like to meet. And there's a good chance they'll meet them. Rory Bremner and Selina Scott always draw a crowd; Tony Benn might be there, or Ken Clarke, or Jeremy Irons or Lynda La Plante - all have been known to queue around the block to get into one of Stone's bashes. On the phone before the party, Stone apologises for the B-list jumble expected that night. "There won't be any stars this time, I'm afraid. Last month I had the American ambassador and next month the Bishop of London is due, but no stars this time."

The most surprising fixture in this jamboree is Stone herself. She is not a hostess in the tradition of the French salon - petite, exquisitely made up, with an artillery of witty epigrams waiting to be fired. Rather, she is loud and goofy, like a cockney Tigger in Winnie the Pooh, bounding through the flat, throwing her paws around the waists of shy or aloof guests, until their shyness or aloofness has been beaten into retreat. She is loud, in that way shy people who have forced themselves out of it often are. She physically grabs people, propelling them through the room and forcing them to chat. She is immensely likable.

"She has this absolute talent for putting people at their ease," says Sara Nathan, journalist and former editor at Channel 4. "She knows how to get people to cut the crap," says Nancy Roberts, broadcaster and internet entrepreneur, "how to leave their egos at the door."

"I am like a puppy dog," says Stone, who married the television current affairs journalist Richard Lindley in June. "I always assume people are going to like me, not because I am wonderful, but because I like them. I am always slightly astonished if they say no, but I just wipe my nose and go off again. I'm sure a lot of people snub me and I don't realise it." This is not an act. In an industry where the parties are full of people sneaking hostile little looks around the room, Stone is a genuine antidote.

She comes from a background a million miles from her status as London's media queen. Her grandfather was "in and out of the workhouse". Her father, when he left the army, opened a sweet shop in Maidstone, then a tobacconist's on a council estate in Southampton. "Our little shop didn't do very well," she says. "We were in the red-light district, so dadda had to supplement our income with the baker's round." Before she was 20, three things turned Stone into the compulsive socialiser she has become: her late brother Roger's schizophrenia, her father's impatience with him, and her mother's strong character.

"We never had people home when I was young. Dadda and Roger were always fighting. My father used to be a boxer in the army and there were lots of fisticuffs. I needed friends so much because if you wanted to go down and have a coffee in the Wimpy with Roger, nobody would come with you because he would probably throw the bloody coffee over them. I realised how important it was to have friends."

Stone was a gawky girl, with huge feet and a big nose. She was painfully shy of her frame, her awkwardness, her zero confidence. Her mother, who one pictures in Stone's image but fiercer, tried to cajole her out of it. "My mother had this openness and this search for knowledge. She was always saying, 'look around the next corner, sweetheart, always look around the next corner'."

Her ambitions were vague however; Stone is no Becky Sharp. She dragged her feet round the circuit for shy girls with dim prospects: public speaking classes, secretarial college, the Youth Employment Bureau. Her mother kept on at her: "Why don't you be a journalist, dear?" she said, but the Youth Employment officer took one look at her and told her to stick to secretarial work.

It was not long after Stone got a job as a secretary in the BBC's Southampton newsroom that she started holding little tuna bean salad lunches that cost her £4.19 a head. She did it, she says, because the idea of mixing-up people she knew fascinated her. In the early days, this was a case of how would her cousin Irene get on with the weather caster at the station? As she got better connected, it became would William Waldegrave hit it off with Sinead Cusack? What if she introduced her mum to Claire Rayner, an agony aunt who might put her in touch with other mums of schizophrenic sons? The combinations were endless and Stone was an impassioned chemist.

"She is very straightforward and that makes a tremendous difference," says Nigel Osner, a lyricist and former barrister at the Lord Chancellor's office who has known Stone for many years. "She is warm and interested and she loves helping people." Through Stone, Osner was introduced to a composer with whom he now collaborates. "You drop in to see her and she will pick up the phone there and then and start calling people for you."

It took a long time for her to grow this confident, however. "When I entered a room, I didn't feel like, hi! It's me, I felt, gor blimey, it's me. I used to hero worship girls who were flighty and confident and slim because I was always overweight or big-boned as they used to call it. I looked at people with small noses thinking: why can't I look like that? There was a girl who always used to sit on the laps of the camera men; I thought if only I had the confidence to do that." Every morning, Stone hung around the newsroom door, waiting for someone else to arrive so she could sidle in undetected, in their wake.

But she was good at her job. In spite of her nerves, Stone was gregarious, deeply interested in other people and not in that cut-eyed, socially defensive way. "I was like my mother, who was never hindered by the fact she didn't go to university," she says. "She wouldn't say, oh! they're much richer than us we can't talk to them, she'd say, ooh, I wonder how they get on? I wonder how they do things?" This is Stone's philosophy, the "ooh, fancy that" approach to socialising.

She gave her first-ever Christmas party in the mid-70s, and they grew in size, from 100, to 250, to 300, until in 1999 the guest list reached 1,100, a queue snaked round the block and the fire officer shut her down. After she left the BBC in 1990 and didn't have a regular job, Stone's Christmas party cost double her total earnings for that year (£2,500), an indication that there is something mildly pathological about her socialising. She is obsessive, ultra-phobic, with the rare combination of claustrophobia and agoraphobia.

What drives her, she says, is the alchemy of getting the guest list just right. "It's not that I can pull people nobody else can pull, it's just that I can get the mix right. I love meeting people. If I miss something, I go into a decline. Everything is life or death to me. I make a drama of everything."

After her start at Radio Brighton, Stone became a regional news producer and two years after that, she produced Woman's Hour and Down your Way. In 1977, at the age of 35, she got her big break and the job that would make her the nucleus of a vast network of contacts. "I was asked if I would like to take over as producer of Any Questions. They said do you know about politics? Oh yes! I said and went to bed every night with Vascher's Parliamentary Companion. But it was absolutely right for me. It made me realise that people of extremely differing opinions don't mind meeting each other."

It was a post she would hold for 10 years: that's four high-profile guests a week, for 40 weeks a year, for 10 years, equalling a contacts book of 1,600 former cabinet ministers, Booker prize winners, columnists and commentators. She kept them in a Filofax, but she was so scared of losing it that she photocopied it. Nine years ago, she went electronic. A technician sat in her office for three weeks, listening to her calls, watching her network, finally customising a database that allowed her in an instant to see who she'd neglected and who over-favoured.

"Sometimes you think, gor, blimey, I know all these people, isn't it sensational! You feel absolutely wow-wee. And then the other half of you thinks, since they say it's not what you know but who you know, why am I not running the country?"

"Their great mistake was not making her producer of Question Time," says a BBC editor at her party. "It's still not right as a programme and she would have kicked it into shape."

She is making a good living, however. Stone's main source of income is as a media consultant, or a "facilitator", charging companies an annual fee to entertain their CEOs at one magnate-packed lunch a month. She recently hosted one for Marjorie Scardino, chief executive of the Pearson media group who turned up without a handbag and was "natural, easy", in spite of her unofficial status as Britain's most powerful woman. It is a title Stone might claim for herself. I ring to ask her to put me in touch with one of her clients, and 10 minutes later David Webster, the chairman of Safeway is on the phone, "only too delighted" to talk about her. "We have an association with Carole that goes back many years," he says. She organises small lunches for the supermarket chain's CEOs. "She is quite unique," says Webster. "She has this natural, warm way and her contacts transcend all worlds: arts, media, industry, which we are able to meet in a relaxed atmosphere. I am a great fan of hers."

Stone's salons, on the other hand, are free of charge, the fruit of her obsession. "People come because I'm not threatening, because I like people. Friendship is the core of life for me. You've got to be prepared to pop over to someone and say, 'Hi, I'm Carole', and for them to say, 'Oh yeah, so what?' It doesn't matter that someone snubbed me. What does it matter?"

She does it because she loves it; because it is the next best thing to what, in her heart, she always wanted to be, which was famous. "I always hoped I'd be a television personality, that I'd have my own shows, that I'd be the next Oprah Winfrey. But then, I suppose, my lunches are my shows." Her salon on Monday night fizzes with energy and she circulates not like a society queen, not like a hostess even, but like a woman regarding her own work, with wonder.

fields.headline:
No: 1610
 Michael Barrymore
fields.body:
Age: 47.

Appearance: Double-jointed.

Occupation: TV presenter turned serious actor. Currently starring in a drama about an insecure chat show host with a disastrous private life.

Ooh, that's a bit close to home: Actually, Michael is very happy with his handsome partner Shaun. The 21-year marriage to wife Cheryl and the serious drink problems are in the past and women fans have offered to give him their children for adoption.

So he's gone all serious then? Not judging by his behaviour at the London Restaurant Awards on Tuesday night.

Did he run across the stage scissoring his legs and shouting "awright"? No, he turned Wish You Were Here presenter Mary Nightingale upside down and swung her back and forth by the ankles.

Did Mary mind? "Luckily no one saw my bum," she said. The next day her bum was on the front page of the Sun.

Lucky the oaf stopped there. He didn't. He charged across the stage, grabbing potplants, microphones and light fittings and handing them to the audience before chasing Boyzone singer Ronan Keating, wrestling a journalist to the ground and ripping a male guest's shirt off.

Was there any alcohol at this party? Unlimited pink champagne.

Does Barrymore go to many awards ceremonies? At the national TV awards he cried and sang I Had a Dream to Trevor McDonald.

I vaguely remember the TV awards in 1997. Yes, he cried and said: "I'm making a right prat of myself."

Wise words. Not as wise as his speech to photographers while lying on the carpet at the TV Game Show awards in 1998: "Baby Jesus lay down on the clouds of heaven. Out of the womb, he doth writhe on the floor and no one knowest what he's at."

Not to be confused with: Noel Edmunds, Plastic Man, the prophet Isaiah.

Do say: "Easy, tiger."

Don't say: "More bubbly?"

fields.headline: The good old days
fields.standfirst:
Hilary Wainwright remembers the thrills and the challenges of working at County Hall in the 80s

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: I used to bump into at least two of the young lads who are now Blair's top advisers, Geoff Mulgan and David Miliband, when roaming the London corridors of County Hall in the 80s. So it is odd to hear Tony Blair and Frank Dobson talk about Ken Livingstone's dangerous policies. So much of the best of New Labour, or at least its rhetoric, can be traced back to Ken Livingstone's GLC.
fields.body:
I used to bump into at least two of the young lads who are now Blair's top advisers, Geoff Mulgan and David Miliband, when roaming the London corridors of County Hall in the 80s. So it is odd to hear Tony Blair and Frank Dobson talk about Ken Livingstone's dangerous policies. So much of the best of New Labour, or at least its rhetoric, can be traced back to Ken Livingstone's GLC.

The first sign that the GLC represented a new politics was that Livingstone did not ask for a Labour party card before offering five of us the politically sensitive job of setting up the council's economic policy group. At least two of us had never been party members. From the start, his approach was inclusive. He appointed his new staff because of their ideas and their experiences.

Certainly the popular planning unit, which I directed as part of an innovative, bottom-up industrial strategy, was an independently minded gang of ex-shop-floor leaders, feminist organisers and writers, experienced adult educationists and community organisers.

Our job was to stir up Londoners - not that they needed much stirring - to open up County Hall, to demand that its resources and expertise be put at the service of local communities and workplaces to create and save jobs. Here again, Livingstone showed that he had broken with the old sectarianism of Labour. Groups would be supported regardless of their politics. If they had good ideas for jobs, they would get our backing - whether they were Liberal Democrats, Greens, Tories or fed up with party politics.

Our work was about exactly the kind of community-led regeneration which is now advocated by the prime minister's Social Exclusion Unit. If the GLC's policies for employment were damaging, then so is the government's New Deal for Communities - a policy that suggests some of the GLC's thinking is alive and well in Whitehall.

We worked closely with local business. We did this through the GLC's Greater London Enterprise Board - a body that was partnership incarnate. It gave money to local businesses on the basis of an agreement between itself, the employers and the trade unions. In this way we created hundreds of good jobs. So much for the idea that the GLC's policies were destructive.

The GLC's industrial strategy was not simply about jobs; it was about economically viable, socially useful and ecologically sustainable innovation. With the help of Mike Cooley the Greater London Enterprise Board created technology networks to work with inventors and innovators and create new kinds of companies whose greatest asset was the knowledge and technological skills of their workers. Sounds familiar? The GLC was trying to nurture the knowledge economy before Tony Blair had even logged on.

Similar pioneering work was done in the food industry and in fair trading. The Food Alliance and Twin Trading are two lasting refutations of the accusation that GLC projects were profligate and ill-conceived. Twin Trading has launched two of the most popular Fair Trade products in the UK: Café Direct and Divine chocolate.

Another innovative approach to partnership Tony Blair must have subconsciously, and half-heartedly, imbibed was our work with the voluntary sector. We knew that County Hall did not have the detailed know-how to solve the problems facing women, ethnic minorities, lesbians and gays, disabled people. So the GLC funded groups created by the people directly affected: childcare groups, women's centres, police monitoring groups, a lesbian and gay help line, groups representing the disabled.

When Tony Blair waxes lyrical about the voluntary sector it could be Ken Livingstone speaking. The difference is that Ken Livingstone was prepared to let go of power at the centre. That's why, in the end and after a long courtship, Londoners loved him. Tony Blair behaves as if he's frightened of the consequences of democracy. That is why he risks the people's rejection.

There has always been something brittle about New Labour. It's evident in the rigidity of their control mechanisms and in their unconfident approach to debate and dissent. But New Labour's self-destructive response to Livingstone and its rubbishing of the GLC reveals something more fundamental: New Labour is built on a myth. It is a peculiarly English myth that the left, which gained such influence in the party in the late 70s and 80s, could be dismissed as either unreconstructed defenders of the command economy or as sectarian Trots.

Sectarian Trots did indeed have a noisome presence in some branches of the Labour party. But Livingstone demonstrated another left, the memory of which seems to be repressed: a left that was innovative, radically democratic and determinedly egalitarian. It was a powerful and effective force. New Labour tried to kill it and then steal its clothes.

 Hilary Wainwright is editor of Red Pepper. From 1982-6 she was assistant chief economic adviser to the GLC and directed its Popular Planning Unit
