webTitle: We can't afford Brown's bills, say businesses

fields.headline: We can't afford Brown's bills, say businesses
fields.trailText: Business leaders yesterday attacked Gordon Brown for undermining their efforts to improve productivity by boosting demand and risking higher interest rates, writes Mark Atkinson.
fields.body:
Business leaders yesterday attacked Gordon Brown for undermining their efforts to improve productivity by boosting demand and risking higher interest rates, writes Mark Atkinson.

The British Chambers of Commerce said that by increasing public spending without raising consumer taxes, the Budget increased pressure on manufacturers from the strong pound. "Business is carrying the can for his spending increases," said Ian Peters, deputy director general of the BCC, said: "You risk competitiveness and investment in higher productivity if you handicap business through higher interest rates."

Earlier, the chancellor urged delegates to the an nual BCC conference in London to close the productivity gap with Britain's main competitors.

While acknowledging the difficulties faced by exporters, Mr Brown said: "We have some world-class sectors, some global champions in whom we take pride. But let's face facts. We have not had enough of them over the last 50 years.

"Productivity growth has been just over 2.5% a year, compared to between 3.5% and 4% among our major European competitors."

The BCC director general, Chris Humphries, complained that despite manufacturers improving productivity by 5% in the past year, they were unable to offset the 11% increase in costs due to the pound's rise.

fields.headline: 'Great big field' bought for R&D
fields.trailText: The property company Slough Estates is to spend £125m developing a new research park in Cambridge, to help house the region's booming hi-tech industry. The group has bought a greenfield site just north of the city from the pension trustees of the Harmsworth family - who control Associated Newspapers.
fields.body:
The property company Slough Estates is to spend £125m developing a new research park in Cambridge, to help house the region's booming hi-tech industry. The group has bought a greenfield site just north of the city from the pension trustees of the Harmsworth family - who control Associated Newspapers.

Slough's chief executive Derek Wilson said: "At the moment it looks like a great big field with a few ornamental lakes in it. But the land has been prepared for the development of offices and research and development space." The purchase price is believed to be around £40m. Slough has earmarked about £85m to construct facilities for internet and bioscience start-ups.

Slough inherits planning consent to build 570,000sq ft of business space. A telecoms company, Cambridge Cable, has already signed up for 73,000sq ft.

Mr Wilson said there would be room for about 10 medium-sized companies, or many more smaller ones. He added: "Things are moving very, very fast in Cambridge. It's one of the fastest growing areas of the country for hi-tech businesses."

About 1,200 hi-tech companies are based around Cambridge, employing some 35,000 people. The city already has several business campuses, the biggest of which - Cambridge Science Park - is home to more than 50 companies, with over 1.2m sq ft of laboratories and offices. It is owned by Trinity College.

Among the companies on the Cambridge Science Park are Celltech, Tadpole Technology and the inkjet printing group Xaar. Slough's strategy is to concentrate resources in locations "attractive to growth industries". It has already invested £1.6bn in locations along the Thames Valley.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Juniors share in Sachs stock
fields.body:
Juniors share in Sachs stock

Goldman Sachs said yesterday that 13,000 junior staff would be granted 2m shares worth on average more than $15,300 a person. The New York-based firm said the one-off grant would allow junior professionals to participate in the benefits of stock ownership and a "culture rooted in teamwork". The move follows a similar share-out at the time the firm floated two years ago.

Virgin loses out on SA flights

A furious Sir Richard Branson yesterday rounded on the government after his airline, Virgin Atlantic, lost out to arch-rival British Airways in a route battle. BA, which operates six flights a week between London and Cape Town, had objected to a decision by the civil aviation authority to allow Virgin to fly a second service on this route.

But deputy prime minister John Prescott overturned the ruling yesterday and said the extra frequency should go to BA. "I've heard of crass decisions by government before but this one beats them all," said Sir Richard, the Virgin chairman.

"I had hoped that the days of unreasonable, heavyhanded state intervention were over."

Finance chief quits Boo.com

Online retailer Boo.com yesterday confirmed that its finance director, Dean Hawkins, had resigned after only two months in order to join Dutch internet firm Chello before its flotation. Mr Hawkins, 38, is to leave immediately.

Boo.com also announced net revenues in the fourth quarter to January 31 of £429,000, while revenues in February alone stood at £414,000; it said these figures were in line with internal targets.

Greenspan urges caution

US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan said the central bank must maintain its "vigilant, non-inflationary" monetary policy in order to prevent the swift pace of the economy from sending prices sharply higher.

In remarks prepared for a conference at the White House, Mr Greenspan praised new technologies for lifting worker productivity, but cautioned that demand for goods and services continues to outstrip supply, leading to imbalances in the economy.

Setback for C&W bidder

Shares in Pacific Century CyberWorks dropped 11% to their lowest close since January 7, leading some analysts to worry about the valuation of its bid for Cable & Wireless.

Hong Kong's biggest capitalisation "new economy" stock closed at HK$14.95, down 32.5% from February 29, when it said it would swallow blue chip stalwart C&W in Asia's biggest merger deal to date. Another couple of dollars' decline could persuade minority shareholders to reconsider the offer.

webTitle: Aid for coal industry 'on the way'

fields.headline: Aid for coal industry 'on the way'
fields.trailText: A £70m government plan to shore up Britain's ailing coal industry is close to being agreed, coal industry leaders said yesterday.
fields.body:
A £70m government plan to shore up Britain's ailing coal industry is close to being agreed, coal industry leaders said yesterday.

The claim came as RJB, the company which controls 60 per cent of the country's pits, reported a loss after tax of £130m up to last December, compared with a £40.1m profit in 1998.

Ministers have expressed sympathy with the coal industry and are awaiting a decision by the European Commission. Trade union leaders yesterday said they were confident that the industry would get the cash.

Richard Budge, RJB's chief executive, warned against Britain becoming solely dependent on gas and nuclear power. He said that his 13 mines ran at a third of the cost of German collieries, and a fifth of those in Italy, both of which received substantial government subsidies.

The industry had made a "robust" case for aid to the De partment of Trade and Industry. "It would be ridiculous to be losing UK jobs when European governments are subsidising theirs," he said.

Mr Budge said that while he was disappointed that he had not received a decision from the government, he realised "these are very difficult choices." He added: "They need to be well thought out, but we are confident they are seriously looking at our proposals."

The company said that the losses included one off charges of £141m. Of that, £15.8 m came from redundancy and pit closure costs with the rest from a revaluation of colliery assets.

The company has promised to keep all its 13 pits open if its demands for aid are met in full. If not it will close Ellington colliery in the north-east.

Ian Lavery, Northumberland secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers, said that RJB's losses confirmed that the company could not compete against foreign subsidised competitors.

webTitle: Newcastle posts loss of £1.3m as transfer freeze hits bites

fields.headline: Newcastle posts loss of £1.3m as transfer freeze hits bites
fields.trailText: A freeze on transfers has triggered a spiralling wage bill at Newcastle United which yesterday announced a pre-tax loss of £1.3m for the six months to January 31.
fields.body:
A freeze on transfers has triggered a spiralling wage bill at Newcastle United which yesterday announced a pre-tax loss of £1.3m for the six months to January 31.

The football club, 11th in the premier league, racked up pre-tax profits of £5.6m this time last year but has since undergone a troubled restructuring.

Plans to make way for lucrative business clients in a redeveloped stadium at the expense of season ticket holders sparked fury earlier this year.

And derogatory comments about women and fans made by some of the club's directors two years ago still rankle. In response, outgoing chairman Freddie Fletcher yesterday took the highly unusual step of issuing a public apology to fans.

"The disruption relating to the stadium, and indeed our own handling of this has severely tested our relationship with our fans. Undoubtedly mistakes have been made in how we handled the communication of these issues," he said.

The club's poor first half financial results were largely due to a freeze on transfers which had swollen under the previous manager Ruud Gullit.

The freeze was necessary, according to Fletcher, to allow new manager Bobby Robson to make his own review of the squad. However, operating profit excluding transfers was 2% higher at £5.8m and turnover up 12% to £28.1m.

The club is confident that the combination of Robson, a redeveloped stadium and a lucrative deal with cable TV operator NTL will relegate the bad times to the past.

An enlarged St James Park will open in August and Newcastle is banking on the extra capacity to propel it back into the black.

"There will be bums on all of the seats come August and the increased capacity will generate more income to allow us to compete with rival clubs," said Fletcher. The new stadium will house 52,000 spectators against 36,000 now.

The club also plans to sell 13 players and forge a smaller squad with the implied lower wage costs. Robson's strategy is, Fletcher said, "more quality and less numbers".

Fletcher, who will step down on May 31, will become a non-executive director. Shares in the group closed at 58p yesterday (no change).

webTitle: A spectacular own goal at half-time

fields.headline: A spectacular own goal at half-time
fields.standfirst: Notebook Exchange integrity in question
fields.trailText: Just as there is never a bad time to score a goal, so there is never a good time for a stock exchange system to crash. But as the soccer pundits will opine at length, timing can still be psychologically critical - snatching the lead just before the break, for example. On that basis, yesterday's systems crash in London represents a spectacular own goal by the stock exchange right on half-time.
fields.body:
Just as there is never a bad time to score a goal, so there is never a good time for a stock exchange system to crash. But as the soccer pundits will opine at length, timing can still be psychologically critical - snatching the lead just before the break, for example. On that basis, yesterday's systems crash in London represents a spectacular own goal by the stock exchange right on half-time.

These are crucial months for Europe's traditional exchanges. They are under threat from new exchanges and from electronic trading systems. Their efforts to build a pan-European structure to meet the competitive challenge are threatening to fragment. Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels are in the process of merger. That puts the onus back, very firmly, on London and Frankfurt.

Nothing new there, you might think. The British and German exchanges were the front-runners in trying to create a cross-border alliance. But the game has moved on.

The question is now one of full blown merger rather than alliance. Not long ago such a prospect was unthinkable but the LSE's decision to demutualise and Frankfurt's plans to open up its shareholder base make a corporate merger technically possible.

The second hurdle is technology. London and Frankfurt - and others - have different trading platforms. Though most pan-European efforts have so far centred on a fudge -the creation of a trading structure, rather than a single platform - it would be much simpler to choose one platform from the pack.

So this is not the time to be seen as technologically challenged.

But yesterday's market antics raise deeper questions about what equity professionals refer to as "the integrity of the market". The LSE has never been a popular institution and the sense yesterday that its technicians did not really know what had gone wrong will not have helped matters.

The past decade has seen the exchange stripped of its job of settling share transactions, it has effectively lost its monopoly on disseminating company information and it is also due to relinquish its role as the listings watchdog to the Financial Services Authority.

Stripping the LSE of its role as the operator of the market's trading mechanism - the bit that broke down yesterday - would leave this institution out of a job.

Options fuss

Controversy over rewards for top bosses is nothing new. But Barclays' attempt to try to revolutionise the way its top managers are paid is facing more criticism than most. While Barclays disputes the claims by pay experts that its complicated scheme could see top executives receive options on shares worth 36 times their salaries and bonus, it cannot dispute that it faces opposition from the influential corporate governance watchdog Pirc.

Pirc, which puts caveats on its recommendation to oppose the scheme on the basis that Barclays is yet to respond to its analysis, is agitated about a number of things, including the fact that there is no attempt to estimate what the cost of the scheme will be to shareholders.Pirc believes the scale of the awards is "potentially excessive" and the two perfor mance criteria based on "economic profit" and the bank's performance relative to its peers may not "stretch" the executives in a way commensurate to the potential rewards. The three-year period over which the performance is measured is also "too short".

Barclays has a valid point that any attempt to try to measure the value of any options award is impossible as no one can know where the bank's share price will be trading in three years time. It is also fair to say that the bank would have to put in a stellar performance if it were to reward its executives to anything approaching the maximum.

But it is the wording of the scheme which is causing most difficulty. According to Barclays, it is not supposed to be complicated. Executives can be awarded as much as 200% of their basic pay and bonus in options, but it is unlikely that it would be more than 150%.

Then options are awarded on the ba sis of the Black Scholes model, popular in the US and which roughly means the option is worth a third of the underlying share - which means that any options grant should be three times more.

Then, the potential payout of the options is based on two criteria. The confusion arises because Barclays insists no more than 8,000 should be allowed to be based on the measure of economic profit - a miniscule proportion of the amount which would be awarded to chief executive Matt Barrett - with the rest based on the performance of the bank's shares relative to its peers.

It is all very north American and its planned introduction should not be surprising, given that Mr Barrett spent all his working life in Canada. He is right to want to introduce a scheme which rewards him and his colleagues for superlative performance. Once again, though, the bank has had trouble with the delivery of its plan.

webTitle: Rift between the odd couple widens

fields.headline: Rift between the odd couple widens
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: Honeymoon over for government and business as small print in Brown's budgets starts to bite
fields.trailText: Before the election Labour wooed the City and leading corporations with a charm bordering on infatuation. But the course of true love never runs smooth and the honeymoon between Labour and business has been officially declared over.
fields.body:
Before the election Labour wooed the City and leading corporations with a charm bordering on infatuation. But the course of true love never runs smooth and the honeymoon between Labour and business has been officially declared over.

Chris Humphries, the director general of the British Chambers of Commerce blames lack of communication - the reason why many marriages break down. "They listen but they do not hear," he says of ministers.

At the BCC's annual conference in London this week the mood has definitely darkened. Three years into Labour's term firms have recovered from their surprise that the government has cast aside its socialist origins. Now, according to Ian Peters, the BCC's deputy director, they want to see if the pro-business rhetoric translates into reality.

So far, according to Mr Peters, the signs are not encouraging. "Business is now very sceptical over whether minister's words mean anything," he said earlier this week, following the keynote appearance of the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, at the BCC conference.

Mr Byers came bearing gifts - a raised threshold for annual audit requirements which will save small firms £180m a year and a promise to consult on the implementation of the part-time working directive - but his audience remained stonily unimpressed.

Mr Peters says the audit concession is not new - it was promised a year ago - and that a consultation period for new regulations should be automatic not a special concession. But the real reason why the temperature at gatherings like the BCC's is heating up is that the small print in Mr Brown's budgets is starting to bite. Behind the headline-grabbing cuts to corporate taxes, the government's programme of re-regulating the labour market - the working time directive, the minimum wage and parental leave provisions are adding to the costs business faces.

To compound their problems, the burden of administering many of the gov ernment's social measures - the working families tax credit is the prime example - falls on firms. This week companies around Britain will take over from the Inland Revenue the task of calculating and paying the WFTC entitlements to low income employees.

The BCC estimates it already costs the smallest businesses £279 per employee per year to collect tax on the government's behalf. Larger firms enjoy economies of scale, which means they can do the job cheaper.

Business has always played a bigger role as a calculator and collector of taxes in Britain than in other countries where the burden falls more on the individual in the form of annual tax returns. But the problem for small firms is increasing as the government seeks to merge the benefits system with the tax regime.

The BCC estimates that the combined cost of all these measures has added £10bn a year to the costs of running British business. Mr Byers' promise of a £180m saving on audit costs is small beer in comparison.

In the audience at the BCC, Charles Rose, director of OnCd Ltd., an electronic publishing company based in Hertfordshire, admits he was never won over by Labour's charm offensive. The problem his firm faces is the amount of regulation the government has piled on to business. "It's a culture that says we now have a better regulation unit, not a deregulation unit and that's very uncomfortable," says Mr Rose. "We need to get government off the back of business to get business back, manufacturing, and succeeding."

Mr Rose says the government "goldplates" European directives - implements them strictly without any exceptions even when the EU rules provide for them. Like many small businessmen, he suspects that European laws are followed to the letter in Britain and widely ignored elsewhere in the Union.

The government's red-tape buster, Lord Haskins, admitted yesterday the government is producing new rules at a rate of 4,000 a year. But he still claims that regulation is not the biggest problem facing sterling. Some pundits say business is protesting too much. Despite the pre-election prawn cocktail offensive, Labour was clear that it planned to tip the balance back in favour of workers. Even after the changes of the last three years, Britain is still a lightly regulated economy by comparison with most of Europe.

And besides, with an election campaign in sight, it would be naive to imagine that the government wouldn't turn its attention to topics dearer to voters: the decision to pour money into the health service for example. Business doesn't vote.

The government believes firms should be grateful for the stability it has provided. The economy is in its seventh year of growth, with unemployment at a 20-year low and no sign of resurgent infla tion. But as manufacturers have been telling the government this week, while the economy as a whole may be robust, industry is squealing under the pressure from the pound's seemingly unstoppable rise up the foreign exchanges.

Mr Byers echoed the governor of the Bank of England and the chancellor in his speech to the BCC: massaging sterling down would threaten the government's inflation target. For many firms this simply isn't good enough and the loosening of fiscal policy in Mr Brown's recent budget which may add to the pressure on sterling simply added insult to injury.

Far from being grateful for the economic stability the government has provided, many businesspeople give the previous government the credit for it and praise Labour only for not cocking it up.

Perhaps it was always an odd match: more of an arranged marriage than a true meeting of minds. But as David Blunkett told the BCC this week, the honeymoon was always going to end. Every couple argues, is the new line. Mr Blunkett said business and the government should aspire to a stable relationship rather than a marriage. But for some in his audience the question now is whether divorce isn't a better option.

webTitle: Black men joking about cannibalism and sweat made of chocolate. Oh, how we laughed

fields.headline: Black men joking about cannibalism and sweat made of chocolate. Oh, how we laughed
fields.standfirst: The bad old days of British comedy
fields.trailText: Back in the 60s there was a black comedian called Charlie Williams. He said, in his broad Yorkshire accent: "If you don't laugh, I'll bring my tribe in and we'll eat the lot of you." White audiences in northern working-men's clubs split their sides.
fields.body:
Back in the 60s there was a black comedian called Charlie Williams. He said, in his broad Yorkshire accent: "If you don't laugh, I'll bring my tribe in and we'll eat the lot of you." White audiences in northern working-men's clubs split their sides. In the 70s Williams was joined by Kenny Lynch, who made regular TV appearances as the butt of Bruce Forsyth's and Jimmy Tarbuck's jokes about black people. Then, in the 80s, came Lenny Henry, who wore a towering red, green and gold woolly hat and called himself Algernon Razzmatazz. His catchphrase was a croaky: "Ooookaaaay!"

Black British comedy has come a long way since then, with the demise of the "single black comic" or SBC, who stood up alone to embody his race, then told offensive jokes about black people. In the 80s a boom in the number of black comics forced white audiences to broaden their notion of "black humour", while drawing increasing numbers of black people into comedy venues. These new comedy fans didn't want to hear their background mocked.

Today the stand-up circuit boasts an array of black stars, such as Richard Blackwood, Felix Dexter, Junior Simpson, Gina Yashere, Curtis Walker, Robbie Gee, Angie Le Mar, Felicity Ethnic, Eddie Nestor, Geoff Schumann and Marcus Powell. "It's almost certain that with a good bill, a black comedy night will sell out," says Roland Muldoon, artistic director of London's Hackney Empire, one of the leading venues for black comedy.

On Monday black comics' achievements will be celebrated at the first Black International Comedy Awards (Bica). But before the comedy business starts patting itself on the back, there are a few problems to address. For a start, some "black comedians" don't even like the term. "When I started out it was fine to call me a black comedian," says Richard Blackwood, the circuit's hottest property, who has his own show on Channel 4. "But I think now I'm just a comedian. It's sad that when a black person is successful the issue of his or her colour always has to be there first, before what they have achieved. And I find this is very much from our own people too. I'd rather just be known as a comedian. It's obvious what race I am. It goes without saying."

Even those closely involved with the awards would rather they didn't exist. "In a perfect world the Bica would not be taking place," says Burt Laurent, its director. "But we are not getting the recognition in the mainstream, so we have to do it ourselves."

Curtis Walker, who has been a stand-up for 18 years, makes a similar point: "Television has not done black comedy a favour. Every few years a black show comes along, then disappears. These shows should be an integral part of TV, not just put in the ghetto slot. But the change is starting to come, with more black comics doing mainstream shows.

"But if it wasn't for Charlie and Lenny doing what they did," he adds, "a lot of black performers wouldn't be anywhere near telly today."

So what exactly did they do? Williams, now 72, was the first black British comic to enjoy mainstream TV success. In the early 70s he was a resident on Granada TV's influential stand-up show The Comedians. He hosted the popular game show The Golden Shot and in 1973 topped the bill in Scarborough, breaking box- office records. Here's one of his jokes: "I invited a fellow round to dinner last night. Half-way through the meal he says, 'I don't like your mother-in-law.' So I said, 'Leave her on the side of the plate and just eat the chips and peas.' "

Of course "jokes" like this were not the only kind the Yorkshire-born comedian did. "When Enoch Powell said, 'Go home, black man,' I said, 'I've got a hell of a long wait for a bus to Barnsley,' " Williams recalls. "People would tell me that because I was coloured and had a Yorkshire dialect, it sounded funny, me telling them jokes. But I don't have any regrets. I told jokes that I thought would suit the audience."

"I was telling jokes for a human race," Williams continues. "So people could have a laugh. There are Jewish jokes, Irish jokes, Scottish ones. So why not coloureds? If you stop telling jokes about the nationalities, you've got nothing left. But if you were offended I apologise. I didn't set out to offend. I went out so that people could laugh."

Williams says he wasn't an SBC. Not exactly. He met two other comics on The Comedians - Josh White and Sammy Thomas - both from Lancashire. He says he was the only black comic on the Yorkshire club circuit but recalls someone before him, when Williams was still a professional footballer for Doncaster Rovers. "There was a man called Astor Garricks - a comedian. I remember him because he was a big supporter of Middlesbrough.

"One game, I heard a booming voice behind Middlesbrough's goal: 'This place ain't big enough for the two of us!' It was Astor. He was well-known in the northern clubs. He was different from any other performer I'd seen because he didn't just stay on the stage. He'd climb down into the audience and walk around. He was a 6ft 2in black man. And I was half-caste. Astor used to say to the audience: 'If you don't laugh at my jokes I'll eat you up. I've had a missionary for my tea before.' " Williams chuckles. "It was kind of funny, them days."

In his 1995 biography, Lenny Henry says that at 16 he knew he didn't want to do the kind of comedy Williams did. Yet at the start of his career Henry spent five years as the SBC touring with the Black and White Minstrel Show. He also regretted doing the kind of joke where he would wipe his sweating brow and say he was leaking chocolate. He writes: "I knew there had to be a better way of trying to put your messages over, putting your jokes over, without having to pick on people because of their colour or because of their race and gender."

What's interesting about Henry's comedy is how it evolved in tandem with his sense of self. There are few performers who publicly admit their mistakes and rectify them in front of you. Still, you sensed that when everyone was attacking Henry, they forgot that not every black person is going to be Malcolm X. And they don't have to be. But that's the SBC's burden. When Walker says the new kids on stage owe something to Henry, it is hard to disagree. With Williams, it's a bit easier. But there is no doubt he opened doors for Henry and many others.

Direct evidence that Henry helped the new generation is The Real McCoy. A lot of material and writers for the BBC2 black and Asian comedy-sketch series came from Step Forward, a workshop Henry set up to find black and Asian talent, when he realised he was the only black writer working on the Lenny Henry Show.

The black comedy circuit is not faultless - occasionally you still hear gags that are offensive to black people - but then no race is perfect, or homogenous. Yet there is something about the dynamic of this environment (a black comedian and a mainly black audience) that is very different from that of the SBC and a mainly white audience. This doesn't make these gags excusable, but the taste they leave in your mouth is nowhere near as bitter as it would once have been.

The Black International Comedy Awards are at the Dominion Theatre, London W1 (0870 607 7420), on Monday. The Richard Blackwood Show is on Channel 4 from May 3.

The Black International Comedy Awards are at the Dominion Theatre, London W1 (0870 607 7420), on Monday. The Richard Blackwood Show is on Channel 4 from May 3.

fields.headline: War games
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements  sees a reworked Silver Tassie triumph in Dortmund
fields.trailText: The usual problem for composers these days is not so much getting a commission to write an opera but securing further performances after the initial production. Opera companies would rather bask in the glory of a world premiere than revive a work that another house has launched.
fields.body:
The usual problem for composers these days is not so much getting a commission to write an opera but securing further performances after the initial production. Opera companies would rather bask in the glory of a world premiere than revive a work that another house has launched. Yet if a new opera is to stand any chance of gaining a toe-hold in the international repertory, it needs to start carving its own niche as soon as possible. So it is hugely encouraging that less than six weeks after Mark-Anthony Turnage's The Silver Tassie was first performed at the Coliseum by English National Opera it has been seen in Germany, at Dortmund's opera house. With the ENO staging off to Dallas in two years, and talk of an Irish production next season, the opera seems to be well on its way.

In an area of Germany where every major town has an opera house, the Dortmund company has established a distinctive profile. Under the leadership of John Dew, the company stages unfamiliar works - whether brand new or neglected - alongside repertory staples. The current season has included the world premiere of Alexander Goehr's Kantan and Damask Drum, and Meyerbeer's rarely heard Dinorah, sandwiched between Tristan, Carmen, Die Fledermaus and Evita. It's a refreshing mixture.

Standards at Dortmund seem impressive too. Orchestrally and vocally, The Silver Tassie is challenging, but apart from one or two ragged edges, David Neely conducted a fine account of the score. Amanda Holden's libretto came over crystal-clear from the mainly English-speaking cast, and outstanding performances included William Killmeier as hero Harry Heegan (in a wheelchair for the second half), Gundula Schneider as Susie, Susan Benkin as Mrs Heegan and Michael Kupfer as Barney.

What was even finer, though, was the staging, which gave the work and its anti-war subject matter the universality any durable opera needs. Instead of the woolly minded literalism of Bill Bryden's production for ENO, the German director Ralf Nürnberger treated the scenario more timelessly, sometimes abstractly. He banished the specious Irishness that clogged the action in London, yet gave each of the four acts a distinct flavour.

As Nürnberger and his designer Thomas Gruber demonstrated, The Silver Tassie has a hugely potent resonance, capable of seizing the attention of any international audience. The first world war trenches of O'Casey's original play became a wasteland of luminous barbed wire and drifting smoke in which the soldiers' fate was pitilessly determined, giving the act more momentum than the Coliseum's static treatment.

By bringing out the black humour of the first act, the work was given the essential edge of irony that was entirely blunted in the London show. It became an authentic tragi-comedy.

These perceptions benefited Turnage's music hugely, too. The way in which the stage action here was so finely tuned to what was going on in the orchestra underlined the subtlety of his dramatic instincts and how his musical language is precisely moulded to the subject matter. What sometimes seemed like standard operatic set pieces in London became something much more personal and subversive, and future productions will doubtless uncover even more layers and subtleties.

Performances continue in Dortmund until June. The ENO production of The Silver Tassie will be shown on BBC2 on April 30.

fields.headline: The great Dane
fields.standfirst:
Derek Malcolm picks his 100 greatest movies. This week, number 62: Carl Dreyer's Day of Wrath
To comment on Derek Malcolm's choices, visit www.filmunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm picks his 100 greatest movies. This week, number 62: Carl Dreyer's Day of Wrath
fields.body:
It is quite common to hear film people, even critics, acknowledge Carl Dreyer's greatness with the merest hint of a yawn, as if this Danish director of The Passion of Joan of Arc (1928), Vampyr (1932), Ordet (1955) and Gertrud (1964) was a film-maker relevant to film history but not to us today. Yet Godard paid tribute to him in Vivre Sa Vie (1962); and Antonioni, Resnais and other directors who came to prominence in the 60s freely acknowledge their stylistic and moral debt to him.

Nothing could be further from the truth than to characterise him as a close relative to Shakespeare's gloomy Dane and his films as too slow and lingering, too concerned with martyrdom and suffering, and too intent on marketing a gaunt spirituality to reach out to modern audiences. Vampyr, for instance, was one of the most poetic horror films ever made, and Day of Wrath (1943) one of the most terrifying.

The fact is that almost all Dreyer's films, stretching through the silent era into sound, etch themselves in the memory. And if they deal with the kind of subject matter today's film-makers, and some audiences, find largely beyond them, that is surely not to his discredit. He stands among the greatest, most profound, artists of the 20th century.

Day of Wrath is about the persecution of witches in the 17th century and is sometimes seen as an allegory of the German occupation of Denmark. Anne, the second wife of an old pastor, who has given refuge to an alleged witch, discovers that her own mother, also accused of witchcraft, was saved from the stake by the pastor in exchange for her hand. Falling in love with her stepson, she is wracked with guilt and confesses to her husband. When he dies from the shock, Anne is denounced as a witch and burnt at the stake.

The film - in some ways reminiscent of the paintings of Dutch masters - examines the cruelty of the time, which is supposed to be the workings of divine law. One of the two central characters admits under torture that she is a witch; the other volunteers to die, convinced of her own evil. Dreyer's measured pace and stark visuals - long, horizontal pans and close-ups of riven faces - accompanied as they are by acting of intense realism, make this a morality play of enormous power.

The scenes of torture and burning, though discreetly handled, are almost unbearable, at least partly because the torturers and burners are not mere hysterics but convinced they have divine justice on their side.

What Dreyer achieves is the sense that for these sternly Protestant people, whose inscrutable faces conceal great passion, witchcraft was a frightening reality. He does not argue for or against them, but simply, as one critic has said, evokes the dark night of the soul through an intensely physical world. Most directors refine their style towards the end of their lives, and Dreyer did so with Gertrud, which some regard as one of the dozen or so greatest films ever made and others as an impenetrable bore; just as The Passion of Joan of Arc is regarded either as a masterpiece of the silent cinema or redeemed only by the luminous face of Renée Falconetti.

Dreyer was not everybody's director. He was, however, over some 45 years of work, a unique and innovating talent.

Credits

Director Carl Dreyer

Starring Thorkild Roose, Lisbeth Movin

Denmark, 1943, 105 minutes

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: The odium of sodium | Thereby hangs a very long tail
fields.body:
The odium of sodium
And now, a new horror on the roads, according to US scientists. Sodium azide is used in pesticides, detona tors, airline safety chutes - and automobile airbags. It looks like sodium chloride, or table salt, but it is as deadly as sodium cyanide. As little as two thousandths of an ounce can lead to coma, a few grams can kill. It used to be rare, but now the stuff is everywhere. Eric Betterton of the University of Arizona told the American Chemical Society that 5m kilos has already hit the road in US airbags. "Given the huge surge in production, there exists a greatly increased potential for significant accidental spills and subsequent human exposure," he warned.

Thereby hangs a very long tail
In 1996, the spacecraft Ulysses, which was supposed to be monitoring the sun's magnetic field, suddenly went bananas. More precisely, it sent off a set of puzzling readings which Geraint Jones of Imperial College and George Gloeckler of the University of Maryland finally make sense of in two papers in Nature today. Ulysses, they agree, had sailed through the unexpectedly-extended wake of comet Hyakutake. Nobody expected the trail of ionised particles to be anywhere near Ulysses at the time: Hyakutake was a half a billion kilometers away. "That's more than three times the distance from the earth to the sun," said one researcher. "It's just unbelievable."

For soy, read new sea food
Paul Brown of Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana, has a new outlet for surplus soy beans. Eight or nine strains of Pacific salmon are now endangered, so it's farmed fish for a fulfilling future. But fish meal is too expensive to feed to fish. So let them eat beans, he says. Soy-fed fish excrete less phosphorus and nitrogen, which means less pollution. By 2035, fish farms could soak up between 40% and 90% of the current soybean output of the United States. He fed the stuff to yellow perch, which then produced quality fillets. He tried it on trout. Next trick: crustaceans, normally fed on cod bones, head and guts. "There's a shortage of cod. Plus, cod racks don't keep well in storage. Lobster producers need a more storable feed," he said.

Not for delicate stomachs
Being sick is time consuming, but not for thornback rays. A team from Aberdeen University report in Nature today that they fed chopped fish to Raja clavata and then an emetic. The rays didn't just bring up the food, they brought up their stomachs, inside out. They rinsed them by shaking in the water and swallowed them again. Gastric grooming was a useful way of getting rid of crunchy prawn shells. The process took as little as four seconds.

webTitle: Hamilton handed full-time post with Canaries

fields.headline: Hamilton handed full-time post with Canaries
fields.trailText: Norwich City have appointed the 54-year-old former Northern Ireland manager Bryan Hamilton as their manager on a permanent basis.
fields.body:
Norwich City have appointed the 54-year-old former Northern Ireland manager Bryan Hamilton as their manager on a permanent basis.

Hamilton had been acting in a caretaker capacity since the resignation of Bruce Rioch on March 13. He was initially employed at Carrow Road as director of football during Rioch's spell at the club.

His first game in charge saw Norwich win 2-0 at Ipswich, although they were beaten at home by the First Division's bottom club, Swindon, in his next match and have remained in mid-table since.

"I am delighted the board and I have agreed so quickly," Hamilton said. "Norwich City is an excellent club and the board and I are ambitious."

Aston Villa have reacted to a slump in attendances by reducing admission prices next season. They were disappointed with both season ticket sales last summer and attendances in this campaign.

Next season no fan will pay more and some tickets will be between £1 and £6 less than this season, meaning a saving of up to £114 for some supporters. The move has been made in conjunction with the rebuilding of the Trinity Road stand which will increase ground capacity to 43,000.

The Birmingham City midfielder Bryan Hughes has had the second of the two bookings he collected against Wolverhampton Wanderers on Saturday rescinded. He was booked for diving but the referee Eddie Wolstenholme changed his mind after watching a video of the incident.

Tranmere Rovers have reported a profit of £46,023 for the last financial year, thanks mainly to net income from transfer fees of £1,729,521. The loss before transfer fees was put at £1,530,463.

The annual report said the club were able to continue trading only because of player sales, creative financial planning and the continuing support of Peter Johnson, who recently sold his interest in Everton. The report showed Johnson was owed £5,561,431 last June and was charging no interest.

webTitle: Horlock puts City in cruise control

fields.headline: Horlock puts City in cruise control
fields.trailText: Man City 2 - 0 Bolton
fields.body:
It is somehow so typically Manchester City that they have already negoiated their top scorer Shaun Goater's release for next month's play-offs. After this result, though, football's favourite sadomasochists may not need to put themselves through that particular torture.

Joe Royle's team swaggered through the first half, deservedly taking the lead through Kevin Horlock and Paul Dickov, before slipping into cruise control for their third win in a row to make them favourites for the second automatic promotion spot behind Charlton Athletic.

City doing things the easy way; whatever next?

Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce had reiterated his fear before the match that his team may end up being known as the "nearly men" of the season. Beaten in the semi-finals of both cups, they needed victory last night to maintain their bid for a place in the play-offs.

But fears of Wembley fatigue seemed well-founded as Bolton's defence, shorn of Paul Ritchie and Gudni Bergsson, presented early chances to Goater and Dickov. Neither took advantage, with Goater firing over from close range and Dickov failing to stretch Jussi Jaaskelainen, but City did not have to wait long.

In the 18th minute Mark Fish failed to cut out Dickov's perceptive pass, allowing Horlock to open the scoring with a composed finish and make a point to Royle, who had left him out of the previous seven matches.

Five minutes later it was 2-0, as Dickov emphatically beat Jaaskelainen after more hesitant defending by John O'Kane and Allan Johnston. O'Kane was withdrawn almost immediately but City nearly added a third within moments, Jimmy Phillips deflecting the outstanding Danny Tiatto's pass onto the crossbar.

City have unashamedly ground out results in recent months, but this was as stylish a performance as has been seen here in years. Bolton were overwhelmed and Goater should have added to their woes just before the break.

The second half was less eventful. Goater sat out the final 40 minutes and Gerard Wiekens was moved up to the midfield, almost scoring with a low drive that skidded wide.

Bolton, however, rarely threatened to force a draw, Johnston curling their best effort just over the crossbar.

webTitle: Thompson leaves it late to stun Owls

fields.headline: Thompson leaves it late to stun Owls
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 0 - 1 Aston Villa
fields.body:
These are terribly bleak days at Hillsborough as Sheffield Wednesday's second lowest Premiership crowd of the season, just over 18,000, left for home last night with nothing to comfort them from this barren performance against a make-do and mend Villa side who won the match in injury time with a headed goal by Alan Thompson from Steve Stone's cross.

Watford's manager Graham Taylor remarked last weekend that, with relegation a virtual certainty, there were times when he wishes it could be over and done with and the new season begun. Wednesday would surely agree now, and welcome the hangman's rope as a friend.

Wednesday had every reason to fancy their chances with Villa's team much changed from their FA Cup semi-final on Sunday. No Gareth Southgate, no George Boateng, no Paul Merson - and, above all, for the sake of spice and perhaps spite, no Benito Carbone.

But although Villa were not exactly brimming with confidence for much of the time against Bolton, trusting more to caution than flair for fear of losing a second semi-final, they were generally quicker to the ball and considerably more poised than Wednesday.

Dion Dublin, making his first start since his neck operation, had an early chance to underline Villa's general dominance, latching on to a ball from Mark Delaney, but the England striker knocked the chance wide. Even before that Alan Wright had picked out Thompson, only for Kevin Pressman to take his shot comfortably.

Wednesday's main threat coming from Gilles de Bilde via the left, the Belgian beating David James with a low shot from Andy Hinchcliffe's swift cross but hitting the outside of the post.

Dublin made more solid contact with the woodwork three minutes before half-time when his carefully controlled header from Lee Hendrie's floated cross just lacked the angle to slip inside Pressman's right-hand post with the Wednesday goalkeeper comprehensively beaten.

John Gregory continued to shuffle his side around in the second half, as if anxious to give everyone a kick rather than the result of any coherent thought process. And for a while Wednesday seemed as if they might profit from Villa's understandable lack of cohesion.

The small amount of half decent football on display in the first half fast disappeared into the clear skies, although there was just a chance that Wednesday's sense of urgency, befitting their parlous position, might break the mediocre deadlock.

But it was Thompson who managed this as the match drifted towards its conclusion and it was hardly a surprise.

webTitle: Berkovic inspires Celtic as Dalglish ultimatum pays off

fields.headline: Berkovic inspires Celtic as Dalglish ultimatum pays off
fields.trailText: Celtic 4 - 0 Motherwell
fields.body:
Celtic picked up three points that will not really matter but Eyal Berkovic produced a performance which might count for a lot. The Israeli, frequently the scapegoat of the fans, was outstanding for the second time in four nights. Having feasted on Kilmarnock on Sunday, he had second helpings against Motherwell.

Kenny Dalglish had given his squad a powerful ultimatum after last month's Old Firm defeat - play for your places or you will not be at the club next season. The evidence last night was that it had concentrated minds wonderfully.

Tommy Johnson clearly wants to stay. Celtic's most effective forward in the last few matches eased his team-mates worries as early as the ninth minute. Motherwell's John Davies brought down Regi Blinker 25-yards out and Johnson curled in a wicked free-kick that gave the goalkeeper Stephen Woods no chance.

With Mark Viduka heading against the bar from Berkovic's 17th-minute, Celtic appeared to have plenty in hand against a side one place behind them in the League.

But controversy surrounded their second goal in the 32nd minute. Motherwell's Don Goodman was involved in a collision on half way which did not look serious. But after rising and tak ing a few steps he collapsed. The team doctor and physio were sufficiently concerned to sprint on without waiting for permission.

With Goodman's team-mates distracted the Celtic youngster Steven Crainey crossed and Berkovic controlled the ball with his thigh before shooting home right-footed from close range.

Dalglish's threat was obvious through the match. Celtic could have relaxed with the game won but in a three-minute period, Johnson and Viduka doubled the scoreline as Motherwell tired.
